But [Louise of Stolberg]233-louise had doubtless absorbed , from [[her]233-louise mother]600-her mother , from [[her]233-louise older fellow - [canonesses]1016-canonesses]1015-her older fellow - canonesses , nay , from [the very school - girls in [the convent]1018-the convent where [she]233-louise had been educated]1017-the very school - girls in the convent where she had been educated , [all proper views , negative and positive , on the subject of marriage]1019-all proper views , negative and positive , on the subject of marriage ; nor must [we]1010-we give to [a girl who was probably still too much of a child]1020-a girl who was probably still too much of a child , [too much of [an unromantic little woman of [the world]573-the world]1022-an unromantic little woman of the world , undeserved pity on account of degradation which [she]233-louise had most probably , as yet , not sufficient moral nerve to appreciate]1021-too much of an unromantic little woman of the world , undeserved pity on account of degradation which she had most probably , as yet , not sufficient moral nerve to appreciate . [[Her]233-louise husband]790-her husband was old , [he]790-her husband was ugly , [he]790-her husband was not attractive ; [he]790-her husband may have been tiresome and rather loathsome in [his]790-her husband constant attendance ; [he]790-her husband may even have smelt of brandy every now and then ; but as marriages had been invented in order to give [young women]1025-young women a position in [the world]573-the world , [husbands]1027-husbands were not expected to be much more than drawbacks to the situation ; and as to the sense of life - long dependence upon [an individual]1028-an individual , as to the desire for love and sympathy , it was still too early in the eighteenth century , and perhaps , also , too early in the life of [a half - Flemish , half - German girl]1029-a half - flemish , half - german girl , very childish still in aspect , and brought up in the worldly wisdom of [a noble chapter of [canonesses]1016-canonesses]1030-a noble chapter of canonesses , to expect anything of that kind .

There must , however , from the very beginning , have been something unreal and uncanny in [the girl]599-the girl 's situation . [The huge old palace]1033-the huge old palace , crammed with properties of [dead Stuarts]1034-dead stuarts and [Sobieskis]261-the sobieskis , with [its]1033-the huge old palace royal throne and daïs in [the ante - room]1035-the ante - room , its servants in [the royal liveries of [England]13-england]1036-the royal liveries of england , must have been full of rather lugubrious memories . Here [James III]252-james iii . of [England]13-england and VIII . of [Scotland]37-scotland had moped away [his]252-james iii bitter old age ; here , years and years ago , [[Charles Edward]204-charles edward 's mother]1037-charles edward 's mother , [the beautiful and brilliant grand - daughter of [John Sobieski]273-john sobieski]1038-the beautiful and brilliant grand - daughter of john sobieski , had pined away , bullied and cajoled back from [the convent in which [she]1037-charles edward 's mother had taken refuge]1039-the convent in which she had taken refuge , perpetually outraged by the violence of [[her]1037-charles edward 's mother husband]790-her husband and the insolence of [[his]790-her husband mistress]934-his mistress ; it was [an ill - omened sort of place for [a bride]1043-a bride]1042-an ill - omened sort of place for a bride . Around extended [the sombre and squalid [Rome]10-rome of the second half of the eighteenth century]1044-the sombre and squalid rome of the second half of the eighteenth century , with [[its]10-rome huge ostentatious rococo palaces and [churches]1046-churches]1045-its huge ostentatious rococo palaces and churches , [its]10-rome straggled , [black and filthy streets]1047-black and filthy streets , [its]10-rome ruins still embedded in nettles and filth , [[its]10-rome population]1048-its population seemingly composed only of [monks]1049-monks and [priests]1050-priests for [all men of the middle - classes]1051-all men of the middle - classes wore the black dress and short hair of [the clergy]1052-the clergy , or of [half - savage peasants]1053-half - savage peasants and [workmen]1054-workmen , bearded creatures , in wonderful embroidered vests and scarves , looking exceedingly like [brigands]1055-brigands , as [Bartolomeo Pinelli]274-bartolomeo pinelli etched [them]1056-them even some thirty years later . [A town]1057-a town where every doorway was [a sewer by day]1058-a sewer by day and a possible hiding - place for [thieves]1059-thieves by night ; where [no woman]1060-no woman durst cross [the street]1061-the street alone after dusk , and [no man]1062-no man dared to walk [home]1063-home unattended after nine or ten ; where , driving about in [her]1064-her gilded state - coach of an afternoon , [[the Pretender]605-the pretender 's bride]1066-the pretender 's bride must often have met a knot of people conveying [a stabbed man the average]1067-a stabbed man the average gave more than one assassination per day to [the nearest barber]1068-the nearest barber or [apothecary]1069-apothecary , the blood of [the murdered man]1070-the murdered man mingling , in the black ooze about the rough cobble - stones over which [the coaches]1071-the coaches jolted , with the blood trickling from the disembowelled sheep hanging , ghastly in [their]1072-their fleeces , from the hooks outside [[the butchers]1073-the butchers ' and [cheesemongers]1075-cheesemongers ' shops]1074-the butchers ' and cheesemongers ' shops ; or returning [home]1063-home at night from the opera , amid the flare of [the footmen]1077-the footmen 's torches , must have heard the distant cries of [some imprudent person struggling in the hands of [marauders]1079-marauders]1078-some imprudent person struggling in the hands of marauders ; or , again , on Sundays and holidays have been stopped by the crowd gathered round [the pillory]1080-the pillory where [some too easy - going husband]1081-some too easy - going husband sat crowned with a paper - cap in a hail - storm of mud and egg - shells and fruit - peelings , round the scaffold where [some petty offender]1082-some petty offender was being flogged by [the hangman]1083-the hangman , until the fortunate appearance of [a clement cardinal or the rage of the sympathising mob]1084-a clement cardinal or the rage of the sympathising mob put a stop to the proceedings . Barbarous as [we]1085-we remember the [Rome]10-rome of [the Popes]1086-the popes , [we]1085-we must imagine it just a hundred times more barbarous , more squalid , picturesque , filthy , and unsafe if [we]1085-we would know what it was a hundred years ago .

But in [this barbarous Rome]1087-this barbarous rome there were things more beautiful and wonderful to [a young Flemish lady of the eighteenth century]1088-a young flemish lady of the eighteenth century than [they]1089-they could possibly be to [us]1085-we , [indifferent and much - cultured creatures of the nineteenth century]1090-indifferent and much - cultured creatures of the nineteenth century , who know that most art is corrupt and most music trashy . [The private galleries of [Rome]10-rome]1091-the private galleries of rome were then in process of formation ; pictures which had hung in [dwelling - rooms]1092-dwelling - rooms were being assembled in [those beautiful gilded and stuccoed saloons]1093-those beautiful gilded and stuccoed saloons , with [their]1093-those beautiful gilded and stuccoed saloons out - look on to [the cloisters of a court]1094-the cloisters of a court , or the ilex tops or orange espaliers of [a garden , filled with the faint splash of the fountains outside]1095-a garden , filled with the faint splash of the fountains outside , the spectral silvery chiming of musical clocks , where , unconscious of [the thousands of beings who would crowd in there armed with guide - books and opera - glasses in the days to come]1096-the thousands of beings who would crowd in there armed with guide - books and opera - glasses in the days to come , only [stray foreigners]1097-stray foreigners were to be met , [foreigners who most likely were daintily embroidered and powdered aristocrats from [England]13-england or [Germany]66-germany]1098-foreigners who most likely were daintily embroidered and powdered aristocrats from england or germany , if [they]1098-foreigners who most likely were daintily embroidered and powdered aristocrats from england or germany were not [men like [Winckelmann]275-winckelmann]1099-men like winckelmann , or [Goethe]276-goethe , or [Beckford]277-beckford . It was the great day , also , for excavations ; the vast majority of antiques which [we]1085-we now see in [Rome]10-rome having been dug up at that period ; and among [the ilexes of [the Ludovisi and Albani gardens]1101-the ludovisi and albani gardens]1100-the ilexes of the ludovisi and albani gardens , among the laurels and rough grass of [the Vatican hill]1102-the vatican hill , porticoes were being built , and [long galleries]1103-long galleries and temple - like places , where [a whole people of marble]1104-a whole people of marble might live among the newly - found mosaics and carved altars and vases . Moreover , there was at that time in [Rome]10-rome a thing of which there is now less in [Rome]10-rome than anywhere , perhaps , in [the world]573-the world - a thing for which [English and Germans]1106-english and germans came expressly to [Italy]3-italy : there was music . A large proportion of the best new operas were always brought out in [Rome]10-rome - always four or five new ones in each season ; and [the young singers from [the conservatorios of [Naples]67-naples]1108-the conservatorios of naples came to [the ecclesiastical city]1109-the ecclesiastical city , where [no actresses]1110-no actresses were suffered , to begin [their]1107-the young singers from the conservatorios of naples came to the ecclesiastical city , where no actresses were suffered , to begin their career in the hoop skirts and stomachers , and powdered toupés with which the eighteenth century was wo nt to conceive the heroines of ancient greece and rome career in the hoop skirts and stomachers , and powdered toupés with which the eighteenth century was wo nt to conceive [the heroines of ancient [Greece]68-greece and [Rome]10-rome]1111-the heroines of ancient greece and rome]1107-the young singers from the conservatorios of naples came to the ecclesiastical city , where no actresses were suffered , to begin their career in the hoop skirts and stomachers , and powdered toupés with which the eighteenth century was wo nt to conceive the heroines of ancient greece and rome . [The bride of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward]1112-the bride of charles edward was [herself]1112-the bride of charles edward [a tolerable musician]1113-a tolerable musician , and [she]1112-the bride of charles edward had a taste for painting and sculpture which developed into a perfect passion in after life ; so , with respect to art , there was plenty to amuse [her]1112-the bride of charles edward .

It was different with regard to society . By insisting upon royal honours such as had been enjoyed by [[his]204-charles edward father]649-his father , but which [the Papal Court]1115-the papal court , anxious to keep on good terms with [England]13-england , absolutely refused to give [him]204-charles edward , [the Pretender]605-the pretender had virtually cut [himself]605-the pretender and [[his]605-the pretender wife]908-his wife out of all Roman society ; for [he]605-the pretender would not know [the nobles]1118-the nobles on a footing of equality , and [they]1118-the nobles , on the other hand , dared know [him]605-the pretender on no other . The great entertainments in [the palaces where [Charles Edward]204-charles edward had so often danced]1119-the palaces where charles edward had so often danced , the admired of [all beholders]1120-all beholders , in [his]204-charles edward boyhood , were not for [the Count]1121-the count and [Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]1122-countess of albany . There remained [the theatres]1123-the theatres and public balls , to which [the Pretender]605-the pretender conducted [[his]605-the pretender wife]908-his wife with the assiduity of [a man immensely vain of having on [his]605-the pretender arm [a woman far too young and too pretty for [his]605-the pretender deserts]1127-a woman far too young and too pretty for his deserts]1126-a man immensely vain of having on his arm a woman far too young and too pretty for his deserts . And , besides this , there was a certain amount of [vague , shifting foreign society]1128-vague , shifting foreign society , [nobles on the loose]1129-nobles on the loose , and [young men]1130-young men on [their]1130-young men grand tour , who mostly considered that a visit to [the Palazzo Muti]1131-the palazzo muti , or at least a seemingly accidental meeting and introduction in the lobby of [a theatre]1132-a theatre or [the garden of [a villa]1134-a villa]1133-the garden of a villa , was an indispensable part of [their]1130-young men sight - seeing . [Such people as these]1135-such people as these were [the guests of [the Palazzo Muti]1131-the palazzo muti]1136-the guests of the palazzo muti ; and , together with [a few Jacobite hangers - on]1138-a few jacobite hangers - on , constituted [the fluctuating little Court of [Louise]233-louise , Queen of [Great Britain]40-great britain , [France]35-france , and [Ireland]41-ireland , whom [the people of [Rome]10-rome]1140-the people of rome , hearing of the throne and daïs in [the ante - room]1035-the ante - room and of the royal ceremonial in [the palace near [the Santissimi Apostoli]69-the santissimi apostoli]1142-the palace near the santissimi apostoli]1139-the fluctuating little court of louise , queen of great britain , france , and ireland , whom the people of rome , hearing of the throne and daïs in the ante - room and of the royal ceremonial in the palace near the santissimi apostoli , usually spoke of as [the Regina Apostolorum]1143-the regina apostolorum ; while only [a very few]1144-a very few , who had approached [that charming little blonde lady]1145-that charming little blonde lady , corrected the title to that of [Queen of Hearts]1146-queen of hearts , [Regina dei Cuori]278-regina dei cuori . Among [the few who bowed before [[Charles Edward]204-charles edward 's wife]1148-charles edward 's wife , in consideration of [this last - named kingdom]1149-this last - named kingdom]1147-the few who bowed before charles edward 's wife , in consideration of this last - named kingdom , was [a brilliant , wayward young man]1150-a brilliant , wayward young man , destined to remain [a sort of brilliant , wayward , impracticable child]1151-a sort of brilliant , wayward , impracticable child until [he]1150-a brilliant , wayward young man was eighty ; and destined , also , to cherish throughout the long lives of [both , the sort of half genuine , half affected , boy]1152-both , the sort of half genuine , half affected , boy 's , or rather page 's , passion with which [Queen Louise]279-queen louise had inspired [him]1150-a brilliant , wayward young man . [Karl Victor von Bonstetten]280-bonstetten , of [a patrician family of [Bern]70-bern]1153-a patrician family of bern , [a Frenchified German]1154-a frenchified german , more French , more butterfly - like than [any real Frenchman , even of the old régime]1155-any real frenchman , even of the old régime , came to [Rome]10-rome , already well - known by [his]1150-a brilliant , wayward young man romantic friendship with [the Swiss historian [Müller]281-müller]1156-the swiss historian müller , and by the ideas which [he]1150-a brilliant , wayward young man had desultorily and gaily aired on most subjects , in the year 1773 . In [his]1150-a brilliant , wayward young man memoirs [he]1150-a brilliant , wayward young man wrote as follows of [the " Queen of Hearts]3882-the " queen of hearts "[1150-a brilliant , wayward young man] : " [She]3882-the " queen of hearts was of middle height , fair , with dark - blue eyes , a slightly turned - up nose , and a dazzling white English complexion . [Her]3882-the " queen of hearts expression was gay and espiègle , and not without a spice of irony , on the whole more French than German . [She]3882-the " queen of hearts was enough to turn all heads . [The Pretender]605-the pretender was tall , lean , good - natured , talkative . [He]605-the pretender liked to have opportunities of speaking English , and was given to talking a great deal about [his]605-the pretender adventures - interesting enough for [a visitor]3884-a visitor , but not equally so for [[his]605-the pretender intimates]3885-his intimates , who had probably heard those stories a hundred times over . After every sentence almost [he]605-the pretender would ask , in Italian , ' Do [you]3886-you understand ? ' [[His]605-the pretender young wife]3887-his young wife laughed heartily at the story of [his]605-the pretender dressing up in [woman]3888-woman 's clothes . "[1150-a brilliant , wayward young man] [A dull , garrulous husband]1157-a dull , garrulous husband , boring [people]927-people with stories of which [they]927-people were sick ; [a childish little wife]1159-a childish little wife , trying to make the best of things , and laughing over the stale old jokes ; this is what may be called the idyllic moment in the wedded life of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward and [Louise]279-queen louise . What would [she]1159-a childish little wife have felt , [that strong , calm lady]1160-that strong , calm lady , growing old far off in [the Isle of Skye]71-the isle of skye , had [she]1159-a childish little wife been able to see what [Bonstetten]280-bonstetten saw ; had [she]1159-a childish little wife heard [the Count]1121-the count and [Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]1122-countess of albany laughing , [the one with the laughter of an old sot]1163-the one with the laughter of an old sot , the other with the laughter of [a giddy child]1164-a giddy child , over the adventures of [that heroic Prince Charlie whose memory was safe in [her]1159-a childish little wife heart as the sheets [he]1165-that heroic prince charlie whose memory was safe in her heart as the sheets he had slept in were safe in her closet had slept in were safe in [her]1159-a childish little wife closet]1165-that heroic prince charlie whose memory was safe in her heart as the sheets he had slept in were safe in her closet , waiting to be [her]1159-a childish little wife grave - clothes ?

Forty - four years later , when [the Queen of Hearts]1166-the queen of hearts was [a stout , dowdy old lady , with no traces of beauty]1167-a stout , dowdy old lady , with no traces of beauty , and [himself]280-bonstetten [a flighty , amiable old gossip of seventy]1168-a flighty , amiable old gossip of seventy , [Karl Victor von Bonstetten]280-bonstetten wrote to [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri from [Rome]10-rome]1169-the countess of albany from rome : " [I]280-bonstetten never pass through [[the Apostles]3889-the apostles ' square]3890-the apostles ' square without looking up at [that balcony]3891-that balcony , at [that house where [I]280-bonstetten saw [you]1169-the countess of albany from rome for the first time]3892-that house where i saw you for the first time . "[280-bonstetten]

CHAPTER IV .

[THE HEIR]1170-the heir .

In 1765 [Horace Walpole]257-walpole , mentioning the now - ascertained fact of [the Pretender]605-the pretender 's abjuration of [Catholicism]262-catholicism , informed [[his]1172-his friend]1173-his friend [Mann]207-sir horace mann that a rumour was about that [Charles Edward]204-charles edward had declared [his]204-charles edward intention of never marrying , in order that [no more Stuarts]1174-no more stuarts should remain to embroil [England]13-england . This magnanimous resolution , which was a mere repetition of an answer made years ago by [[the Pretender]605-the pretender 's father]1176-the pretender 's father , did not hold good against the temptations of [the Cabinet of [Versailles]23-versailles]1177-the cabinet of versailles . There is something particularly disgusting in the thought that , merely because [the French Government]1178-the french government thought it convenient to keep [a Stuart]204-charles edward in reserve with whom , if necessary , to trip up [England]13-england , [the once magnanimous Charles Edward]204-charles edward consented to marry in consideration of a certain pension from [Versailles]23-versailles ; to make money out of any possible or probable son [he]204-charles edward might have . This , however , was the plain state of the case ; and [Louise of Stolberg]233-louise had been selected , and married to [a drunkard old enough to be [[her]233-louise father]1180-her father]1179-a drunkard old enough to be her father , merely that this honourable bargain between [the man outraged in 1748]1181-the man outraged in 1748 , and the Government which had outraged [him]1179-a drunkard old enough to be her father , might be satisfactorily fulfilled .

[The Court of [Versailles]23-versailles]606-the court of versailles wasted [its]606-the court of versailles money : [the officially - negotiated baby]1183-the officially - negotiated baby was never born . Nay , [Sir Horace Mann]207-sir horace mann , [the English Minister at [Florence]9-florence , whose spies watched every movement of [the Count]1121-the count and Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]1184-the english minister at florence , whose spies watched every movement of the count and countess of albany , was able to report to [[his]207-sir horace mann Government]1186-his government , in answer to a vague rumour of the coming of [an heir]992-an heir , that [the wife of [Charles Edward Stuart]204-charles edward]686-the wife of charles edward stuart had never , at any moment , had any reasons for expecting to become [a mother]657-a mother . And when , in the first years of this century , [Henry Benedict]267-henry , [Cardinal York]265-cardinal york , [the younger brother of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward]1190-the younger brother of charles edward , was buried where [the two melancholy genii of]1191-the two melancholy genii of [Canova]72-canova keep watch in [St. Peter 's]73-st. peter 's , opposite to the portrait of [Maria Clementina Sobieska]253-maria clementina sobieska in powder and paint and patches , a certain solemn feeling came over [most Englishmen]1192-most englishmen with the thought that the race of [James II]238-james ii . was now extinct .

But [the world]573-the world had forgotten that [the children of [Edward IV .]282-edward iv .]1194-the children of edward iv . were resuscitated ; that [the son of [Louis XVI]283-louis xvi . , whose poor little dead body had been handled by [the Commissary of [the Republic]1197-the republic]1196-the commissary of the republic]1195-the son of louis xvi . , whose poor little dead body had been handled by the commissary of the republic , had returned to [earth]1198-earth in the shape of [five or six perfectly distinct individuals]1199-five or six perfectly distinct individuals , [Bruneau]284-bruneau , [Hervagault]74-hervagault , [Naundorff]75-naundorff , whatever else [their]1199-five or six perfectly distinct individuals names ; that [King Arthur]285-king arthur is still living in [the kingdom of Morgan le Fay]1200-the kingdom of morgan le fay ; and [Barbarossa]286-barbarossa still asleep on the stone table , waiting till the rooks which circle round [the Kiefhäuser hill]1201-the kiefhäuser hill shall tell [him]286-barbarossa to arise ; and [the world]573-the world had , therefore , to learn that [a Stuart]943-a stuart still existed . The legend runs as follows .

In 1773 , [a certain Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton , [a staunch Jacobite]1204-a staunch jacobite , who had fought at [Culloden]60-culloden , was attracted , while travelling in [Italy]3-italy , by the knowledge that [[his]287-dr. beaton legitimate sovereigns]1205-his legitimate sovereigns were spending part of the summer at [a villa in [the neighbourhood]1207-the neighbourhood]1206-a villa in the neighbourhood , to [a vague place somewhere in [the Apennines]48-the apennines between [Parma]76-parma and [Lucca]77-lucca , distinguished by the extremely un - Tuscan name of [St. Rosalie]78-st. rosalie]1208-a vague place somewhere in the apennines between parma and lucca , distinguished by the extremely un - tuscan name of st. rosalie . Here , while walking about " in [the deep quiet shades]3893-the deep quiet shades , "[1209-the doctor] [the doctor]1209-the doctor was one day startled by a " calash and four , with scarlet liveries , "[288-st. andrew] which dashed past [him]1209-the doctor and up [an avenue]1210-an avenue . During the one moment of its rapid passage , [the Scotch physician]1211-the scotch physician recognised in [the rather apocalyptic gentleman]1212-the rather apocalyptic gentleman wearing the garter and the cross of [St. Andrew]288-st. andrew , who sat by the side of [a beautiful young woman]1213-a beautiful young woman , " [the Bonnie Prince Charlie of [[our]3895-our faithful beau ideal]3896-our faithful beau ideal]3894-the bonnie prince charlie of our faithful beau ideal , still the same eagle - featured , royal bird , which [I]1213-a beautiful young woman had seen on [[his]1213-a beautiful young woman own mountains]3897-his own mountains , when [he]1213-a beautiful young woman spread [his]1213-a beautiful young woman wings towards the south . "[1213-a beautiful young woman] Towards dusk of that same day , as [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton was pacing up and down [the convent church of St. Rosalie]1214-the convent church of st. rosalie , doubtless thinking over that " eagle - featured royal bird , "[1216-this person] whom [he]287-dr. beaton had seen driving in the calash and four , [he]287-dr. beaton was startled in [his]287-dr. beaton meditations by the jingle of spurs on [the pavement]832-the pavement , and by the approach of [a man " of superior appearance]3898-a man " of superior appearance . "[3898-a man " of superior appearance]

[This person]1216-this person was dressed in a manner which was " a little equivocal , "[1216-this person] wore a broad hat and a thick moustache , which , joined with the sternness of [his]1216-this person pale cheek and the piercingness of [his]1216-this person eye , must indeed have suggested something extremely eerie to [a well - shaven , three - corner hat , respectable man of the eighteenth century]1217-a well - shaven , three - corner hat , respectable man of the eighteenth century ; so that [we]1218-we are not at all surprised to hear that [the doctor]1209-the doctor 's imagination was crossed by " a sudden idea of the celebrated Torrifino , "[1216-this person] who , although [his]1216-this person name sounds like a sweetmeat , was probably one of [the many mysterious [Italians]289-italians , [brothers of the Count of Udolpho]1221-brothers of the count of udolpho and [Spalatro]290-spalatro and [Zeluco]291-zeluco , who haunted [the readers of the romances of the latter eighteenth century]1222-the readers of the romances of the latter eighteenth century]1220-the many mysterious italians , brothers of the count of udolpho and spalatro and zeluco , who haunted the readers of the romances of the latter eighteenth century . [This personage]1223-this personage enquired whether [he]1216-this person was addressing " [il Dottor Betoni Scozzere]292-il dottor betoni scozzere . "[1216-this person]

[The physician]1224-the physician having answered this question , asked , for no conceivable reason , in bad Italian of [a Scotchman]1225-a scotchman by [a Scotchman]1225-a scotchman for [we]1218-we learn that [the unknown]1227-the unknown was a [Chevalier Graham]293-the mysterious chevalier graham , [the mysterious moustached man]1228-the mysterious moustached man requested [him]1209-the doctor to attend at once upon " [one who stood in immediate need]3899-one who stood in immediate need . "[1228-the mysterious moustached man] [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton 's enquiries as to the nature of the assistance and [the person who required it]1229-the person who required it , having been answered with the solemn remark that " the relief of the malady , and not the circumstances of [the patient]3900-the patient , is the province of [a physician]3901-a physician , "[1228-the mysterious moustached man] and the proposal being made that [he]1209-the doctor should go to [the sick person]1230-the sick person blindfolded and in [a shuttered carriage]1231-a shuttered carriage , [the doctor]1209-the doctor 's prudence and the thought of [the famous Torrifino]1233-the famous torrifino dictated a flat refusal ; but [the mysterious stranger]1234-the mysterious stranger would not let [him]1209-the doctor off . " [Signor]199-signor mario pratesi , "[1209-the doctor] [he]1209-the doctor exclaimed persistently talking bad Italian , " [I]1209-the doctor respect [your]199-signor mario pratesi doubts ; by one word [I]1209-the doctor could dispel them ; but it is a secret which would be embarrassing to [the possessor]3902-the possessor . It concerns the interest and safety of one - [the most illustrious and unfortunate of [the Scottish Jacobites]3904-the scottish jacobites]3903-the most illustrious and unfortunate of the scottish jacobites . "[1209-the doctor] " What ! Whom ? "[287-dr. beaton] exclaimed [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton . " [I]1235-the stranger can say no more , "[1235-the stranger] replied [the stranger]1235-the stranger ; " but if [you]199-signor mario pratesi would venture any service for [one who was once the dearest to [[your]199-signor mario pratesi country]3906-your country and [your]199-signor mario pratesi cause]3905-one who was once the dearest to your country and your cause , follow [me]1235-the stranger . "[1235-the stranger] " Let [us]3907-us go , "[287-dr. beaton] cried [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton , the enthusiasm for [Prince Charlie]204-charles edward entirely getting the better of the thought of [the famous Torrifino]294-the famous torrifino ; and so , blindfolded , [he]1209-the doctor was conveyed , partly by [land]1236-land and partly by water what water , in [those Apennine valleys where there are no streams]1237-those apennine valleys where there are no streams save torrents in which even a punt would be impossible , it is difficult to understand , to [a house standing in [a garden]1239-a garden]1238-a house standing in a garden . That [it]1238-a house standing in a garden did stand in [a garden]1239-a garden appears to have been a piece of information volunteered by [the mysterious Chevalier Graham]293-the mysterious chevalier graham , for [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton expressly states that it was not till [the two]1241-the two had passed through a " long range of [apartments]3908-apartments "[293-the mysterious chevalier graham] that the bandage was removed from [his]1209-the doctor eyes .

[The doctor]1209-the doctor found [himself]1209-the doctor in [a ' splendid saloon]1243-a ' splendid saloon , hung with crimson velvet , and blazing with mirrors which reached from the ceiling to the floor . At the farther end a pair of folding doors stood open , and showed the dim perspective of [a long conservatory]1244-a long conservatory . " [The mysterious Chevalier Graham]293-the mysterious chevalier graham rang a silver bell , which summoned a little page dressed in scarlet , with whom [he]293-the mysterious chevalier graham exchanged a few rapid words in German . The communication appeared to agitate [the Chevalier]3909-the chevalier ; and after dismissing the page , [he]0-i turned to [the doctor]1209-the doctor . "[295-signor dottore] [Signor Dottore]295-signor dottore , " [he]0-i said , "[295-signor dottore] the most important part of [your]295-signor dottore occasion is past . [The lady whom [you]295-signor dottore have been unhappily called to attend]1245-the lady whom you have been unhappily called to attend , met with an alarming accident in [[her]1245-the lady whom you have been unhappily called to attend carriage]1246-her carriage , not half an hour before [I]0-i found [you]295-signor dottore in [the church]827-the church , and the unlucky absence of [[her]1245-the lady whom you have been unhappily called to attend physician]1248-her physician leaves [her]1245-the lady whom you have been unhappily called to attend entirely under [your]295-signor dottore charge . [Her]1245-the lady whom you have been unhappily called to attend accouchement is over , apparently without any result more than exhaustion ; but of that [you]295-signor dottore will be [the judge]1249-the judge . "[295-signor dottore]

It was only at the mention of [the carriage]1250-the carriage and the accident that [Dr. Beaton , whose wits appear to have been wool - gathering]1251-dr. beaton , whose wits appear to have been wool - gathering , suddenly guessed at a possible connection between [these " most illustrious and unfortunate of [Scottish Jacobites]3911-scottish jacobites , "[1255-the page] to whose house [he]1251-dr. beaton , whose wits appear to have been wool - gathering had been thus mysteriously introduced]1252-these " most illustrious and unfortunate of scottish jacobites , " to whose house he had been thus mysteriously introduced , and [the lady and gentleman in whom [he]1251-dr. beaton , whose wits appear to have been wool - gathering had that same afternoon]1253-the lady and gentleman in whom he had that same afternoon recognised [Charles Edward]204-charles edward and [[his]204-charles edward wife]908-his wife . [The page]1255-the page reappeared , and conducted [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton through [another suite of [splendid apartments]1257-splendid apartments]1256-another suite of splendid apartments , till [they]1258-they came to [an ante - room]1259-an ante - room decorated with the portraits of [no less remarkable persons than [the rebel Duke of [Perth]79-perth]1261-the rebel duke of perth]1260-no less remarkable persons than the rebel duke of perth and [King James VIII]296-king james viii . , a fact which shows that [the Stuarts]241-the stuarts must have carried [their]241-the stuarts furniture with [them]241-the stuarts , from [Rome]10-rome to [a Lucchese villa]1262-a lucchese villa hired for a few months , with more recklessness than one might have imagined likely in those days of post - chaises . Out of [this ante - room]1263-this ante - room [the physician]1224-the physician was ushered into [a large and magnificent bed - room , lit with a single taper]1265-a large and magnificent bed - room , lit with a single taper . From the side of a crimson - draped bed stepped [a lady]1266-a lady , who saluted [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton in English , and led [him]287-dr. beaton up to [the patient]3900-the patient , while [a female attendant]1268-a female attendant nursed [an infant enveloped in a mantle]1269-an infant enveloped in a mantle . [The lady]1270-the lady drew aside the curtain , and by the faint light [the doctor]1209-the doctor was able to distinguish a pale , delicate face , and a slender white arm and hand lying upon the blue velvet counterpane . [The lady in waiting]1272-the lady in waiting said some words in German , in answer to which [the sick woman]1273-the sick woman feebly attempted to stretch out [her]1273-the sick woman hand to [the physician]1224-the physician . Having ascertained that [the patient]3900-the patient was in a dangerous condition , [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton asked for pen and paper to write out a prescription , which , in [that Apennine wilderness]1276-that apennine wilderness , would doubtless be made up with the greatest exactness and rapidity . By the side of the writing - desk was a dressing - table ; and on what should [the doctor]1209-the doctor 's casual glance not rest but a miniature , thrown carelessly among the scent bottles and jewels , and in which [he]1209-the doctor instantly recognised a portrait of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward such as [he]1209-the doctor had seen [him]204-charles edward riding on [the field of [Culloden]60-culloden]1278-the field of culloden ! But in a moment , when [he]1209-the doctor glanced again from [his]1209-the doctor writing to the toilet - table , the miniature was no longer visible .

[The lady]1270-the lady having apparently recovered , [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton was dismissed , blindfolded as [he]1209-the doctor had come , but only after having taken an oath upon the crucifix " never to speak of what [he]1209-the doctor had heard , or seen , or thought , that night , except it should be in the service of [King Charles]242-charles iii , "[1270-the lady] and also to quit [Tuscany]80-tuscany immediately . [He]1209-the doctor repaired , therefore , to [the nearest seaport]1280-the nearest seaport , but was detained [there]593-there three days before the departure of [[his]1209-the doctor ship]1282-his ship . One moonlight evening , as [he]1209-the doctor was walking on [the sands]1283-the sands , [he]1209-the doctor was surprised by seeing [an English man - of - war]1284-an english man - of - war at anchor . In answer to [his]1209-the doctor enquiries , [she]1284-an english man - of - war proved to be [the Albina]1285-the albina , [Commodore O'Haloran]297-commodore o'haloran . While [he]1209-the doctor was lying in a sequestered corner , watching [the frigate]1286-the frigate , [he]1209-the doctor was startled by the sudden appearance of [a small closed carriage]1287-a small closed carriage and of a horseman , in whom , by the moonlight , [he]1209-the doctor immediately recognised [the moustached stranger of [St. Rosalie]78-st. rosalie]1288-the moustached stranger of st. rosalie . [The cavalcade]1289-the cavalcade stopped at [the water]1290-the water 's brink , and [the horseman]1291-the horseman blew a shrill whistle . Immediately [a man - of - war]1292-a man - of - war 's boat shot from behind some rocks and pulled straight towards [them]1293-them . [A man with glimmering epaulettes]1294-a man with glimmering epaulettes sprang from [the boat]1295-the boat on to [the beach]1296-the beach , and helped into [it]1295-the boat [a lady , who had alighted from [the carriage]1250-the carriage]1297-a lady , who had alighted from the carriage , and carried something wrapped in a shawl . [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton heard the cry of [an infant]1299-an infant , the soothing voice of [the lady]1270-the lady ; and , a moment later , after a word and shake of the hand with [the moustached man]1301-the moustached man , [the boat]1295-the boat pulled off from [shore]1303-shore . " For more than a quarter of an hour [the tall black figure of [the cavalier]3913-the cavalier]3912-the tall black figure of the cavalier continued fixed upon the same spot , and in the same attitude ; but suddenly the broad gigantic shadow of [the frigate]1286-the frigate swung round in the moonshine , [her]1270-the lady sails filled to the breeze , and dimly brightening in the light , [she]1270-the lady bore off slow and still and stately towards the west . "[1270-the lady]

Such is the adventure of [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton , and thus [he]287-dr. beaton is said to have related it , in the year 1831 , eighty - five years after the battle of [Culloden]60-culloden , where [he]287-dr. beaton had [himself]287-dr. beaton seen [Charles Edward]204-charles edward ; whence it is presumable that [the doctor]1209-the doctor was considerably over a hundred when [he]287-dr. beaton made the disclosure . This story of [Doctor Beaton]298-doctor beaton was published , not in a historical work , but in a volume entitled Tales of the Century ; or Sketches of the Romance of History between the years 1746 and 1846 , published at [Edinburgh]81-edinburgh in 1847 . But although this book might pass as a work of imagination , and could , therefore , scarcely be impugned as a historical document , there is every reason for supposing that , while not officially claiming to reveal the existence of [an heir of [the Stuarts]1306-the stuarts]1305-an heir of the stuarts , it was deliberately intended to convey information to that effect ; and as such , [an anonymous writer]1307-an anonymous writer either [Lockhart]209-lockhart or [Dennistoun]210-dennistoun made short work of it in the Quarterly Review for June 1847 , from which [I]0-i have derived the greater part of [my]0-i knowledge of this curious " romance of history . "[1307-an anonymous writer]

Nay , the Tales of the Century were undoubtedly intended to insinuate a further remarkable fact : not merely that there still existed [heirs of Stuarts in the direct male line]1308-heirs of stuarts in the direct male line , but that [these heirs of [the Stuarts]241-the stuarts]1309-these heirs of the stuarts were [no others]1310-no others but [the joint authors of the book]1311-the joint authors of the book . [The two brothers]1312-the two brothers styling [themselves]1312-the two brothers on the title - page [John Sobieski Stuart]273-john sobieski and [Charles Edward Stuart]204-charles edward , but whose legal names were respectively [John Hay Allan]299-john hay allan and [Charles Stuart Allan]300-charles stuart allan , had been known for some years in [the Highlands]82-the highlands as [persons enveloped in a degree of romantic mystery]1313-persons enveloped in a degree of romantic mystery , and claiming to be something much more illustrious than what [they]1312-the two brothers were officially supposed to be , [the grandsons of [an admiral in the service of [George III]301-george iii]1315-an admiral in the service of george iii]1314-the grandsons of an admiral in the service of george iii . According to the information collected by [Baron von Reumont]193-baron von reumont , [the joint authors of the Tales of the Century]1316-the joint authors of the tales of the century had made [themselves]1316-the joint authors of the tales of the century conspicuous by [their]1316-the joint authors of the tales of the century affectation of the Stuart tartan , to which , as [Hay Allans]302-hay allans , [they]1316-the joint authors of the tales of the century could have no right ; by a certain [Stuart]300-charles stuart allan make - up by the help of [a Charles I. wig which was once found and mistaken for a bird's - nest by [an irreverent Highlander on the part of [the elder]1319-the elder]1318-an irreverent highlander on the part of the elder , and by a habit of bowing to [[his]1319-the elder brother]804-his brother whenever [the King]1321-the king 's health was drunk on the part of [the younger]1322-the younger]1317-a charles i. wig which was once found and mistaken for a bird's - nest by an irreverent highlander on the part of the elder , and by a habit of bowing to his brother whenever the king 's health was drunk on the part of the younger . Moreover the family circumstances of [[these gentlemen]1323-these gentlemen 's father]1324-these gentlemen 's father coincided exactly with those of [the hero of this book]1325-the hero of this book , of [the supposed son of [Charles Edward Stuart]204-charles edward and [Louise]233-louise of [Stolberg]15-stolberg]1326-the supposed son of charles edward stuart and louise of stolberg . [[Their]1323-these gentlemen father]1327-their father , [Thomas Hay Allan]303-thomas hay allan , once [a lieutenant in the navy]1328-a lieutenant in the navy , was known before the law as [the younger son of [a certain Admiral Carter Allan]1330-a certain admiral carter allan , who laid claims to [the earldom of [Errol]305-errol]1331-the earldom of errol]1329-the younger son of a certain admiral carter allan , who laid claims to the earldom of errol ; and [the Jolair Dhearg]304-the jolair dhearg for such was the Keltic appellation of [the hero of the Tales of the Century]1332-the hero of the tales of the century was [the reputed son of a certain Admiral O'Haloran , who laid claim to [the Earldom of [Strathgowrie]84-strathgowrie]1334-the earldom of strathgowrie , to which curious parallel [the writer in the Quarterly]1335-the writer in the quarterly adds the additional point that [Errol]305-errol , being in [the district of Gowrie]1336-the district of gowrie , [the Earldom of [Strathgowrie]84-strathgowrie]1334-the earldom of strathgowrie claimed by [the imaginary Admiral O'Haloran]1338-the imaginary admiral o'haloran was evidently another name for [the Earldom of [Errol]305-errol]85-the earldom of errol]1333-the reputed son of a certain admiral o'haloran , who laid claim to the earldom of strathgowrie , to which curious parallel the writer in the quarterly adds the additional point that errol , being in the district of gowrie , the earldom of strathgowrie claimed by the imaginary admiral o'haloran was evidently another name for the earldom of errol claimed by [the real Admiral Carter Allan]306-the real admiral carter allan , two names , by the way , [O'Haloran]297-commodore o'haloran and [Carter Allan]306-the real admiral carter allan , of which the first seems intended to reproduce in some measure the sound of the other . [The father of [Messrs. John Hay]307-messrs. john hay and [Charles Stuart Allan]300-charles stuart allan]1339-the father of messrs. john hay and charles stuart allan , was married in 1792 , and [the hero of the Tales of the Century]1332-the hero of the tales of the century was married somewhere about 1791 , both to [ladies more suited to [the sons of [an admiral]1343-an admiral]1342-the sons of an admiral than to [the sons of the Pretender]1344-the sons of the pretender]1341-ladies more suited to the sons of an admiral than to the sons of the pretender . Taking all these circumstances into consideration it becomes obvious that when [the two brothers]1312-the two brothers [Hay Allan]303-thomas hay allan assumed respectively the names of [John Sobieski]273-john sobieski and [Charles Edward Stuart]204-charles edward , [they]1312-the two brothers distinctly , though unofficially , identified [themselves]1312-the two brothers with [the sons of [the Jolair Dhearg]304-the jolair dhearg of [their]1312-the two brothers book]1346-the sons of the jolair dhearg of their book , with [the sons of [that mysterious infant at whose birth]1348-that mysterious infant at whose birth [Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton had been present , who had been conveyed by night on board [the Albina]86-the albina and educated as [the son of [Admiral O'Haloran]308-admiral o'haloran]1349-the son of admiral o'haloran]1347-the sons of that mysterious infant at whose birth dr. beaton had been present , who had been conveyed by night on board the albina and educated as the son of admiral o'haloran ; in other words , with [the sons of [the child , unknown to history]1351-the child , unknown to history , of [the Count]1121-the count and [Countess of Albany]196-alfieri]1350-the sons of the child , unknown to history , of the count and countess of albany .

Now , not only are [we]1353-we assured by [Sir Horace Mann]207-sir horace mann , whose spies surrounded [the Pretender]605-the pretender and [[his]605-the pretender wife]908-his wife , and included even [[their]1312-the two brothers physicians]1356-their physicians , that there never was the smallest or briefest expectation of [an heir to [the Stuarts]241-the stuarts]1357-an heir to the stuarts ; but , added to this positive evidence , [we]1353-we have an enormous bulk of even more convincing negative evidence by which it is completely corroborated . This negative evidence consists of a heap of improbabilities and impossibilities , of which even a few will serve to convince [the reader]1358-the reader . [The Pretender]605-the pretender married , and was pensioned for marrying , merely that [the French Court]923-the french court might have [another possible Pretender]1361-another possible pretender to use as a weapon against [England]13-england ; is it likely , therefore , that [such an heir]1362-such an heir would be hid away so as to lose [his]1362-such an heir identity , and be completely and utterly forgotten ? [The Pretender]605-the pretender , separated from [[his]605-the pretender wife]908-his wife in consequence of circumstances which will be related further on , called to [him]605-the pretender , as [sole companion of [his]605-the pretender old age]1365-sole companion of his old age , [[his]605-the pretender illegitimate daughter]921-his illegitimate daughter by [Miss Walkenshaw]264-miss walkenshaw , after neglecting and apparently forgetting both [her]921-his illegitimate daughter and [[her]921-his illegitimate daughter mother]600-her mother for twenty years ; is it likely [he]605-the pretender would have done this had [he]605-the pretender possessed [a legitimate son]1368-a legitimate son ? [Cardinal York]265-cardinal york assumed the title of [Henry IX]309-henry ix . immediately on the decease of [[his]265-cardinal york brother]804-his brother ; is it likely that [he]265-cardinal york , always indifferent to royal honours , always faithful to [[his]265-cardinal york brother]804-his brother , and now almost dying , would have done so had [he]265-cardinal york known that [[his]265-cardinal york brother]804-his brother had left [a son]1372-a son ? [The Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri , who never relinquished [her]600-her mother Stuart position , and who was extremely devoted to [children]548-children]310-albany , left [her]600-her mother fortune to [the painter Fabre]1374-the painter fabre ; is it likely [she]600-her mother would have done so had [she]600-her mother been aware that [she]600-her mother possessed [a child of [her]600-her mother own]1375-a child of her own ? But there is yet further evidence - [I]0-i scarcely know whether [I]0-i should say positive or negative , but in point of fact perhaps both at once , since it is evidence that the word of one , at least , of [the joint authors of the Tales of the Century]1316-the joint authors of the tales of the century can not outweigh the silence of all other authorities . Five years before [the brothers Allan]303-thomas hay allan , or [Stuart]310-albany , whichever [they]303-thomas hay allan should be called , mysteriously informed the world of the adventures of [the Jolair Dhearg]304-the jolair dhearg , [the elder of [the two]1241-the two]1377-the elder of the two , once [John Hay Allan]299-john hay allan , now [John Sobieski Stuart]273-john sobieski , had brought out a magnificent volume , price five guineas , entitled Vestiarium Scoticum , and purporting to be a treatise on family tartans written somewhere in the 16th century , and now edited for the first time . The history of this work , as stated in the preface , was well - nigh as complicated and as romantic as the history of [the Jolair Dhearg]304-the jolair dhearg . The only reliable copy of three known by [Mr. Sobieski Stuart]273-john sobieski , of which one was said to exist in [the library of [the Monastery of St. Augustine]1380-the monastery of st. augustine at [Cadiz]87-cadiz]1379-the library of the monastery of st. augustine at cadiz , and another had been obtained from [an [Edinburgh]81-edinburgh sword - player and porter named [John Ross]311-john ross]1381-an edinburgh sword - player and porter named john ross , was in the possession of [the learned editors]1382-the learned editors , and had been given by [the fathers of [the Scots College at [Douay]89-douay]88-the scots college at douay to [Prince Edward Stuart]204-charles edward , from whom it had , in some unspecified but doubtless extremely romantic manner probably sewn in the swaddling clothes in which [the Jolair Dhearg]304-the jolair dhearg was consigned to [Admiral O'Haloran]308-admiral o'haloran descended to [Mr. John Sobieski Stuart]273-john sobieski]1383-the fathers of the scots college at douay to prince edward stuart , from whom it had , in some unspecified but doubtless extremely romantic manner probably sewn in the swaddling clothes in which the jolair dhearg was consigned to admiral o'haloran descended to mr. john sobieski stuart . This venerable heraldic document appears , if one may judge by the review in the Quarterly , to have been well - deserving of publication , owing to the extremely new and unexpected information which it contained upon Scottish archæology . Among such information may be mentioned that it derived several clans from [other clans with which [they]1384-other clans with which they were well known to have no possible connection were well known to have no possible connection]1384-other clans with which they were well known to have no possible connection ; that it extended the use of tartans to [border - families who had never heard of such a thing]1385-border - families who had never heard of such a thing ; that it contained many words and expressions hitherto entirely unknown in the particular dialect in which it was written ; and , moreover , that it multiplied complicated and recondite patterns of tartans in a manner so remarkable that [Sir Walter Scott]312-sir walter scott , to whom part of [Mr. Sobieski Stuart]273-john sobieski 's transcript of the ancient MS . was submitted , was led to suspect " that information as to its origin might be obtained even in a less romantic site than [the cabin of [a Cowgate porter]3916-a cowgate porter]3915-the cabin of a cowgate porter or [the Scots College at [Douay]89-douay]3917-the scots college at douay , even behind the counter of one of [the great clan - tartan warehouses which used to illuminate [the principal thoroughfare of [Edinburgh]81-edinburgh]3919-the principal thoroughfare of edinburgh]3918-the great clan - tartan warehouses which used to illuminate the principal thoroughfare of edinburgh . "[273-john sobieski]

This important and well - nigh unique document was apparently never submitted in [its]304-the jolair dhearg original MS . to [anyone]1386-anyone ; the copy from [the Scots College at [Douay]89-douay]3917-the scots college at douay , and the copy from the old sword - player of [Cowgate]90-cowgate , remained equally unknown to [everyone]1388-everyone save [[their]1388-everyone fortunate possessor]1389-their fortunate possessor . But transcripts of some portions of the work were submitted , at the request of [the Antiquarian Society]91-the antiquarian society , to [Sir Walter Scott]312-sir walter scott , and as [he]312-sir walter scott dismissed the deputation which had met to hear [his]312-sir walter scott opinion upon [the Vestiarium Scoticum]92-the vestiarium scoticum , [the author of [Waverley]93-waverley]1390-the author of waverley was pleased to remark by way of summing up : " Well , [I]1390-the author of waverley think [the March of the next rising]3920-the march of the next rising "[1390-the author of waverley] alluding to the part of [the Highlanders]313-the highlanders in the ' 45 " must be not ' Hey tuttie tattie , ' but ' [The Devil among [the Tailors]3922-the tailors]3921-the devil among the tailors . ' "[1390-the author of waverley]

However , perhaps [the Vestiarium Scoticum]1391-the vestiarium scoticum may have come out of [the Scots College at [Douay]89-douay]3917-the scots college at douay , and perhaps also [the son of [Charles Edward Stuart]204-charles edward and of [Louise of Stolberg]233-louise]1393-the son of charles edward stuart and of louise of stolberg may have been born in [the room]778-the room hung with red brocade , and have been handed over to [a British Admiral]1395-a british admiral one moonlight night , in the presence of [the venerable Dr. Beaton]287-dr. beaton , whom [Providence permitted to attain the unusual age of a hundred years or more]1396-providence permitted to attain the unusual age of a hundred years or more , in order that , with unimpaired faculties and unclouded memory , [he]287-dr. beaton might transmit to posterity this strange romance of history .

CHAPTER V.

[FLORENCE]9-florence .

It is quite impossible to tell the precise moment at which began what [Horace Mann]207-sir horace mann , most light - hearted and chirpy of [diplomatists]1397-diplomatists , called [the Countess of [Albany]310-albany]527-the countess of albany 's martyrdom . As [we]1399-we have seen , [Charles Edward]204-charles edward had momentarily given up all excessive drinking at the time of [his]204-charles edward marriage . [Bonstetten]280-bonstetten thought [him]204-charles edward [a good - natured garrulous bore]1400-a good - natured garrulous bore , and [[his]204-charles edward wife]908-his wife [a merry , childish young woman , who laughed at [[her]908-his wife husband]790-her husband 's oft - told stories]1402-a merry , childish young woman , who laughed at her husband 's oft - told stories . This was the very decent exterior of [the Pretender]605-the pretender 's domestic life in the first year of [his]204-charles edward marriage . But who can tell what there may have been before beneath the surface ? Who can say when [Louise]233-louise d'Albany , hitherto apparently so childish , became suddenly [a woman with the first terrible suspicion of the nature of the bondage into which [she]233-louise had been sold]1405-a woman with the first terrible suspicion of the nature of the bondage into which she had been sold ? Such things are unromantic , unpoetical , coarse , common - place ; yet if the fears and the despair of [a guiltless and charming girl]1406-a guiltless and charming girl have any interest for [us]1399-we , the first whiff of brandy - tainted breath which met [the young wife]1407-the young wife in [[her]1407-the young wife husband]790-her husband 's embraces , the first qualms and reekings after dinner which came before [her]1407-the young wife eyes , [the first bestial and unquiet drunkard]1409-the first bestial and unquiet drunkard 's sleep which kept [her]1407-the young wife awake in disgust and terror , these things , vile though they be , are as tragic as any more ideal horrors . At the beginning , most probably , [Charles Edward]204-charles edward drank only in the evening , and slept off [his]204-charles edward drunkenness over - night ; nor does [Bonstetten]280-bonstetten appear to have guessed that there was any skeleton in [the palace]779-the palace at [the Santissimi Apostoli]69-the santissimi apostoli . But [the spies of [the English minister]1412-the english minister]1411-the spies of the english minister soon reported that [Charles Edward]204-charles edward was returning to [his]204-charles edward old ways ; that the " nasty bottle , "[265-cardinal york] as [Cardinal York]265-cardinal york called it , had got the better of [the young wife]1407-the young wife ; and when , two years after [their]1414-their marriage , [the Count]1121-the count and [Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]1122-countess of albany had left [Rome]10-rome and settled in [Florence]9-florence , [Charles Edward]204-charles edward seems very soon to have acquired in the latter place the dreadful notoriety which [he]204-charles edward had long enjoyed in the former .

[Circumstances]314-circumstances also had conduced to replunge [the Pretender]605-the pretender into the habits to which the renewed hope of political support , the novelty of married life , and perhaps whatever of good may still have been conjured up in [his]204-charles edward nature by the presence of [a beautiful young wife]1418-a beautiful young wife , had momentarily broken through . [The French Government]65-the french government , after its sudden pre - occupation about the future of [the Stuarts]241-the stuarts , seemed to have completely forgotten the existence of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward , except as regarded the payment of the pension granted on [his]204-charles edward marriage . [The child that had been prepaid by that wedding pension , who was to rally [the Jacobites]706-the jacobites]1419-the child that had been prepaid by that wedding pension , who was to rally the jacobites round [a man whose claims must otherwise devolve legitimately in a few years to [the Hanoverian usurpers]1422-the hanoverian usurpers]1421-a man whose claims must otherwise devolve legitimately in a few years to the hanoverian usurpers , [the heir]1170-the heir was not born , and , as month went by after month , its final coming became less and less likely . Nor was this all . [Charles Edward]204-charles edward seems to have expected that the sudden interest taken by [the Court of [Versailles]23-versailles]606-the court of versailles in [his]204-charles edward affairs , and [his]204-charles edward new position as [a married man]1425-a married man and [the possible father of [a line of Stuarts]1427-a line of stuarts]1426-the possible father of a line of stuarts , would bring [the obdurate sovereigns of [Italy]3-italy]1428-the obdurate sovereigns of italy , and especially [the Pope]650-the pope , to grant [him]204-charles edward those royal honours enjoyed by [[his]204-charles edward father]649-his father , but hitherto obstinately denied to [the moody drunkard whose presence in [the paternal palace]1432-the paternal palace had been occasionally revealed only by the rumour of [some more than ordinarily gross debauch]1433-some more than ordinarily gross debauch , or the noise of some more than ordinarily violent scene of blackguardly altercation]1431-the moody drunkard whose presence in the paternal palace had been occasionally revealed only by the rumour of some more than ordinarily gross debauch , or the noise of some more than ordinarily violent scene of blackguardly altercation .

[Charles Edward]204-charles edward , as [I]0-i have already had occasion to remark , while absolutely callous to the rights which self - sacrifice and heroism might give [others]1434-others over [him]204-charles edward , was extremely alive to the rights which , as [a Stuart]943-a stuart and as [an obstinate and wilful man]1436-an obstinate and wilful man , [he]204-charles edward imagined [himself]204-charles edward to possess over [other folk]1437-other folk ; and , while it never occurred to [him]204-charles edward that there might be something slightly ungentlemanly in [a prince who had secretly abjured the Catholic faith for political reasons continuing to live in [a house]1439-a house and on a pension granted [him]204-charles edward by [the unsuspecting sovereign Pontiff]1440-the unsuspecting sovereign pontiff in consideration of [his]204-charles edward being [a martyr for the glory of the Church]1441-a martyr for the glory of the church]1438-a prince who had secretly abjured the catholic faith for political reasons continuing to live in a house and on a pension granted him by the unsuspecting sovereign pontiff in consideration of his being a martyr for the glory of the church , [he]204-charles edward was fully persuaded of the cowardly meanness which prevented [Clement XIV]224-clement xiv . , whose interest it was to jog on amicably with [England]13-england , from acknowledging [the grandson of [James II]238-james ii]1442-the grandson of james ii . as [a legitimate King of [Great Britain]40-great britain and [Ireland]41-ireland]1443-a legitimate king of great britain and ireland . It is therefore easy to conceive the accumulation of disappointment and anger with which [Charles Edward]204-charles edward saw [his]204-charles edward hopes deluded . [He]204-charles edward had , immediately on [his]204-charles edward return to [Rome]10-rome , officially announced to [Clement XIV]224-clement xiv . the arrival in [the Eternal City]1444-the eternal city of [King Charles III]242-charles iii . and [[his]204-charles edward Queen]1445-his queen , and [the Pope]650-the pope had condescended no answer save that [he]204-charles edward had hitherto been unaware of the existence of [such persons]1447-such persons , and that [he]204-charles edward would suffer none such to live under [his]204-charles edward jurisdiction . [He]204-charles edward had , for more than a year , imposed upon [[his]204-charles edward wife]908-his wife despite [Cardinal York]265-cardinal york 's and [her]908-his wife own entreaties , if [we]1449-we may credit [Sir Horace]207-sir horace mann Mann the title and etiquette of [a Queen]673-a queen , and had flaunted [his]204-charles edward scarlet liveries along the Corso day after day , with no result save that of making [the Roman nobles]1451-the roman nobles keep carefully out of the way wherever [he]204-charles edward and [[his]204-charles edward wife]908-his wife might go ; nay , more , [he]204-charles edward had replaced over the doorway of [[his]204-charles edward residence the royal escutcheon of [Great Britain]40-great britain]1453-his residence the royal escutcheon of great britain , only to return from [the country]1454-the country one day and find that [the Pontifical police]1455-the pontifical police had taken it down during [his]204-charles edward absence . After this [we]1449-we can understand , as [I]0-i said , the disappointment and rage which must have accumulated in [his]204-charles edward heart , and which , fifteen months after [his]204-charles edward wedding , made [him]204-charles edward abandon [the base town]1456-the base town of [the popes]1086-the popes and seek sympathy and dignity in [the capital of [Tuscany]80-tuscany]1458-the capital of tuscany . But [he]204-charles edward was destined only to further disappointment . [The Grand Duke]1459-the grand duke , [Peter Leopold]315-peter leopold , [the practical , economical , priest]1460-the practical , economical , priest - hating , [paternally - meddlesome , bustlingly and tyrannically - reforming son of [Maria Theresa]227-maria theresa]1461-paternally - meddlesome , bustlingly and tyrannically - reforming son of maria theresa , was not [the man to console so mediæval and antiquated and unphilosophical a thing as [a Stuart]943-a stuart]1462-the man to console so mediæval and antiquated and unphilosophical a thing as a stuart . The arrival , the presence of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward in [Florence]9-florence , was absolutely ignored by [the Court]1464-the court , and no invitations of any sort were sent out either to [King Charles III]242-charles iii . or to [the Count of [Albany]196-alfieri]607-the count of albany . Except [the Corsinis]1466-the corsinis , [old friends of [the Stuarts]241-the stuarts , who had known [Charles Edward]204-charles edward in [his]204-charles edward brilliant boyhood]1467-old friends of the stuarts , who had known charles edward in his brilliant boyhood , and who politely placed at [his]204-charles edward disposal [[their]1466-the corsinis half - suburban palace or casino]1468-their half - suburban palace or casino , opening on to [the famous Oricellari Gardens]1469-the famous oricellari gardens , [no one]1470-no one seemed inclined to pay any particular respects to [the new - comers]1471-the new - comers . There was , indeed , no pressure from [the Government]1472-the government as had been the case in [Rome]10-rome , and [the Florentine nobles , whose exclusiveness and pride had been considerably diminished by the inroad of [swaggering Lorenese favourites under [the Grand Duke Francis]316-the grand duke francis]1474-swaggering lorenese favourites under the grand duke francis , and of cut and dry Austrian officials under [[his]316-the grand duke francis son]1475-his son [Peter Leopold]315-peter leopold]1473-the florentine nobles , whose exclusiveness and pride had been considerably diminished by the inroad of swaggering lorenese favourites under the grand duke francis , and of cut and dry austrian officials under his son peter leopold , showed a sort of lukewarm willingness to receive [the Count]1121-the count and Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri on equal terms into [[their]1466-the corsinis society]1477-their society . But [Charles Edward]204-charles edward wanted royal honours ; [he]204-charles edward forbade [[his]204-charles edward wife]908-his wife demeaning [her]908-his wife queenly position by returning the visits of [Florentine ladies]1479-florentine ladies , and [the nobles of [the Tuscan Court]1481-the tuscan court]1480-the nobles of the tuscan court gradually left [the would - be King and Queen of [England]13-england]1482-the would - be king and queen of england to [their]1480-the nobles of the tuscan court own resources .

These resources , with the exception of receiving [such few visitors]1483-such few visitors as might care to know [them]1483-such few visitors on unequal terms , and a dogged pushing into notice in every place , [promenade]1484-promenade , [theatre]1485-theatre , or [[nobles]1486-nobles ' club]1487-nobles ' club , where no invitation was required , these resources consisted on the part of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward in [the old , old consoler]1488-the old , old consoler , the flask of Cyprus or bottle of brandy , in the even grosser pleasures of excessive eating , the indefatigable , assiduous courtship of [[his]204-charles edward young wife]3887-his young wife , and the occasional rows with [[his]204-charles edward servants]1490-his servants and [acquaintances]1491-acquaintances . [The Count]1121-the count and [Countess of Albany]310-albany appear to have inhabited [the Casino Corsini]1493-the casino corsini until 1777 , when [they]1482-the would - be king and queen of england sent for the greater part of the furniture of [[their]1482-the would - be king and queen of england Roman house]1494-their roman house , and established [themselves]1482-the would - be king and queen of england in [a palace]1495-a palace , bought of [the Guadagnis]317-the guadagnis and later sold to [the Duke of [San Clemente]94-san clemente]1496-the duke of san clemente , between [the now suppressed Porta San Sebastiano]1497-the now suppressed porta san sebastiano and [the Garden of St. Mark 's]1498-the garden of st. mark 's . In both [these places]1499-these places [Sir Horace Mann]207-sir horace mann , [the vigilant Minister to [the Tuscan Court]1481-the tuscan court and head spy over [the Stuarts]241-the stuarts in [Italy]3-italy]1500-the vigilant minister to the tuscan court and head spy over the stuarts in italy , kept [the Pretender]605-the pretender well in sight ; but , in fact , things had now become so public that spying had grown unnecessary . Already , the year following the removal from [Rome]10-rome to [Florence]9-florence , [Sir Horace Mann]207-sir horace mann wrote to [Walpole]257-walpole that [the Pretender]605-the pretender 's health was giving way beneath [his]605-the pretender excesses of eating and drinking ; dyspepsia and dropsy were beginning , and a sofa had been ordered for [his]605-the pretender opera - box , that [he]605-the pretender might conveniently snooze through the performance . For neither drunkenness nor ailments would induce [Charles Edward]204-charles edward to let [[his]204-charles edward wife]908-his wife out of [his]204-charles edward sight for a minute . [His]204-charles edward systematic jealousy may possibly have originated , as [the English Minister]1412-the english minister reports [Charles Edward]204-charles edward to have [himself]204-charles edward declared , from fear lest there might attach to the birth of [any possible heir of [his]204-charles edward]1506-any possible heir of his those doubts of legitimacy which are almost invariably the lot of [a pretender]1507-a pretender ; but there can be no doubt that jealousy was an essential feature of [his]204-charles edward character , in which it amounted almost to monomania . [He]204-charles edward had caged [[his]204-charles edward mistress]934-his mistress long after [he]204-charles edward had ceased , by [his]204-charles edward own avowal , to care for [her]934-his mistress ; [he]204-charles edward now caged [[his]204-charles edward wife]908-his wife , and with probably about as much or as little affection . [He]204-charles edward had fenced up [Miss Walkenshaw]264-miss walkenshaw 's bed with tables and chairs fitted with bells which the slightest touch set ringing ; [he]204-charles edward now and so early as 1775 barricaded all avenues to [[[his]204-charles edward wife]908-his wife 's room]1511-his wife 's room excepting the one through [his]204-charles edward own . Very soon , also , the gross and violent language , the blows which had fallen to the lot of [the half - tipsy mistress]1512-the half - tipsy mistress , were to be shared by [the virtuous and patient wife]1513-the virtuous and patient wife .

Illustration : [LOUISE]233-louise , [COUNTESS OF [ALBANY]196-alfieri]1122-countess of albany From a pastel once in the possession of [the heirs of Fabre]1515-the heirs of fabre , now in the possession of [Mrs. Horace Walpole]257-walpole , of [Heckfield Place]57-heckfield place , [Winchfield]58-winchfield , [Hants]59-hants .

For virtuous and patient all accounts unite in showing [the young Countess of Albany]310-albany to have been . In [that corrupt Florence]1516-that corrupt florence of the corrupt eighteenth century , where [every married woman]1517-every married woman was furnished , within two years of [her]1517-every married woman marriage , with [an officially appointed lover who sat in [[her]1517-every married woman dressing - room]1519-her dressing - room while [she]1517-every married woman was finishing [her]1517-every married woman toilet , who accompanied [her]1517-every married woman on all [her]1517-every married woman visits , who attended [her]1517-every married woman to balls and [theatres]1520-theatres , and , in fact , entirely replaced , by the strict social necessities of the system of cicisbeism , [the husband]1521-the husband , who was similarly employed about [the wife of another]1522-the wife of another]1518-an officially appointed lover who sat in her dressing - room while she was finishing her toilet , who accompanied her on all her visits , who attended her to balls and theatres , and , in fact , entirely replaced , by the strict social necessities of the system of cicisbeism , the husband , who was similarly employed about the wife of another ; in this society , where conjugal infidelity was a social organisation supplemented by every kind of individual caprice of gallantry ; where [women]547-women were none the worse thought of if [they]547-women added to [the official cavaliere]1524-the official cavaliere servente a whole string of [other lovers]1525-other lovers , varying from [the Cardinals of [the Holy Church]1527-the holy church]1526-the cardinals of the holy church to [the singers who played [women]547-women 's parts , in powder and hoops , at the opera]1528-the singers who played women 's parts , in powder and hoops , at the opera ; in this world of jog - trot immorality , where jealousy was tolerated in [lovers]1530-lovers , but ridiculous in [husbands]1027-husbands , [such a couple as [the Count]1121-the count and Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]1532-such a couple as the count and countess of albany was indeed a source of pity , wonder , and amazement . But if [a husband who barricaded [[his]1521-the husband wife]908-his wife 's room , never went out without [her]908-his wife , nor permitted [her]908-his wife to go out without [him]1521-the husband , who was never further off than [the next room]1536-the next room during the presence of [any visitor]1537-any visitor , was a marvellous sight ; still more marvellous was [a beautiful and charming woman of twenty - three or twenty - four]1538-a beautiful and charming woman of twenty - three or twenty - four , who cast no glances of longing at the brilliant cavaliers all round [her]908-his wife , who consoled [her]908-his wife dreary prison - hours with reading hard enough for [a professor at [the university]1540-the university]1539-a professor at the university , and who showed towards [the peevish , violent , disgustingly - ailing old toper who overshadowed [her]908-his wife life]1541-the peevish , violent , disgustingly - ailing old toper who overshadowed her life with [his]1541-the peevish , violent , disgustingly - ailing old toper who overshadowed her life presence nothing , as [Horace Mann]207-sir horace mann tells [us]1542-we , but attention and tenderness]1534-a husband who barricaded his wife 's room , never went out without her , nor permitted her to go out without him , who was never further off than the next room during the presence of any visitor , was a marvellous sight ; still more marvellous was a beautiful and charming woman of twenty - three or twenty - four , who cast no glances of longing at the brilliant cavaliers all round her , who consoled her dreary prison - hours with reading hard enough for a professor at the university , and who showed towards the peevish , violent , disgustingly - ailing old toper who overshadowed her life with his presence nothing , as horace mann tells us , but attention and tenderness . The fact is that [Louise of Stolberg]233-louise , much as [her]233-louise subsequent life and ways of thought proved [her]233-louise to be [a woman of the eighteenth century]1543-a woman of the eighteenth century , and not at all above the eighteenth century 's easy - going habits and conventional ideas , was [a kind of woman rare at all times and rarest of all]1544-a kind of woman rare at all times and rarest of all in a time like [her]233-louise own , With a kindly and affectionate temper , the immense bulk of [her]233-louise nature , the overbalance , the top - heaviness of it , was intellectual ; and intellectual not in the sense of the ready society intelligence , so common among [eighteenth - century women]1545-eighteenth - century women , but in the sense of actual engrossing interest and in abstract questions and ideals . The portraits done of [her]233-louise immediately after [her]233-louise marriage show , as [I]0-i have said , [a remarkably childish person]1546-a remarkably childish person ; and childish , without much ballast of passion or even likings , the likeness sketched by [Bonstetten]280-bonstetten seems certainly to show [her]233-louise . But there are women who , while immature as [women]547-women and [human beings]1548-human beings , are precocious as intellects , and in whom the character , instead of rapidly developing itself by the force of its own emotions and passions , seems in a manner to be called into existence by the intelligence : retarded natures , in whom the thoughts seem to determine the feelings . Of this sort , [I]0-i think , [we]1542-we must imagine [the Countess of Albany]527-the countess of albany , if [we]1542-we would understand the anomalies of [her]527-the countess of albany life : [a person rather deficient in sensitiveness]1550-a person rather deficient in sensitiveness ; indifferent , light - hearted , in [her]527-the countess of albany girlhood ; not rebelling against the frightful negativeness of existence , the want of love , of youth , of brightness , of all that [a young girl]1551-a young girl can want in the early part of [her]1551-a young girl married life ; not rebelling against the positive miseries , the constant presence of everything that was mentally and physically loathsome in the second period of this wedded slavery ; [a woman of cold temperament]1552-a woman of cold temperament , and even , [you]1553-you might say , of cold heart , and safe , safe in the routine of duty and suffering , until a merely intellectual flame burst out , white and cold , in [her]233-louise hitherto callous nature .
