A creature , so to speak , only half awake , or awake , perhaps , only when [she]233-louise devoured [her]233-louise books and tried to puzzle out [her]233-louise mathematical problems ; and going through life by the side of [[her]233-louise jealous , brutal , sickly , drunken husband]1554-her jealous , brutal , sickly , drunken husband , in a kind of somnambulistic indifferentism , perhaps not feeling [her]233-louise miseries very acutely , and probably not envying [other women]1555-other women [their]1555-other women meaningless liberty , [[their]1555-other women inane lovers]1556-their inane lovers , [their]1555-other women empty wholeness of life .

Thus the routine continued . [The Count and Countess of Albany , cured by this time of any affectation of royalty]1557-the count and countess of albany , cured by this time of any affectation of royalty , had gradually got domesticated in [Florentine]95-florentine society . [People]927-people began to go to [[their]927-people house]1559-their house , [the newly - bought palace in [Via San Sebastiano]96-via san sebastiano]1560-the newly - bought palace in via san sebastiano . [People]927-people came to the opera - box where [Charles Edward]204-charles edward lay stretched , dozing or snoring , [his]204-charles edward bottle of Cyprus wine by [his]204-charles edward side , on [his]204-charles edward sofa . It is easy to read through the lines of [Sir Horace Mann]207-sir horace mann 's pages of social tittle - tattle , that [Florence]318-florence , frivolous and unintellectual and corrupt though it was , and , perhaps , almost in proportion to its frivolity , emptiness , and corruption , felt a strange sort of interest , experienced a vague , mixed feeling , pity , fear , and general surprise and want of comprehension towards [this beautiful young woman]1562-this beautiful young woman , with [her]1562-this beautiful young woman dazzling white complexion , dark hazel eyes and blonde hair , [her]1562-this beautiful young woman childish features grown , perhaps not less young , but more serious and solemn for [her]1562-this beautiful young woman five years of wasted youth and endured misery , with [her]1562-this beautiful young woman reputation for coldness , [her]1562-this beautiful young woman almost legendary eccentricities of intellectual interests . [Women like this one]1563-women like this one are apt to be regarded not so much with dislike and envy , as with the mixed awe and pity which [peasants]552-peasants feel towards [an idiot]1565-an idiot , by [frivolous and immoral people like [those powdered Florentines of a hundred years ago]1567-those powdered florentines of a hundred years ago , whose brocaded trains and embroidered coats have long since found [their]1566-frivolous and immoral people like those powdered florentines of a hundred years ago , whose brocaded trains and embroidered coats have long since found their way into the cupboards of curiosity shops , and been cut up into quaint room decoration by æsthetically - minded foreigners way into the cupboards of [curiosity shops]1568-curiosity shops , and been cut up into quaint room decoration by [æsthetically - minded foreigners]1569-æsthetically - minded foreigners]1566-frivolous and immoral people like those powdered florentines of a hundred years ago , whose brocaded trains and embroidered coats have long since found their way into the cupboards of curiosity shops , and been cut up into quaint room decoration by æsthetically - minded foreigners ; pity and awe the more natural when , as in the case of [Louise d'Albany]233-louise , it is evident to [every man]1570-every man and [woman]3888-woman , however heartless and stupid , that [the creature in question]1572-the creature in question is [a victim]1573-a victim , and [an innocent one]1574-an innocent one . [People]927-people were led , perhaps to some extent by impertinent curiosity , by the lazy desire to have some opinion to give upon [that now legendary household of [the besotten , sleepy , nauseous old King of [England]13-england]1577-the besotten , sleepy , nauseous old king of england and [[his]1577-the besotten , sleepy , nauseous old king of england terribly virtuous and intellectual young Queen]1578-his terribly virtuous and intellectual young queen]1576-that now legendary household of the besotten , sleepy , nauseous old king of england and his terribly virtuous and intellectual young queen , to [the palace in [Via San Sebastiano]96-via san sebastiano]1579-the palace in via san sebastiano ; and [men]711-men and [women of fashion]1581-women of fashion led thither , as to one of the curious sights of [Florence]9-florence , [[their]1566-frivolous and immoral people like those powdered florentines of a hundred years ago , whose brocaded trains and embroidered coats have long since found their way into the cupboards of curiosity shops , and been cut up into quaint room decoration by æsthetically - minded foreigners country cousins]1582-their country cousins and [[their]1566-frivolous and immoral people like those powdered florentines of a hundred years ago , whose brocaded trains and embroidered coats have long since found their way into the cupboards of curiosity shops , and been cut up into quaint room decoration by æsthetically - minded foreigners distinguished visitors]1583-their distinguished visitors from other parts . And thus , one day in the autumn of 1777 , there was brought , [we]1584-we know not by whom , half - curious and half - indifferent , to the salon of [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany [a certain very tall , thin , pale young man of twenty - eight , with handsome , mobile , rather hard aquiline features , choleric , flashing blue eyes , and a head of crisp , bright red hair]1586-a certain very tall , thin , pale young man of twenty - eight , with handsome , mobile , rather hard aquiline features , choleric , flashing blue eyes , and a head of crisp , bright red hair ; [a man of fashion]1587-a man of fashion , nattily dressed in the Sardinian uniform , but with something strange , untamed , morose about [his]1587-a man of fashion whole aspect which contrasted singularly with the effete gracefulness and amiability of [young Florentine dandies]1588-young florentine dandies . [He]1587-a man of fashion had heard of [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany 's eccentricities long before ; [she]527-the countess of albany had doubtless heard of [his]1587-a man of fashion .

[One]1590-one can imagine the curiosity with which [the wild , moody young officer]1591-the wild , moody young officer fixed those bright , hard , steel , flashing blue eyes upon [the beautiful young woman of whom [he]1591-the wild , moody young officer had heard that [she]527-the countess of albany was]1592-the beautiful young woman of whom he had heard that she was , what [no woman of [his]1591-the wild , moody young officer acquaintance and [his]1591-the wild , moody young officer acquaintance]1593-no woman of his acquaintance and his acquaintance was but too large had been - intellectual and virtuous . One can imagine the curiosity , much vaguer and more indifferent , with which [the woefully cold and woefully weary young woman]1594-the woefully cold and woefully weary young woman met the scrutiny of those hard , flashing blue eyes , and took the moral measure of [this eccentric creature]1595-this eccentric creature , come from [Turin]97-turin to [Florence]9-florence with some ten or twelve half - tamed horses , in order to learn Tuscan grammar for the sake of writing tragedies . [The common friend , whose name has been engulfed into the unknowable]1596-the common friend , whose name has been engulfed into the unknowable , introduced to [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany [Count Vittorio Alfieri]196-alfieri .

CHAPTER VI .

[ALFIERI]196-alfieri .

The childhood and early youth of [Vittorio Alfieri]196-alfieri had been strangely vacant , dreary , one might almost say intellectually and morally sordid ; and the strangest , the dreariest circumstance about [them]1598-them was exactly that this vacuity , this dreariness , this total want of all that can make the life of [a boy]1599-a boy and of [a young man]1600-a young man pleasant to [our]1601-our fancy or attractive to [our]1601-our sympathy , did not in the least depend upon any harshness or stinginess of fate . Indeed , perhaps , [no man]1062-no man had ever prepared for [him]196-alfieri an easier existence ; [no man]1062-no man had ever less misfortune sent to [him]196-alfieri by Providence , or less unkindness shown towards [him]196-alfieri by [mankind]1604-mankind , than [this constantly struggling]1605-this constantly struggling , [this pessimistic and misanthropic man]1606-this pessimistic and misanthropic man . [The only son of [Count Alfieri of [Cortemiglia]98-cortemiglia]1608-count alfieri of cortemiglia , of one of [the richest and noblest families of [Asti]99-asti in [Piedmont]100-piedmont]1609-the richest and noblest families of asti in piedmont]1607-the only son of count alfieri of cortemiglia , of one of the richest and noblest families of asti in piedmont , [his]1607-the only son of count alfieri of cortemiglia , of one of the richest and noblest families of asti in piedmont early childhood was spent under the care of [[his]1607-the only son of count alfieri of cortemiglia , of one of the richest and noblest families of asti in piedmont mother]1610-his mother , [a woman of almost saintly simplicity and kindness]1611-a woman of almost saintly simplicity and kindness , unworldly , charitable , devoted to [[her]1610-his mother children]1612-her children , and to [the poor of [the place]1614-the place]1613-the poor of the place ; and of [[her]1610-his mother third husband]1615-her third husband , also [an Alfieri]1616-an alfieri , who appears to have been , in [his]1616-an alfieri affection and generosity towards [[his]1616-an alfieri wife 's children]1617-his wife 's children , everything that [a step - father]1618-a step - father is usually supposed not to be . Being delicate in health , [the boy]1619-the boy was treated with every degree of consideration , never worried with lessons , never exasperated with punishments , as long as [he]1619-the boy remained at [home]1063-home . [He]1619-the boy was sent , under the care of [an uncle]1621-an uncle , [the eminent architect]1622-the eminent architect , [Benedetto Alfieri]319-benedetto alfieri , who appears to have been [the ideally amiable uncle]1623-the ideally amiable uncle as [Giacinto Alfieri]320-giacinto alfieri had been [the ideally amiable step - father]1624-the ideally amiable step - father , to [the academy or [nobles]1486-nobles ' college at [Turin]97-turin]1625-the academy or nobles ' college at turin , where again , provided with plenty of money , and [a most accommodating half - tutor]1627-a most accommodating half - tutor , [half - valet]1628-half - valet , [he]1619-the boy enjoyed , or might have enjoyed , every advantage possible to [a young Piedmontese noble , either in the way of study or of idleness]1629-a young piedmontese noble , either in the way of study or of idleness . And , finally , when still in [his]1619-the boy teens , [he]1619-the boy had been supplied with ample money , horses and fine clothes ad libitum , and almost unlimited liberty to wander all over [the world]573-the world , from [Naples]67-naples to [Holland]101-holland , from [St. Petersburg]102-st. petersburg to [Cadiz]87-cadiz , in search of experience or amusement . Nor during those years of youthful wanderings , does [he]1619-the boy ever seem , except upon one memorable occasion , to have been made to suffer from the unconscientiousness , the harshness , the infidelity , the indifference of [the men]687-the men and women whom [he]1619-the boy met , any more than in [his]1619-the boy boyhood [he]1619-the boy had suffered from the severity of [[his]1619-the boy masters]1632-his masters , the brutality of [[his]1619-the boy tutor - servants]1633-his tutor - servants , or the ill - nature of [[his]1619-the boy fellow pupils]1634-his fellow pupils . Fate and [the world]573-the world were extremely kind to [Vittorio Alfieri]196-alfieri : giving [him]196-alfieri every advantage and comfort , and teaching [him]196-alfieri no cruel lessons . But [Vittorio Alfieri]196-alfieri was nevertheless one of the least happy of [little boys]1636-little boys , and [one of the least happy of young men]1637-one of the least happy of young men . [He]196-alfieri was born with an uncomfortable and awkward and unwieldy character , as [some men]1638-some men are born lame , or scrofulous , or dyspeptic . [The child of [a father over sixty]1640-a father over sixty , and of [a very young mother]1641-a very young mother]1639-the child of a father over sixty , and of a very young mother ; there was in [him]196-alfieri some indefinable imperfection of nature , some jar of character , or some great want , some original sin of mental constitution , which made [him]196-alfieri different from [other men]1642-other men , disabled [him]196-alfieri from getting pleasure or profit out of the circumstances which gave pleasure or profit to [them]1642-other men ; and turned [his]196-alfieri youth into a long period of mental weakness and suffering , from which [he]196-alfieri recovered , indeed , by a system of moral and intellectual cold water , meagre diet , and excessive exercise , but only to remain for the rest of [his]196-alfieri days in a condition of character absolutely analogous to the bodily condition of [those self - martyring invalids , who keep the gout down by taking exhausting walks , eating next to no dinner , and filling the lives of [others]1434-others]1643-those self - martyring invalids , who keep the gout down by taking exhausting walks , eating next to no dinner , and filling the lives of others with [their]1434-others excitable cantankerousness and gloomy forebodings . There was a numbness and yet a sort of over - sensitiveness about [his]196-alfieri youth ; a strangeness which , without giving the least promise of superior genius , merely made [him]196-alfieri less happy than [other lads]1645-other lads .

The word numbness returns to [my]0-i mind in connexion with [this young Alfieri]1646-this young alfieri ; it certainly does not express the exact impressions left in [me]0-i by [his]196-alfieri own narrative of [his]196-alfieri boyhood and youth , and yet [I]0-i can find no better word : there was in [him]196-alfieri something like those irregularities of the circulation due to dyspepsia , which , while making some part of the body , say the head , throb and ache at the least sound , yet leave [the whole man]1647-the whole man dull , heavy , only half - awake .

As [a child]569-a child [he]196-alfieri had vague and wistful cravings , untempered , unbeautified by such imaginative visions as usually accompany the eccentric feelings of [such children]1649-such children as are subject to [them]1649-such children . Obstinate and taciturn , [he]196-alfieri tells [us]1650-us of the curious passion which [he]196-alfieri experienced for [the little choristers]1651-the little choristers , [boys of twelve or thirteen]1652-boys of twelve or thirteen , whom [he]196-alfieri saw serving mass , or heard singing the responses , in [the Carmine Church at [Asti]99-asti]1653-the carmine church at asti . Silently , painfully , [he]196-alfieri seems to have yearned for [them]1651-the little choristers in solitude ; the daily visit to [the church]827-the church where [they]1651-the little choristers shone out in [their]1651-the little choristers white surplices , being the only pleasure in this black , blind little life of seven or eight . Some physical ailment , some want of change and movement may have underlain this morbid and sombre passionateness ; and [we]1650-us learn that when [he]196-alfieri was still [a tiny boy , having heard that the poisonous hemlock]1655-a tiny boy , having heard that the poisonous hemlock was a sort of grass which brought death , and with no clear notion what death was , but with a vague longing for it , [he]196-alfieri gorged [himself]196-alfieri with grass out of [the garden]1656-the garden , in the belief that there would be some hemlock in it .

At [school]1657-school [he]196-alfieri learned nothing . The education given at [the Academy of [Turin]97-turin]103-the academy of turin may , indeed , have been poor in quantity and quality ; still it was the best which [a young Piedmontese nobleman]1658-a young piedmontese nobleman could obtain , and [Alfieri]196-alfieri [himself]196-alfieri confesses that of [[his]196-alfieri school - fellows]1659-his school - fellows most came away with more profit , and some afterwards became cultured and even [learned men]1660-learned men . [He]196-alfieri learned nothing because [he]196-alfieri felt interest , emulation , curiosity about nothing . [His]196-alfieri nature was still dull , dumb , dormant ; and what [he]196-alfieri calls a period of vegetation might more fitly be termed a moral and intellectual hibernation . [His]196-alfieri school life is a weary , colourless , featureless part of [his]196-alfieri autobiography . [He]196-alfieri would seem to have made [neither friends]1661-neither friends nor [enemies]1662-enemies . The tricks practised by or upon [other school - boys]1663-other school - boys are never mentioned by [him]196-alfieri ; never a practical joke , a lark , a scrape . Of [his]196-alfieri intellectual tendencies , which were but little developed , [we]1664-we learn only that [he]196-alfieri exchanged a copy of [Ariosto]321-ariosto , finally confiscated by [the authorities]1665-the authorities , for a certain number of helpings of chicken , relinquished by [him]196-alfieri to [its possessor]1666-its possessor ; and that [he]196-alfieri bribed , with eatables also , [a certain other boy]1667-a certain other boy to tell [him]196-alfieri stories .

The one incident which sheds light upon [the lad]1668-the lad 's morbid constitution or condition , which reveals that strange , apathetic obstinacy , that vis inertiæ which was the spring even of [his]196-alfieri most decided actions in after life , and which at the same time raises grave doubts in [my]0-i mind whether there may not have been an actual taint of insanity in this extraordinary being , is the incident of [his]196-alfieri having submitted , rather than give in after some misdemeanour , to being confined to [[his]196-alfieri room in [the Academy]1670-the academy]1669-his room in the academy for nearly three months at a stretch . [Alfieri]196-alfieri was fifteen ; [he]196-alfieri might have been let loose for the asking , since there was no real severity in [the school]1671-the school . [He]196-alfieri slept nearly all day long , rose in the evening , but refused to let [himself]196-alfieri be combed or dressed , and lay for hours on a mattress before the fire , cooking a squalid meal of polenta instead of [his]196-alfieri dinner , which [he]196-alfieri regularly sent down ; receiving the visits of [[his]196-alfieri school - fellows]1659-his school - fellows without speaking or even moving ; deaf and dumb , as [he]196-alfieri describes [himself]196-alfieri , by the hour together , [his]196-alfieri eyes fixed on the ground , brimful with tears , but never permitting [himself]196-alfieri to cry or complain - a strange sort of savage animal rather than [a human being]1673-a human being .

After leaving [school]1657-school at eighteen , [he]196-alfieri began [his]196-alfieri long series of journeys , [his]196-alfieri series of passions for [women]547-women and for horses , passions dull and dumb , but violent , yet never such as to break through the spell of inarticulateness which seemed to freeze [his]196-alfieri nature . Nothing more curious can be fancied than [his]196-alfieri journeys . [He]196-alfieri went from place to place without being attracted to any , without feeling the smallest interest in anything which [he]196-alfieri saw , without contracting the faintest attachment for [any person]1676-any person or thing , driven along by a sort of fury of restlessness and sombre vacuity . [Many youths]1677-many youths have doubtless been to the full as indifferent as [Vittorio Alfieri]196-alfieri to all the objects of interest on [[their]1677-many youths road]1678-their road ; but [they]1677-many youths have been so from frivolity and giddiness , and [no one]1470-no one was ever less frivolous or giddy than [the young Alfieri]196-alfieri . With no particular purity of nature or principles of conduct to restrain [him]196-alfieri from vice , [his]196-alfieri dissipation could yet scarcely be called dissipation , so little did it wake up this lethargic , ailing , restless nature . Despite the furious passion which [he]196-alfieri had for horses , and the hysterical , one might almost say epileptic passions which [he]196-alfieri experienced for [women]547-women , [he]196-alfieri remained characterless , chaotic , only half alive . [His]196-alfieri many journeys gave [him]196-alfieri only the negative pleasure of getting away from [already known places]1681-already known places , the negative wisdom of seeing through a variety of things , military and diplomatic distinctions and national prejudices . [He]196-alfieri remained joyless and ignorant , and , what was worse , without longing for pleasure or desire for knowledge . More than once [kindly men of [the world]573-the world and [scholars]1684-scholars]1682-kindly men of the world and scholars were smitten with pity for [this strange lad]1685-this strange lad , in whom [they]1682-kindly men of the world and scholars could not but recognise certain [negative qualities rare in the eighteenth century]1686-negative qualities rare in the eighteenth century - an intense and cruel truthfulness , an absolute disinterestedness , a constitutional contempt for all the vanities and baseness of [the world]573-the world . [They]1682-kindly men of the world and scholars tried to talk to [him]196-alfieri , to lend [him]196-alfieri books , to awaken [him]196-alfieri out of this dormouse sleep of the intellect , to break the spell which weighed [him]196-alfieri down . All in vain . [He]196-alfieri continued [his]196-alfieri life of dull dissipation and dull wanderings , through [Italy]3-italy , [Germany]66-germany , [France]35-france , [England]13-england , far into [Spain]36-spain , [Portugal]14-portugal , [Russia]104-russia , and even [Finland]105-finland . Periodic fits of depression and of almost sordid avarice showed that [he]196-alfieri was still [the same person as [the boy of fifteen who had spent those three months unwashed , unkempt , in savage squalor]1689-the boy of fifteen who had spent those three months unwashed , unkempt , in savage squalor , by [his]196-alfieri fireside]1688-the same person as the boy of fifteen who had spent those three months unwashed , unkempt , in savage squalor , by his fireside ; and fits of brutal and almost maniac violence , as when , because a hair was sharply pulled out by the roots during the elaborate process of frizzling , [he]196-alfieri cut open with a blow of a heavy silver candlestick the temple of [[[his]196-alfieri faithful valet]1690-his faithful valet [Elia]322-elia , who had nursed [him]196-alfieri like [a mother , and whose only revenge , after this fearful scene]1692-a mother , and whose only revenge , after this fearful scene , was to keep the two handkerchiefs steeped with [his]196-alfieri blood as a memorial and a warning to [[his]196-alfieri master]1693-his master]1691-his faithful valet elia , who had nursed him like a mother , and whose only revenge , after this fearful scene , was to keep the two handkerchiefs steeped with his blood as a memorial and a warning to his master .

Still , seeing nothing , learning nothing , taking interest in nothing , by turns morosely apathetic and brutally violent , continually intriguing with [women]547-women , [mercenary]1695-mercenary or depraved , [Vittorio Alfieri]196-alfieri had , at twenty - five , less things to be proud of , but perhaps less also to regret as absolutely dishonourable , than [most young men of [his]196-alfieri time]1696-most young men of his time . [He]196-alfieri had never lied , never seduced , never stooped to anything which seemed to [him]196-alfieri demeaning . [He]196-alfieri was splashed with vice from head to foot , but [he]196-alfieri was neither unnerved nor warped by it . A subject of constant gossip , of frequent scandal , with [his]196-alfieri teams of half - tame horses , [his]196-alfieri flashy clothes , [his]196-alfieri furious passions for [worthless women]1697-worthless women , [his]196-alfieri moroseness and violence , [he]196-alfieri was still , so far , a very negative character , a mere mass of rough material , out of which [a man]1698-a man might be made . But who should mould that matter ? It is extremely difficult to understand how it came about , as difficult almost as to understand how a certain amount of inorganic molecules will sometimes suddenly seem to obey an impulse from within , and become an organism , a yeast plant , or a microscopic animal ; but whether or not [we]1699-we succeed in understanding the how and why of the phenomenon , the phenomenon nevertheless took place ; and this unorganised mass of passions called [Vittorio Alfieri]196-alfieri , this chaotic thing without a higher life or a purpose in [the world]573-the world , only partially sensitive , and seemingly quite impervious to external influence , suddenly obeyed some inner impulse perhaps some accumulation of unnoticed effects from without , and organised itself into [a man]1698-a man , [a thinker]1702-a thinker , and [a writer]1703-a writer .

[Alfieri]196-alfieri had always been capable of contempt for [others]1434-others , and largely also of contempt for [himself]196-alfieri : blind and dull , impulsive and indifferent by turns , [he]196-alfieri had yet felt acutely the ignominy of certain excesses , whether of avarice , or brutality , or love if love it may be called , which had ever and anon broken the monotony of [his]196-alfieri aimless life . Of these ignominies the one [he]196-alfieri had felt most , perhaps because it deprived [him]196-alfieri of the independence which even in [his]196-alfieri stupidest times [he]196-alfieri put [his]196-alfieri pride in , was the ignominy of love ; that is to say , of what love was to [him]196-alfieri , unworthy incapacity of doing without [a woman whom [he]196-alfieri despised and even occasionally hated]1705-a woman whom he despised and even occasionally hated . The very fits of moral hysterics , nay , of moral St. Vitus 's dance , of which such love maladies largely consisted , sickened [him]196-alfieri , degraded [him]196-alfieri in [his]196-alfieri own eyes like some disgusting physical infirmity . In [his]196-alfieri twenty - second year [he]196-alfieri had such a love malady , [he]196-alfieri had been the scandal of all [London]44-london in an intrigue with [a certain very lovely [Lady Ligonier]323-lady ligonier , who , divorced by [[her]323-lady ligonier husband]790-her husband for [her]323-lady ligonier guilt with [the young Italian]1708-the young italian , was on the point of being joyfully taken to [wife]1709-wife by [Alfieri]196-alfieri when it came out that before being [[his]196-alfieri mistress]934-his mistress]1706-a certain very lovely lady ligonier , who , divorced by her husband for her guilt with the young italian , was on the point of being joyfully taken to wife by alfieri when it came out that before being his mistress [she]323-lady ligonier had been [the mistress of [[her]323-lady ligonier own groom]1712-her own groom]1711-the mistress of her own groom ; a termination of the adventure which , much as it distressed [the writer of [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's autobiography]1713-the writer of alfieri 's autobiography , is extremely satisfactory to [the reader]1358-the reader . A few years later , after a variety of minor love affairs , [he]196-alfieri became entangled at [Turin]97-turin in the nets of a [Marchesa di Prié]324-marchesa di prié , [a rather faded Armida of very tarnished reputation , and whom [he]196-alfieri thoroughly despised and even disliked at the very height of [his]196-alfieri attachment]1715-a rather faded armida of very tarnished reputation , and whom he thoroughly despised and even disliked at the very height of his attachment . The struggles between [his]196-alfieri sense of weariness and degradation and [his]196-alfieri unworthy love for [this woman]1716-this woman half wore [him]196-alfieri out , and brought on a severe malady , from which [he]196-alfieri recovered only to swear [he]196-alfieri would never enter [[her]1716-this woman house]1717-her house again , and to return to [it]1717-her house as soon as [he]196-alfieri could stand on [his]196-alfieri feet . The beautiful social customs of eighteenth - century [Italy]3-italy authorised and even imposed upon [a man who had accepted the position of cavaliere]1718-a man who had accepted the position of cavaliere servente a sort of pseudo - platonic vice - husbandship which covered illicit connections with a worldly propriety to attend upon [[his]196-alfieri lady]1719-his lady from the moment of [her]1716-this woman getting up in the morning to the moment when [she]1716-this woman returned [home]1063-home or dismissed [[her]1716-this woman guests]1721-her guests at night , with only a few intervals during which [the lover]1722-the lover might have [his]1722-the lover meals or pay [his]1722-the lover visits ; so , when [the Marchesa di Prié]324-marchesa di prié fell ill of a malady which required absolute repose and silence , [Alfieri]196-alfieri was bound to spend the whole morning seated at the foot of [her]1716-this woman bed . During one of these weary watches , it came into [his]196-alfieri head to kill time by scribbling some dramatic scenes on loose sheets of paper , which [he]196-alfieri hid during the intervals of [his]196-alfieri visits under the cushion of an arm - chair . A Piedmontese and [a thorough ignoramus]1723-a thorough ignoramus , [he]196-alfieri had scarcely ever attempted to write even so much as a letter in Italian ; and as to a literary composition in any language , such a thing had never occurred to [him]196-alfieri . The Cleopatra thus written in [[[his]196-alfieri lady]1719-his lady 's bed - room]1725-his lady 's bed - room and secreted under the chair cushion , was a most worthless performance , but it made [Alfieri]196-alfieri [an author]1726-an author . Always devoured by a desire to shine , hitherto by the excellence of [his]196-alfieri get - up , the beauty of [his]196-alfieri person , and the number of [his]196-alfieri horses , it suddenly flashed across [him]196-alfieri that [he]196-alfieri might shine in future as [a poet]1727-a poet . This was the turning - point of [his]196-alfieri life , or what [he]196-alfieri called [his]196-alfieri liberation . But , like [a man bound in all [his]196-alfieri limbs]1728-a man bound in all his limbs , and who at length has slipped the cord from off one hand , there still remained to [Alfieri]196-alfieri an infinite amount of struggle , of bitter effort , of hopeless inaction , before [he]196-alfieri could completely liberate [himself]196-alfieri from the bonds of sloth , of worldly vanity , dissipation , and unworthy love , before [he]196-alfieri could step forth and walk steadily along [the new road]1729-the new road which had appeared to [him]196-alfieri . [His]196-alfieri ignorance was appalling . [He]196-alfieri could no longer construe a line of Latin , [he]196-alfieri had not for months opened a book ; and as to Italian , [he]196-alfieri knew it no better than [any Piedmontese street porter]1730-any piedmontese street porter . [His]196-alfieri idleness , [his]196-alfieri habit of absolute vacuity , was even worse ; [his]196-alfieri desire to shine before [the frivolous women]1731-the frivolous women , [the inane young men of [Turin]97-turin]1732-the inane young men of turin , nay , merely to have [himself]196-alfieri , [his]196-alfieri well - cut coat , [his]196-alfieri well - frizzled hair , the horse [he]196-alfieri rode or drove , noticed by any chance loafer in [the street]1061-the street , was another almost incredible obstacle ; and , worst of all , there was [his]196-alfieri degrading serfdom to [a woman whom [he]196-alfieri knew [he]196-alfieri neither loved nor respected , and who had never loved , still less respected , [him]196-alfieri]1734-a woman whom he knew he neither loved nor respected , and who had never loved , still less respected , him . But [Alfieri]196-alfieri , once awakened out of that strange long torpor of [his]196-alfieri youth , was able to put forth as active and invincible forces all that extraordinary obstinacy , that morose doggedness , that indifference to comfort and pleasure , that brutal violence which had more than once , in their negative condition , made [him]196-alfieri seem more like [some wild animal or half - savage monomaniac]1735-some wild animal or half - savage monomaniac than [an ordinary young man under five - and - twenty]1736-an ordinary young man under five - and - twenty . [He]196-alfieri had , moreover , at this moment , when all the energies of [his]196-alfieri nature suddenly burst out , a power of deliberate , complacent , and pitiless moral self - vivisection , a power of performing upon [his]196-alfieri character such cutting and ripping - open operations as [he]196-alfieri thought beneficial to [himself]196-alfieri , which makes [one]1590-one think of the abnormal faculty of enduring pain , the abnormal and almost cruel satisfaction in examining the mechanism of [one]1590-one 's own suffering , occasionally displayed by [hysterical women]1739-hysterical women ; and which brings back the impression already conveyed by the morbid sensitiveness , the frenzied violence , the moody torpor of [his]196-alfieri youth , that there was something abnormal in [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's whole nature . [He]196-alfieri was now employing that very hysterical satisfaction in pain and impatience of half measures , to reduce [himself]196-alfieri , by heroic means , to at least such moral and mental health as would permit the full exercise of [his]196-alfieri faculties . There exists a diary of [his]196-alfieri , written in 1777 , which is an almost unique example of the seemingly cold , but really excited and hysterical kind of self - vivisection of which [I]0-i have spoken . [Alfieri]196-alfieri had always been extraordinarily truthful , not merely for [his]196-alfieri time and country , but truthful quite beyond the limits of a mere negative virtue . But [he]196-alfieri was also , what seems almost incompatible with this ferocious truthfulness , excessively self - conscious and morally attitudinising , [a thin - skinned poseur]1740-a thin - skinned poseur . To reconcile these seemingly contradictory characteristics , to become what [he]196-alfieri wished to appear , to pose as what [he]196-alfieri was , to make [himself]196-alfieri up if [I]0-i may say so as [himself]196-alfieri , to intensify what [he]196-alfieri recognised as [his]196-alfieri main characteristics and efface all [his]196-alfieri other ones , now became to [Alfieri]196-alfieri a sort of unconscious aim of life , closely connected with [his]196-alfieri avowed desire to become [a great poet]1741-a great poet ; " the reason of which desire , "[196-alfieri] [he]196-alfieri [himself]196-alfieri wrote in [his]196-alfieri diary , " is [my]196-alfieri immoderate ambition , which , finding no other field , has devoted itself entirely to literature . "[196-alfieri] Nothing can be more serious , as [I]0-i have already remarked , than this diary of [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's struggles , where [he]196-alfieri notes , day by day , the laziness , the meanness , the want of frankness to [himself]196-alfieri and [others]1434-others , the despicable vanity , the attempt to appear what [he]196-alfieri is not , the indulged unfounded suspiciousness towards [[his]196-alfieri friends]860-his friends , all the little base defects which must have pained a nature like [his]196-alfieri more than any real sinfulness , as the prodding of [a surgeon]1744-a surgeon 's instruments would have agonised [such a man]1745-such a man more than an actual amputation . [He]196-alfieri narrates in extenso all [his]196-alfieri vacillations about nothing at all , all [his]196-alfieri givings way to laziness , all [his]196-alfieri insincere confidences made to [others]1434-others . One morning is consumed in debating whether or not [he]196-alfieri will buy a certain Indian walking - stick : " Torn by avarice and the ambition of having it , [I]196-alfieri go away without deciding whether [I]196-alfieri will buy it or not , yet [I]196-alfieri know full well that before two days are out [I]196-alfieri shall have bought it . Seeking to understand this contradiction , [I]196-alfieri discover a thousand ridiculous dirtinesses in [my]196-alfieri character mille ridicole porcherie . "[196-alfieri] Another day [he]196-alfieri notes down , after describing the mean envy with which [he]196-alfieri has listened to the praises of [another member of [[his]196-alfieri little club of [dilettante authors]1749-dilettante authors]1748-his little club of dilettante authors]1747-another member of his little club of dilettante authors : " [I]196-alfieri do believe that as much praise as is being given and will ever be given to [all mankind]3923-all mankind for every sort of praiseworthy thing , [I]196-alfieri should like to snap up for [myself]196-alfieri alone . "[196-alfieri] Again , another day [he]196-alfieri writes : " More lazy than ever . Walking with [a friend]3924-a friend , and talking about [our]3925-our incomes , c. [I]196-alfieri thought [I]196-alfieri was giving [him]3924-a friend a perfectly open account of [my]196-alfieri money matters ; but , with the best intention of telling [him]3924-a friend the truth , [I]196-alfieri find that , in order to deceive [myself]196-alfieri as well as [him]3924-a friend , [I]196-alfieri increased [my]196-alfieri fortune by one - fifth . "[196-alfieri] Again , " [I]196-alfieri had some doubts whether , as it was blowing hard on [the promenade]3926-the promenade , [I]196-alfieri would go on as far as where [the ladies]3927-the ladies were walking ; because , knowing that [I]196-alfieri was looking pale and ill , and that the wind had taken the powder out of [my]196-alfieri hair , [I]196-alfieri was unwilling to show [myself]196-alfieri in a condition so unsuitable to [my]196-alfieri pretensions to beauty . "[196-alfieri]

But while thus analyzing [himself]1750-i , while working at Latin and grammar like [a school - boy]1751-a school - boy , [this fashionable young man]1752-this fashionable young man , ashamed of being seen when [he]1750-i was not in good looks , ashamed of having one horse less than usual , was continually ruminating over the glory for which [he]1750-i intended living , and which [he]1750-i appears never for a moment to have doubted of attaining . " In [my]1750-i mind , which is completely given up to the idea of glory , [I]1750-i frequently go over the plan of [my]1750-i life . [I]1750-i determine that at forty - five [I]1750-i will write no more , but merely enjoy the fame which [I]1750-i shall have obtained , or imagine that [I]1750-i have obtained , and prepare [myself]1750-i for death . One thing only makes [me]1750-i uneasy : [I]1750-i fear that as [I]1750-i approach the prescribed limit , [I]1750-i may push it continually back , and that at forty - five [I]1750-i may still be thinking only of continuing to live and , perhaps , of continuing to scribble . Hard as [I]1750-i try to think , or to make [others]1434-others think , that [I]1750-i am different from the rest of [mankind]1604-mankind , [I]1750-i fear , [I]1750-i tremble lest [I]1750-i be extremely like [them]1434-others . "[1750-i]

But in order to devote [himself]1753-his to the pursuit of literary glory , one thing remained to be achieved by [this strange , self - conscious , frank , contemptuous , and vain creature]1754-this strange , self - conscious , frank , contemptuous , and vain creature , by [this young man who , even in [his]1753-his weaknesses , has a certain heroic air about [him]1753-his]1755-this young man who , even in his weaknesses , has a certain heroic air about him . It was necessary to break through the bonds of unworthy love . Unable to trust any longer to [his]1753-his often baffled resolution and self - command , [Alfieri]196-alfieri devised a primitive and theatrical remedy too much in harmony with [his]1753-his whole nature to be otherwise than efficacious . [The lady]1270-the lady occupied [a house in [the great rococo square of [San Carlo]106-san carlo]1758-the great rococo square of san carlo , opposite to [the one which [he]196-alfieri rented]1759-the one which he rented]1757-a house in the great rococo square of san carlo , opposite to the one which he rented ; [she]1270-the lady could not go in or out of [her]1270-the lady door without being seen by [Alfieri]196-alfieri , and the sight of [her]1270-the lady was too much for [him]196-alfieri : [he]196-alfieri invariably broke all [his]196-alfieri resolves and went across [the square]830-the square to [[his]196-alfieri Armida]1761-his armida . Knowing this , [Alfieri]196-alfieri obliged [a friend of his]1762-a friend of his to receive from [him]196-alfieri a solemn written promise to the effect that [he]196-alfieri would not merely never go to [the lady]1270-the lady , nor take any notice of [her]1270-the lady messages , but that , until [he]196-alfieri felt [himself]196-alfieri absolutely indifferent and beyond [her]1270-the lady reach , [he]196-alfieri would go out only in solitary places and at unlikely hours , and spend the greater part of the day seated at [his]196-alfieri window looking at [[her]1270-the lady house]1717-her house , seeing [her]1270-the lady pass , hearing [her]1270-the lady spoken of , receiving [her]1270-the lady letters , without ever approaching [her]1270-the lady or sending [her]1270-the lady the smallest message . As a pledge of this engagement , [Alfieri]196-alfieri cut off [his]196-alfieri long red hair , and sent the plait to [[his]196-alfieri friend]1173-his friend , leaving [himself]196-alfieri in a state of crop - headedness , which made it utterly impossible , in that day when wigs had been given up but short hair had not yet been adopted , for [him]196-alfieri to appear anywhere . And then [he]196-alfieri had [himself]196-alfieri tied to [his]196-alfieri chair with ropes hidden under [his]196-alfieri cloak , and spent day after day looking at [[his]196-alfieri mistress]934-his mistress ' windows , quite unable to read a word or attend to conversation , raging and sobbing and howling like a demoniac , but never asking to be untied ; until , at the end of a fortnight or three weeks , [he]196-alfieri was rewarded , most characteristically , by being at once delivered of all love for [[his]196-alfieri lady]1719-his lady , and inspired with the idea for a sonnet .

[Alfieri]196-alfieri worked harder and harder at [his]196-alfieri Latin and Italian lessons , sketched out the plan of several plays : and , then , in the early summer of 1776 , got together [his]196-alfieri horses , procured a permission to travel from [the King of [Sardinia]107-sardinia]1768-the king of sardinia , and set out for [Tuscany]80-tuscany in order to learn the language in which [he]196-alfieri was to achieve that great literary glory to which [he]196-alfieri had dedicated [his]196-alfieri life .

CHAPTER VII .

[THE CAVALIERE SERVENTE]1769-the cavaliere servente .

[Alfieri]196-alfieri 's greatest terror in life was to fall in love once more . All [his]196-alfieri love affairs had been degrading to [his]196-alfieri good sense , [his]196-alfieri will and [his]196-alfieri manhood ; they had been odious , even at the moment , to [his]196-alfieri extraordinary innate passion , or , one might almost say , monomania for independence ; [he]196-alfieri who even in [his]196-alfieri dullest and most inane years had hated the thought of any sort of military or diplomatic position which should imply subjection to a despotic government , whose only strong feeling about [the world in general]1770-the world in general had long been a fierce hatred and contempt both for those who tyrannised and [those who were tyrannised over]1771-those who were tyrannised over , this [Alfieri]196-alfieri had always , as [he]196-alfieri tells [us]1772-us , fled , though unsuccessfully , from the presence of [women whose social position though the words sound like a sarcasm]1773-women whose social position though the words sound like a sarcasm was sufficiently good to make any regular love intrigue possible or probable . How much more must [he]196-alfieri not defend [his]196-alfieri liberty now that [he]196-alfieri saw before [him]196-alfieri the direct road to glory , and felt within [himself]196-alfieri the power to journey along it .

Thus it was , as [he]196-alfieri explains in [his]196-alfieri autobiography , that on [his]196-alfieri first arrival in [Florence]9-florence , hearing [everyone]1388-everyone praising the character and talents of [the wife of [Charles Edward Stuart]204-charles edward]686-the wife of charles edward stuart , and seeing [the beautiful young woman]1776-the beautiful young woman at [theatres]1520-theatres and in [the public promenade]1778-the public promenade , [he]196-alfieri resolutely declined to be introduced to [her]1776-the beautiful young woman . The very charm of the impression which [she]1776-the beautiful young woman had thus accidentally made upon [him]196-alfieri , the vivid image of those very dark eyes [I]0-i am translating [his]196-alfieri words , and must explain that [her]1776-the beautiful young woman eyes , which seemed blue to [Bonstetten]280-bonstetten and dark to [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's , were in reality of that hazel colour which gives great prominence to the pupil , and therefore leaves the idea of black eyes contrasting with the brilliant fair skin and pale blonde hair , of the graciousness and sweetness and perhaps even a certain sad austerity in [her]1776-the beautiful young woman whole appearance and manner , - all this made [Alfieri]196-alfieri determine to avoid all personal acquaintance .

But after some months at [Siena]6-siena , where [his]196-alfieri thoughts had been entirely absorbed in the literary projects which [he]196-alfieri discussed with [[his]196-alfieri new friend]1779-his new friend , [the grave and good and serious - minded Gori]325-gori , and [one or two Sienese professors]1780-one or two sienese professors , after that first feeling of attraction had died away , and [he]196-alfieri felt [himself]196-alfieri covered , as it were , with an impenetrable armour of poetic interests , [Alfieri]196-alfieri decided , on [his]196-alfieri return to [Florence]9-florence , that [he]196-alfieri was quite sufficiently of [a new man]1781-a new man to expose [himself]196-alfieri without any danger to [such a lady]1782-such a lady as [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany . [He]196-alfieri was , after all , [a different individual from [that inane , dull , violent young man who in the vacuity of life had raged and roared in the chains of unworthy love]1785-that inane , dull , violent young man who in the vacuity of life had raged and roared in the chains of unworthy love]1784-a different individual from that inane , dull , violent young man who in the vacuity of life had raged and roared in the chains of unworthy love . And [she]1782-such a lady , [she]1782-such a lady also , was quite [a different woman from [the Lady Ligonier]323-lady ligonier]1786-a different woman from the lady ligonier and from [the Marchesa di Prié]1787-the marchesa di prié , [the shameless , unfaithful wives]1788-the shameless , unfaithful wives , and [heartless , vain , worldly coquettes who had made such havoc of [his]196-alfieri heart]1789-heartless , vain , worldly coquettes who had made such havoc of his heart . [She]1782-such a lady was [a cold , virtuous , extremely intellectual woman , trying to find consolation for [her]1782-such a lady quietly and bravely supported miseries in study , in abstract interests which should take away [her]1782-such a lady thoughts from the sickening reality of things]1790-a cold , virtuous , extremely intellectual woman , trying to find consolation for her quietly and bravely supported miseries in study , in abstract interests which should take away her thoughts from the sickening reality of things ; [a woman who would be valuable as [a friend]3924-a friend to [a poet]1727-a poet , and who would know how to value [his]196-alfieri friendship]1791-a woman who would be valuable as a friend to a poet , and who would know how to value his friendship . And [he]196-alfieri , continually seeking for [people who could understand [his]196-alfieri literary ambitions , with whom [he]196-alfieri could discuss all [his]196-alfieri poetical projects , and from whom [he]196-alfieri might receive assistance in this new intellectual life]1794-people who could understand his literary ambitions , with whom he could discuss all his poetical projects , and from whom he might receive assistance in this new intellectual life , was [he]196-alfieri not in need of such a friendship ? Would [he]196-alfieri not appreciate its usefulness and uniqueness sufficiently to see that it did not turn to a mere useless and demoralising love affair ? There may also have been something very reassuring to [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's apprehensions in the knowledge that [he]196-alfieri would be dealing , not with [an Italian woman]1795-an italian woman , accustomed and almost socially obliged to hold [a man]1698-a man in the degrading bonds of cicisbeism , but with [a foreigner]1797-a foreigner , [the jealously - guarded wife of [a sort of legendary ogre]1799-a sort of legendary ogre]1798-the jealously - guarded wife of a sort of legendary ogre , with whom , however much the old fury of love might awaken in [him]196-alfieri , there could by no possibility be anything beyond the most strictly watched friendship . So [Alfieri]196-alfieri went to [the palace of [the Count of [Albany]196-alfieri]607-the count of albany]1800-the palace of the count of albany ; and , having once been , returned [there]593-there .

[The palace bought by [Charles Edward]204-charles edward about 1776]1803-the palace bought by charles edward about 1776 stands in [the most remote and peaceful quarter of [Florence]9-florence]1804-the most remote and peaceful quarter of florence . [A few quiet streets]1805-a few quiet streets , unbroken by [shop - fronts and unfrequented by vehicles]1806-shop - fronts and unfrequented by vehicles , lead up to [that quarter]1807-that quarter ; [streets of low white - washed convent]1808-streets of low white - washed convent walls overtopped by trees , of [silent palaces]1809-silent palaces , of [unpretending little houses of the seventeenth or eighteenth century]1810-unpretending little houses of the seventeenth or eighteenth century , from behind whose iron window - gratings and blistered green shutters one expects even now , as one passes in the silence of the summer afternoons , to hear the faint jangle of some harpsichord - strummed minuet , the turns and sudden high notes of some long - forgotten song by [Cimarosa]108-cimarosa or [Paisiello]326-paisiello . [It]1811-it is a region of dead walls , over which bend the acacias and elms , over which shoot up the cypresses and cedars of [innumerable convent]1812-innumerable convent and [[palace]1813-palace - gardens]1814-palace - gardens , on whose flower - beds and fountains and quincunxes the first - floor windows look down . In the midst of all this , at the corner of [two very quiet streets]1815-two very quiet streets , stands [the palace]779-the palace , now of [the Duke of [San Clemente]94-san clemente]1496-the duke of san clemente , [an ungainly , yellow structure of various epochs , with a pretty late sixteenth - century belvedere tower on one side]1818-an ungainly , yellow structure of various epochs , with a pretty late sixteenth - century belvedere tower on one side ; a lot of shuttered and heavily - grated seventeenth - century windows , ornamented with stone stay - laces and tags , upon [the dark street]1819-the dark street ; and to the back [a desolate old garden]1820-a desolate old garden , where the vines have crawled over the stonework , and the grotesque seventeenth - century statues , green and yellow with lichen , stand in niches among the ill - trimmed hedges of ilex and laurel : the most old - world house and garden in [the old - world part of [the town]770-the town]1821-the old - world part of the town . The eighteenth century still seems very near as [we]1823-we walk in [those streets]1824-those streets and look in , through the railings , at the ilex and laurel quincunxes , the lichened statues of [that garden]1825-that garden ; and from the roof of [the house]769-the house still floats , creaking in the wind , regardless of the triumph of [the Hanoverians]327-the hanoverians , unconscious of the many banners which have been thrown , mere heaps of obsolete coloured tatters , on the dust - heap , a rusty metal weather - vane , bearing the initials of [Carolus Rex]328-carolus rex , [the last successor of the standard that was raised in [Glenfinnan]110-glenfinnan]1827-the last successor of the standard that was raised in glenfinnan .

In [this house]1828-this house was now developing one of the most singular loves that ever were . Shortly after [his]1829-his introduction to [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany , [Alfieri]196-alfieri , terrified lest [he]1829-his might be forfeiting [his]1829-his spiritual liberty once more , took to flight and tried to forget [the lady]1270-the lady in a mad journey to [Rome]10-rome . But [he]1829-his had not forgotten [her]1270-the lady ; and on [his]1829-his passage through [Siena]6-siena , returning to [Florence]9-florence , [he]1829-his had explained [his]1829-his feelings , [his]1829-his fears , to [[his]1829-his friend]1173-his friend [Francesco Gori]325-gori . [This Gori]325-gori , [a young Sienese of the middle class]1833-a young sienese of the middle class , extremely cultured , of " antique uprightness , "[325-gori] to use the eighteenth - century phrase , seems to have taken to [his]325-gori heart , as one might [some wild younger brother]1834-some wild younger brother , or [some eccentric , moody child]1835-some eccentric , moody child , [the strange , self - engrossed , passionate Piedmontese]1836-the strange , self - engrossed , passionate piedmontese . [A gentle , grave , and quiet man]1837-a gentle , grave , and quiet man , [he]1837-a gentle , grave , and quiet man had loved the magnanimity and independence so curiously mingled with mere vanity and egotism in [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's nature ; [he]1837-a gentle , grave , and quiet man had never tired of hearing [[his]1829-his friend]1173-his friend 's plans for the future , had never smiled at [his]1837-a gentle , grave , and quiet man almost comic certainty of supreme greatness , [he]1837-a gentle , grave , and quiet man had never lost patience with the self - meritorious egotism which made all [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's actions seem the one interest of [the world]573-the world in [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's own eyes . To [Francesco Gori]325-gori , therefore , [Alfieri]196-alfieri went for advice : ought [he]196-alfieri , or ought [he]196-alfieri not , to fly from this new love while it was still possible to do so ?

The grave and virtuous [Gori]325-gori answered that [he]196-alfieri should not : this new love had been sent to [him]196-alfieri as a cure for all baser loves ; instead of crushing it as an obstacle to [his]196-alfieri higher life and [his]196-alfieri glory , [he]196-alfieri should thankfully cultivate it as an incentive and assistance in working out [his]196-alfieri intellectual redemption .

Let [us]1840-us pause , and consider for a moment the meaning of [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's question , and the meaning of [Gori]325-gori 's answer ; let [us]1840-us try and realise the ideas and feelings of [two honourable men]1841-two honourable men , seeking a higher life , in [a country so near [our]1840-us own as [Italy]3-italy]1842-a country so near our own as italy , and so short a while ago as the year 1777 . Here was [Alfieri]196-alfieri , passionately desirous to redeem [his]196-alfieri own existence by intellectual efforts , and confident of a vague mission to awaken [[his]196-alfieri countrymen]1843-his countrymen to [his]196-alfieri own nobler feelings : to the contempt of sensual pleasures and worldly vanities , the hatred of political and religious servitude , the love of truth and justice , the love of [Italy]3-italy . Here was this [Alfieri]196-alfieri , at the very outset of [his]196-alfieri new career , solemnly confiding to [[his]196-alfieri kindest and wisest friend]1844-his kindest and wisest friend the scruples , the fears , which restrained [him]196-alfieri from seeking the company of [a woman whom [he]196-alfieri was beginning to love , and who was beginning to love [him]196-alfieri]1845-a woman whom he was beginning to love , and who was beginning to love him , [a young woman married by mere worldly convention to [a sickly , brutal , and brutish drunkard]1847-a sickly , brutal , and brutish drunkard , old enough to be [[her]1846-a young woman married by mere worldly convention to a sickly , brutal , and brutish drunkard , old enough to be her father father]1180-her father]1846-a young woman married by mere worldly convention to a sickly , brutal , and brutish drunkard , old enough to be her father . And what were these scruples ? Merely that a new love might distract [Alfieri]196-alfieri from [his]196-alfieri plans of study and work , that [a woman]689-a woman might cheat [him]196-alfieri of glory , and [Italy]3-italy of the tragic drama which would school [her]689-a woman to virtue . That there could be any other scruples appears never to have crossed [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's brain : that there could be any reason to pause and ask [himself]196-alfieri whether [he]196-alfieri was doing wrong or ill before exposing to temptation [the woman whom [he]196-alfieri loved]1850-the woman whom he loved , and the honour which [he]196-alfieri loved more than [her]689-a woman ; whether [he]196-alfieri had a right to return to [the palace of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward]1851-the palace of charles edward and , while receiving [his]196-alfieri hospitality , while enjoying [his]196-alfieri confidence , to teach [the wife of [[his]196-alfieri host]874-his host how to love [another man]1854-another man than [[her]689-a woman husband]790-her husband]1852-the wife of his host how to love another man than her husband ; whether [he]196-alfieri had a right to return to the presence of [that beautiful and intellectual lady]1856-that beautiful and intellectual lady , who had hitherto suffered only from the brutishness of [[her]1856-that beautiful and intellectual lady husband]790-her husband , and add to these sufferings the sufferings of hopeless love , the sufferings of a guilty conscience ?

But to [the Italian of the eighteenth century]1858-the italian of the eighteenth century , even to [the man who most thoroughly despised and loathed [[his]1859-the man who most thoroughly despised and loathed his country 's and century 's corruption country]1860-his country 's and century 's corruption]1859-the man who most thoroughly despised and loathed his country 's and century 's corruption , no such scruple ever came . What consideration need [any man]1861-any man or [any woman]1862-any woman waste upon [a husband]1863-a husband ? What possible disgrace could come to [a woman]689-a woman in having [a lover]1865-a lover ? And did not the frantic jealousy of [the besotted old husband]1866-the besotted old husband , [his]1866-the besotted old husband continual attendance , [his]1866-the besotted old husband perpetual spying , most effectually remove any further consideration there might be for [him]1866-the besotted old husband ?

[I]0-i scarcely know whether it is a thing about which to be cheerful or sad , proud or ashamed ; but the more one studies the ideas and feelings of [[even one]1867-even one 's nearest neighbours]1868-even one 's nearest neighbours , in place or in time , the more is one impressed with the sense that , say what [people]927-people choose , [men]711-men and [women]547-women do not think and feel , even upon the most important subjects , in anything like a uniform manner . Social misarrangements , which are crimes towards [the individual]1872-the individual , are invariably partially righted , made endurable , by individual rearrangements , which are crimes towards [society]996-society . [The woman]1874-the woman was not consulted by [[her]1874-the woman parents]1875-her parents before [her]1874-the woman marriage , [she]1874-the woman was not restrained by [her]1874-the woman conscience afterwards ; [she]1874-the woman was given for ambition to [a man whose tenure of [her]1874-the woman received legal and religious sanction]1876-a man whose tenure of her received legal and religious sanction ; [she]1874-the woman gave [herself]1874-the woman for love to [a man whose possession of [her]1874-the woman was against society and against religion]1877-a man whose possession of her was against society and against religion ; but [society]996-society received [her]1874-the woman to [[its]996-society parties]1879-its parties , and [the Church]827-the church gave [her]1874-the woman its communion . And thus , in [Italy]3-italy , and in the eighteenth century , where [no one]1470-no one had found any fault at [a girl of nineteen]690-a girl of nineteen being married by proxy to [a man who turned out to be a disgusting and brutal sot]1883-a man who turned out to be a disgusting and brutal sot ; [no one]1470-no one also could find any fault at [a young man of twenty - eight]1885-a young man of twenty - eight seeking , and obtaining , the love of [a married woman of twenty - five]1886-a married woman of twenty - five . The immoral law had produced the immoral lawlessness . So , to the scruples of [Alfieri]196-alfieri , [Francesco Gori]325-gori had answered : " Return to [Florence]9-florence . "[325-gori]

[We]1887-we shall now see how , out of this vile piece of prose , the higher nature of [Alfieri]196-alfieri and of [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany , and what a satire upon poetic and platonic affection ! most of all , the monomaniac jealousy of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward , contrived to make a sort of poetry .

CHAPTER VIII .

THE ESCAPE .

[Alfieri]196-alfieri 's fears had been groundless . [His]196-alfieri love for [the wife of [Charles Edward Stuart]204-charles edward]686-the wife of charles edward stuart - a love , [he]196-alfieri tells [us]1887-we , quite different from any [he]196-alfieri had previously experienced , quiet , pure , and solemn - was destined not to interfere with that austere process of detaching [his]196-alfieri soul from the base passions of [the world]573-the world , and devoting it to the creation of a new style of poetry , to the achievement of a new kind of glory ; nay , rather , by bringing to the surface whatever capacity for tenderness and self - restraint and respect for [others]1434-others had hitherto lurked within this fantastic nature , this new love helped to complete that strange monumental personality of [Alfieri]196-alfieri - a personality more striking , more ideal , than any of those plays by which [he]196-alfieri hoped to regenerate [Italy]3-italy , and which has been far more potent than [his]196-alfieri works in the moral regeneration of [[his]196-alfieri country]1860-his country . [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's youth had been illiterate and stupid ; and [he]196-alfieri required , in order to make up for so much waste of time and waste of spirit , that [he]196-alfieri should now be surrounded by an atmosphere as intensely intellectual as the atmosphere in which [he]196-alfieri had previously lived had been the reverse . After the long spiritual numbness of [his]196-alfieri earlier years , this soul , if it was to be kept alive , must be kept in an almost artificially high spiritual temperature , and continually plied with spiritual cordials . These advantages [he]196-alfieri obtained in the love , or , [we]1887-we ought rather to say , the friendship of [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany , and it is extremely improbable whether [he]196-alfieri would have obtained them otherwise . Irritable and vain and moody , at once excessively persuaded of [his]196-alfieri own dramatic mission and morbidly diffident of [his]196-alfieri actual powers of carrying it out , contemptuous of [others]1434-others and of [himself]196-alfieri , [Alfieri]196-alfieri , who required such constant sympathy and encouragement in [his]196-alfieri work , was not [the man who could hope to obtain much of either from other men]1895-the man who could hope to obtain much of either from other men , whom [his]196-alfieri excessive pretensions , [his]196-alfieri ups and downs of humour , [his]196-alfieri very dissatisfaction with [himself]196-alfieri , must have quickly exhausted of the small amount of brotherly tenderness which seems to exist in [the literary brotherhood]1896-the literary brotherhood . [He]196-alfieri did , indeed , meet a degree of sincere helpfulness and friendliness from [the members of [the Turinese Literary Club]111-the turinese literary club]1897-the members of the turinese literary club ; from [Cesarotti]329-cesarotti , [the translator of [Ossian]330-ossian]1898-the translator of ossian ; from [Parini]331-parini , [the great Milanese satirist]1899-the great milanese satirist , and from [one or two other men of letters]1900-one or two other men of letters ; which shows that there is more kindness in [the world]573-the world than [he]196-alfieri ever would admit , and confirms [me]0-i in [my]0-i remark that [he]196-alfieri was singularly well treated by fate and [mankind]1604-mankind . But all this was very lukewarm sympathy ; and except from [[his]196-alfieri two great friends]1903-his two great friends , [Francesco Gori]325-gori and [Tommaso di Caluso]332-tommaso di caluso , [a difficult - tempered man like [Alfieri]196-alfieri]1904-a difficult - tempered man like alfieri could receive only lukewarmness . Now what [he]196-alfieri required was sympathy , admiration , adoration , of the most burning description . This was possible , towards [such a man]1745-such a man , only from [a woman]689-a woman . But where find [the woman who could give it]1907-the woman who could give it , among [the convent - educated , early corrupted , frivolous ladies of]1908-the convent - educated , early corrupted , frivolous ladies of [Italy]3-italy , to whom love - making was the highest interest in life , but an interest only a trifle higher than card - playing , dancing , or dressing ? Where , even among [the very small number of women like [Silvia Verza]333-silvia verza at [Verona]112-verona]1909-the very small number of women like silvia verza at verona , [Isabella Albrizzi]334-isabella albrizzi at [Venice]18-venice , or [Paolina Castiglione]335-paolina castiglione at [Milan]7-milan , who actually had some amount of culture , and actually prided [themselves]1910-themselves on it ? The rank and file of [Italian ladies]1911-italian ladies could give [him]196-alfieri only [another Marchesa di Prié]1912-another marchesa di prié , a little better or a little worse , [another woman who would degrade [him]196-alfieri in the sensual and inane routine of a cicisbéo]1913-another woman who would degrade him in the sensual and inane routine of a cicisbéo . [The exceptional ladies]1914-the exceptional ladies were even worse . [Fancy]336-fancy [this morbid , conceited , self - doubtful , violent , moody Alfieri]1915-this morbid , conceited , self - doubtful , violent , moody alfieri accepting literary sympathy in [a room]1916-a room full of [small provincial lions]1917-small provincial lions - sympathy which had to be divided with [half a dozen others]1918-half a dozen others ; [learned persons who edited Latin inscriptions]1919-learned persons who edited latin inscriptions , [dapper poet priestlets]1920-dapper poet priestlets , [their]1910-themselves pockets crammed with sonnets on [ladies]1921-ladies ' hats , [opera - singers]1922-opera - singers , canary birds , births , deaths , and marriages , and ponderous pedants of all sorts and descriptions . Why , [a lady who set up as the muse of [a hot - tempered and brow - beating creature like [Alfieri]196-alfieri]1924-a hot - tempered and brow - beating creature like alfieri , [a man whom consciousness of imperfect education]1925-a man whom consciousness of imperfect education made horribly sensitive - [such a lady]1782-such a lady would have lost all the accustomed guests of [[her]1782-such a lady salon]1927-her salon]1923-a lady who set up as the muse of a hot - tempered and brow - beating creature like alfieri , a man whom consciousness of imperfect education made horribly sensitive - such a lady would have lost all the accustomed guests of her salon in ten days ' time . Herein , therefore , consisted the uniqueness of [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany , in the fact that [she]527-the countess of albany was everything to [Alfieri]196-alfieri , which [no other woman]1929-no other woman could be . Originally better educated than [[her]1782-such a lady Italian contemporaries]1930-her italian contemporaries , [the ex - canoness of [Mons]17-mons , half - Flemish , half - German by [family]1932-family]1931-the ex - canoness of mons , half - flemish , half - german by family , French by training , and connected with [England]13-england through [her]1782-such a lady marriage with [the Pretender]605-the pretender , had the advantage of open doors upon several fields of culture . [She]1782-such a lady could read the books of [four different nations]1934-four different nations - a very rare accomplishment in [her]1782-such a lady day ; and [she]1782-such a lady was , moreover , [one of [those women]1936-those women , rarer even in the eighteenth century than now - a - days , whose nature , while unproductive in any particular line , is intensely and almost exclusively intellectual , and in the intellectual domain even more intensely and almost exclusively literary - [women who are born readers]1937-women who are born readers , to whom a new poem is as great an excitement as a new toilette , a treatise of philosophy [we]1938-we shall see [the Countess devouring Kant]310-albany long before [he]196-alfieri had been heard of out of [Germany]66-germany]1935-one of those women , rarer even in the eighteenth century than now - a - days , whose nature , while unproductive in any particular line , is intensely and almost exclusively intellectual , and in the intellectual domain even more intensely and almost exclusively literary - women who are born readers , to whom a new poem is as great an excitement as a new toilette , a treatise of philosophy we shall see the countess devouring kant long before he had been heard of out of germany more exquisitely delightful than a symphony . And [this woman , thus educated , with this immense fund of intellectual energy]1939-this woman , thus educated , with this immense fund of intellectual energy , was living , not a normal life with the normal distracting influences of [an endurable husband]1940-an endurable husband , of [children]548-children and society , but a life of frightful mental and moral isolation , by the side , or rather in the loathsome shadow , of [a degraded , sordid , violent , and jealous brute , from the reality of whose beastly excesses and bestial fury , of whose vomitings and oaths and outrages and blows]1942-a degraded , sordid , violent , and jealous brute , from the reality of whose beastly excesses and bestial fury , of whose vomitings and oaths and outrages and blows , [she]1782-such a lady could take refuge only in [the unreal world of books]1943-the unreal world of books .

With such [a woman]689-a woman , [Alfieri]196-alfieri , accepted as [an intimate]1945-an intimate by [the husband]1521-the husband , who doubtless thought [one hare - brained poet more easy to manage than two or three fashionable gallants]1947-one hare - brained poet more easy to manage than two or three fashionable gallants - with [such a woman as this]1948-such a woman as this , [Alfieri]196-alfieri might talk over plans of self - culture and work , [his]196-alfieri plays , [his]196-alfieri essays on liberty and literature , and all the things by which [he]196-alfieri intended to redeem [Italy]337-lamartine and make [himself]196-alfieri immortal , without any fear of [[his]196-alfieri listener]1949-his listener ever growing weary ; from [her]689-a woman [he]196-alfieri could receive that passionate sympathy and encouragement without which life and work were impossible to [him]196-alfieri . For [we]1950-we must bear in mind what [a man like [Alfieri]196-alfieri]1951-a man like alfieri , in the heyday of [his]196-alfieri youth , [his]196-alfieri beauty , and that genius which was the indomitable energy and independence of [his]196-alfieri nature , must have been in the eyes of [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany . [She]527-the countess of albany had been married at nineteen - [she]527-the countess of albany was now twenty - six : in those seven years of suffering there had been ample time to obliterate all traces of [the frivolous , worldly girl whom [Bonstetten]280-bonstetten had seen light - heartedly laughing at [[her]527-the countess of albany old husband]1954-her old husband 's jokes]1953-the frivolous , worldly girl whom bonstetten had seen light - heartedly laughing at her old husband 's jokes ; there had been plenty of time to produce in this excessively intellectual nature that vague dissatisfaction , that desire for the ideal , which is the price too often paid for the consolation of mere abstract and literary interests . The pressure of constant disgust and terror at [[her]527-the countess of albany husband]790-her husband 's doings , the terrible mental and moral solitude of living by [such a husband]1956-such a husband 's side , had probably wrought up [Louise]233-louise d'Albany to the very highest and almost morbid refinement of nature - a refinement far surpassing the normal condition of [her]527-the countess of albany character , even as the extra fining off of already delicate features by illness will make them surpass by far [their]1957-their healthy degree of beauty . In such a mental condition the sense of what [[her]527-the countess of albany husband]790-her husband was must have exasperated [her]527-the countess of albany imagination quite as much as [his]790-her husband actual loathsomeness must have repelled [her]527-the countess of albany feelings ; the knowledge of the frightful moral and intellectual fall of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward must have been as bad as the filthy place to which [he]790-her husband had fallen . And opposite to the image of [the Pretender]605-the pretender must constantly have arisen the image of [Alfieri]196-alfieri - opposite to the image of [the man , once heroic and charming and brilliant]1960-the man , once heroic and charming and brilliant , who had sold [his]196-alfieri heroism and [his]196-alfieri charm , [his]196-alfieri mind and [his]196-alfieri manhood , for the bestial pleasure of drink - who had rewarded the devotion and self - sacrifice and noble enthusiasm of [[his]196-alfieri followers]707-his followers by the sight , worse than the scaffold on [Tower Hill]113-tower hill , of [[their]707-his followers idol]1962-their idol turning into [a half - maniac , besotted brute]1963-a half - maniac , besotted brute ; opposite to this image of degradation must have arisen the image of [the man who had wrestled with the baser passions of [his]196-alfieri nature , who had broken through the base habits of [his]196-alfieri youth , who had fashioned [himself]196-alfieri into a noble moral shape as the marble is fashioned by the hand of [the sculptor]1965-the sculptor]1964-the man who had wrestled with the baser passions of his nature , who had broken through the base habits of his youth , who had fashioned himself into a noble moral shape as the marble is fashioned by the hand of the sculptor ; who was struggling still , not merely with the difficulties of [his]196-alfieri art , but with whatever [he]196-alfieri thought mean and slothful in [himself]196-alfieri .

Some eighteen months after [their]1966-their first acquaintance , [Alfieri]196-alfieri announced to [the wife of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward]1967-the wife of charles edward that [he]196-alfieri had just happily settled a most important piece of business , the success of which was one of the most fortunate things of [his]196-alfieri life . [He]196-alfieri had made a gift of all [his]196-alfieri estates to [[his]196-alfieri sister]1968-his sister , reserving for [himself]196-alfieri only a very moderate yearly income ; [he]196-alfieri had reduced [himself]196-alfieri from comparative wealth to comparative poverty ; [he]196-alfieri had cut [himself]196-alfieri off from ever making a suitable marriage ; [he]196-alfieri had made [himself]196-alfieri [a pensioner of [[his]196-alfieri sister 's husband]1970-his sister 's husband]1969-a pensioner of his sister 's husband : but at this price [he]196-alfieri had bought independence - [he]196-alfieri was no longer the subject of [the King of [Sardinia]107-sardinia]1768-the king of sardinia , nor of [any sovereign or State]1972-any sovereign or state in [the world]573-the world .

The passion for political liberty , the abhorrence of any kind of despotism , however glorious or however paternal , had grown in [Alfieri]196-alfieri with every journey [he]196-alfieri had made through [France]35-france , [Spain]36-spain , [Germany]66-germany , [Russia]104-russia - with every sojourn in [England]13-england ; it had grown with every page of [Livy]338-livy and [Tacitus]339-tacitus , with every line of Dante and [Petrarch]340-petrarch which [he]196-alfieri had read ; it had grown with every word that [he]196-alfieri [himself]196-alfieri had written . [He]196-alfieri had determined to be [the poet who should make [men]711-men ashamed of being [slaves and ashamed of being tyrants]1976-slaves and ashamed of being tyrants]1974-the poet who should make men ashamed of being slaves and ashamed of being tyrants .
