[Alfieri]410-alfieri might hope for [a daughter - in - law]2800-a daughter - in - law in [the writer]2801-the writer , and for [grand - children]2802-grand - children through [her]2801-the writer . But [Madame Alfieri]409-alfieri did not understand ; imagining , perhaps , that [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany was alluding to some project of marriage of [[her]426-mme friend]2803-her friend [M. le Comte Alfieri]410-alfieri ; and the letter in which [the ill - treated wife]2804-the ill - treated wife 's aversion to [[her]2804-the ill - treated wife husband]790-her husband was first openly revealed appears to have acted as a thunder - clap , and to have , at least momentarily , put an end to all correspondence .

[The Countess of Albany]527-the countess of albany was mistaken in supposing that [Charles Edward]204-charles edward would die in the arms of [mere servants]2807-mere servants . The very year after [her]2804-the ill - treated wife own separation from [Alfieri]410-alfieri , [the Pretender]605-the pretender had called to [Florence]318-florence [the natural daughter born to [him]790-her husband by [Miss Walkenshaw]264-miss walkenshaw]2809-the natural daughter born to him by miss walkenshaw , and whom [he]790-her husband had left , apparently forgotten for twenty - five years , in [the convent at [Meaux]115-meaux]2810-the convent at meaux , where [[her]2804-the ill - treated wife mother]600-her mother had taken refuge from [his]790-her husband brutalities , even as [Louise d'Albany]233-louise had taken refuge from [them]2812-them in [the convent of the Bianchette]2203-the convent of the bianchette . Partly from a paternal feeling born of the unexpected solitude in which [[his]790-her husband wife]908-his wife 's flight had left [him]790-her husband ; partly , doubtless , from a desire to spite [the Countess]1995-the countess ; [he]790-her husband had solemnly , as [King of [England]13-england]648-king of england , legitimated [this daughter]2817-this daughter , and created [[her]2817-this daughter Duchess of [Albany]196-alfieri]2818-her duchess of albany : [he]790-her husband had made incredible efforts , abandoning drink , going into [the world]573-the world and keeping open [house]2820-house , to attach [this young woman]2821-this young woman to [him]790-her husband , and to treat [her]2821-this young woman as well as [he]790-her husband had treated [[his]790-her husband wife]908-his wife ill .

[[Charlotte]411-charlotte of [Albany]196-alfieri]2823-charlotte of albany , [a strong , lively , good - humoured , big creature , devoted to gaiety]2824-a strong , lively , good - humoured , big creature , devoted to gaiety , effectually reformed [[her]411-charlotte father]1180-her father in [his]790-her husband last years , and turned [him]790-her husband , from [the brute [he]790-her husband had been]2826-the brute he had been , to [a tolerably well - behaved old man]2827-a tolerably well - behaved old man . But [we]2828-we must not therefore conclude that [Charlotte]411-charlotte was [a better woman]2829-a better woman , or [a woman more desirous of doing [her]411-charlotte duty]2830-a woman more desirous of doing her duty , than [Louise d'Albany]233-louise . Between [the two]1241-the two there was an abyss : [Charlotte]411-charlotte had been sent for by [a man weary of solitude , smarting under the frightful punishment brought upon [his]790-her husband pride by the flight of [[his]790-her husband wife]908-his wife ; ready to do anything in order not to be alone and despised by [the world]573-the world]2832-a man weary of solitude , smarting under the frightful punishment brought upon his pride by the flight of his wife ; ready to do anything in order not to be alone and despised by the world ; [a man broken by illness and age]2835-a man broken by illness and age , weak , hysterical , incapable almost of [his]790-her husband former excesses ; and [Charlotte]411-charlotte was [a woman of thirty]2836-a woman of thirty , [she]411-charlotte was [a daughter]658-a daughter , [she]411-charlotte was free to go where [she]411-charlotte would to marry , and [[her]411-charlotte father]1180-her father could buy [her]411-charlotte presence only at the price of submission to [her]411-charlotte tastes and to [her]411-charlotte desires . How different had it not been with [Louise of Stolberg]233-louise : united to [this man]2278-this man twelve years before , [a mere child of nineteen]2840-a mere child of nineteen , given over to [him]790-her husband as [[his]790-her husband wife]908-his wife , [his]790-her husband chattel , [[his]790-her husband property]2842-his property , to torment and lock up as [he]790-her husband might torment and lock up [his]790-her husband dog or [his]790-her husband horse ; losing all influence over [him]790-her husband with every day which made [her]233-louise less of a novelty and diminished the chance of [an heir]992-an heir ; and sickened and alarmed more and more by the obstinate jealousy and drunkenness and brutality of [a man]1698-a man still in the vigour of [his]790-her husband odious passions . Still , the fact remains that while [Louise]233-louise d'Albany was secretly or openly making light of all social institutions , and living as [the mistress]2845-the mistress , almost [the wife]2846-the wife , of [Alfieri]410-alfieri ; this insignificant [Charlotte]411-charlotte , [this bastard of [a Miss Walkenshaw]264-miss walkenshaw]2847-this bastard of a miss walkenshaw , [this woman who had probably never had an enthusiasm , or an ideal , or a thought]2848-this woman who had probably never had an enthusiasm , or an ideal , or a thought , had succeeded in reclaiming whatever there remained of human in the degraded [Charles Edward]204-charles edward ; had succeeded in doing [the world]573-the world the service of laying out at least with decency and decorum this living corpse which had once contained the soul of [a hero]2850-a hero , so that [posterity]2191-posterity might look upon it without too much contempt and loathing , nay , almost , seeing it so quiet and seemingly peaceful , with compassion and reverence .

And when , at the beginning of February 1788 , [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri , in the full enjoyment of [her]2852-her love for [Alfieri]196-alfieri , and of the pleasures of [the most brilliant Parisian society]2853-the most brilliant parisian society]196-alfieri , received the news that on the last day of January [Charles Edward]204-charles edward had passed away peacefully in the arms of [the Duchess Charlotte]411-charlotte ; and that the drink - soiled broken body , from which [she]411-charlotte must so often have recoiled in disgust and terror , had been laid out , with the sad mock royalty of a gilt wooden sceptre and pinchbeck crown , in state in [the cathedral of [Frascati]121-frascati]2854-the cathedral of frascati ; when , [I]0-i say , the news reached [Paris]4-paris , [this woman , so confident of having been in the right]2855-this woman , so confident of having been in the right , and who had written so frankly that if [she]411-charlotte did not hate [[her]411-charlotte husband]790-her husband it was from mere Christian charity and the duty of forgiveness , felt [herself]411-charlotte smitten by an unexpected grief .

[Alfieri , who witnessed it with astonishment , and to whose cut - and - dry nature it]2857-alfieri , who witnessed it with astonishment , and to whose cut - and - dry nature it must have seemed highly mysterious , was , nevertheless , in a way overawed by this sudden emotion at the death of [the man who had made [both lovers so miserable]2859-both lovers so miserable]2858-the man who had made both lovers so miserable . [His]196-alfieri appreciation , difficult to so narrow a temper , of all that may move [our]2860-our sympathy in that , to [him]196-alfieri , unintelligible grief , is , [I]0-i think , one of the facts in [his]196-alfieri life which brings this strange , artificial , heroic , admirable , yet repulsive character , most within reach of [our]2860-our affection ; as that same grief , so unexpected by [herself]411-charlotte , at what was after all [her]411-charlotte final deliverance , is , together with the letter to [[Alfieri]196-alfieri 's mother]2738-alfieri 's mother , telling of [her]411-charlotte hatred to [Charles Edward]204-charles edward , and that exclamation in the hysterical love - letter at Siena - " O [God]272-god ! how this degrades the soul ! "[411-charlotte] - one of the things which persuade [us]2860-our that [this woman]1716-this woman , whom [we]2860-our shall see inconsistent , worldly , and cynical , did really possess at bottom what [[her]1716-this woman lover]2050-her lover called " [a most upright and sincere and incomparable soul]4016-a most upright and sincere and incomparable soul . "[2050-her lover]

" For the present , "[196-alfieri] wrote [Alfieri]196-alfieri to [[his]196-alfieri Sienese friends]2864-his sienese friends on the occasion of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward 's death , " nothing will be altered in [our]2860-our mode of life . "[196-alfieri] In other words , [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany and [[her]527-the countess of albany lover]2050-her lover , established publicly beneath the same roof in [Paris]4-paris , did not intend getting married . Whatever hopes may have filled [Mme . d'Albany]426-mme 's heart when , years before , [she]426-mme had hinted to [[Alfieri]196-alfieri 's mother]2738-alfieri 's mother that when certain circumstances changed , [the Alfieri family]2798-the alfieri family should be saved from extinction ; whatever ideas [Alfieri]196-alfieri had had in [his]196-alfieri mind when [he]196-alfieri prayed in a sonnet for the happy day when [he]196-alfieri might call [his]196-alfieri love holy ; whatever intention of repairing the injury done to social institutions , may at one time have mingled with [the lovers]2265-the lovers ' remorse and [the lovers]2265-the lovers ' temptations , - had now been completely forgotten . [We]2871-we have seen how , more than once , love , however self - restrained , had induced [Alfieri]196-alfieri to put aside all [his]196-alfieri Republican sternness and truthfulness , and to cringe before people whom [he]196-alfieri thoroughly despised ; [we]2871-we can not easily forget that ignominious stroking of [the Brutus poet]2872-the brutus poet 's cheek by [Pope Pius VI]382-pius vi . [We]2871-we shall now see how this peculiar sort of Roman and stoical virtue , cultivated by [Alfieri]196-alfieri in [himself]196-alfieri and in [his]196-alfieri beloved as the one admirable thing in [the world]573-the world , a strange exotic in this eighteenth - century baseness , had nevertheless withered in several of its branches , beaten by the wind of illegitimate passion , and dried up by the callousness of an immoral state of society : an exotic , or rather a precocious moral variety , come before its season , and bleached and warped like a winter flower .

[Alfieri]196-alfieri and [the Countess]1995-the countess did not get married , simply , [I]0-i think , because [they]2875-they did not care to get married ; because marriage would entail reorganisation of a mode of life which had somehow organised itself ; because it would give a common - place prose solution to what appeared a romantic and exceptional story ; and finally because it might necessitate certain losses in the way of money , of comfort , and of rank .

[One]1590-one sees throughout all [his]196-alfieri autobiography and letters that [Alfieri]196-alfieri drew a sharp distinction between love and marriage ; that [he]196-alfieri conceived marriage as the act of [a man who sets up [shop]2878-shop , so to say , in [[his]196-alfieri native place]2879-his native place , goes in for having [children]548-children , for being master in [[his]196-alfieri own house]2881-his own house , administering and increasing [[his]196-alfieri estates]1989-his estates , and generally devoting [himself]196-alfieri to the advancement of [[his]196-alfieri family]933-his family]2877-a man who sets up shop , so to say , in his native place , goes in for having children , for being master in his own house , administering and increasing his estates , and generally devoting himself to the advancement of his family . As such [Alfieri]196-alfieri , who was essentially [a routinist]2884-a routinist , respected and approved of marriage ; and anything different would have struck [his]196-alfieri martinet , rule and compass , mind , as ridiculous and contemptible . In giving up [his]196-alfieri fortune to [[his]196-alfieri sister]1968-his sister , [Alfieri]196-alfieri had deliberately cut [himself]196-alfieri off from the possibility of such a marriage ; moreover , putting aside the financial question , [his]196-alfieri notion of the liberty of [a writer , who must be able to speak freely against any government]2886-a writer , who must be able to speak freely against any government , was incompatible with [his]196-alfieri notion of [a father of [a family]969-a family]2887-a father of a family , settled in dignity in [[his]196-alfieri ancestral palace]2889-his ancestral palace ; and finally , [I]0-i feel perfectly persuaded that in the mind of [Alfieri]196-alfieri , which saw things only in sharpest black and white contrasts , there existed a still more complete incompatibility between [a woman like [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany , and [a wife such as [he]196-alfieri conceived [a wife]608-a wife]2892-a wife such as he conceived a wife]2890-a woman like the countess of albany , and a wife such as he conceived a wife : to marry [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany would be to degrade a poetical ideal into vulgar domesticity , and at the same time to frightfully depart from the normal type of matrimony , which required that [the man]2465-the man be [absolute master]2895-absolute master , and not afflicted with any sort of sentimental respect for [his]2465-the man better half .

According to [Alfieri]196-alfieri , there were two possibilities for [the ideal man]2896-the ideal man : a handsome and highly respectable marriage with [a girl twenty years [his]196-alfieri junior]2897-a girl twenty years his junior , fresh from [the convent]1018-the convent , provided with the right number of heraldic quarterings , [acres]2899-acres , diamonds , and domestic virtues , and who would bear [him]196-alfieri , in deep awe for [his]196-alfieri unapproachable superiority , [five or six robust children]2900-five or six robust children ; and a romantic connexion with [a married woman]2901-a married woman or [a widow]2902-a widow , [a woman all passion and intellect and aspiration]2903-a woman all passion and intellect and aspiration , with whom [he]196-alfieri should go through a course of mutual soul improvement , who should be the sharer of all [his]196-alfieri higher life , and whom [he]196-alfieri would diligently deck out as [a Beatrice]2904-a beatrice or [a Laura in the eyes of society]2905-a laura in the eyes of society .

[The Countess of Albany]196-alfieri did not fit into the first ideal ; nor , for the matter of that , did [Alfieri]196-alfieri , [poor , expatriated , mad for independence , engrossed in literature]2906-poor , expatriated , mad for independence , engrossed in literature , fit into it [himself]196-alfieri ; and both , as it happened , fitted in perfectly to the second ideal possibility . To get married with a view to turning into [domestic beings]2907-domestic beings , would be a failure , a trouble , an interruption , a desecration , and a bore ; to get married merely to go on as [they]2908-they were at present , would , in the eyes of [Alfieri]196-alfieri , have been a profanation of the poetry of [their]2908-they situation , a perfectly unnecessary piece of humbug .

Such were , doubtless , [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's views of the case . [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany , on the other hand , had evidently no vocation as [a housewife]2909-a housewife or [a mother]657-a mother ; marriage was full of disagreeable associations to [her]426-mme : [a husband]1863-a husband might beat [one]1590-one , and [a lover]1865-a lover might not . [She]426-mme , probably , also , guessed instinctively that to [Alfieri a Laura]345-alfieri must always be [a mere mistress]2914-a mere mistress , and [a wife]608-a wife must always be [a mere Griselda]2916-a mere griselda ; [she]426-mme knew [his]196-alfieri cut - and - dry views , [his]196-alfieri frightful power of carrying theory into practice ; [she]426-mme may have guessed that the most respectful of [lovers]1530-lovers would in [his]196-alfieri case make the most tyrannical of [husbands]1027-husbands . But while [Alfieri]345-alfieri doubtless brought [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany to share [his]196-alfieri abstract reasons , [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany probably brought [home]1063-home to [him]196-alfieri [her]426-mme own more practical ones . [Alfieri]345-alfieri , [we]2920-we must remember , had been [a man of excessive social vanity]2921-a man of excessive social vanity ; and much as [he]196-alfieri despised [mankind]1604-mankind , [he]196-alfieri certainly still liked to enjoy its admiring consideration . [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany , on the other hand , had been brought up in the full worldliness of [a canoness of Ste . Wandru]2923-a canoness of ste . wandru , and had grown accustomed to a certain amount of state and of luxury ; and these worldly tendencies , thrown into the background by the passion , the poetry which sprang up with the irresistible force of a pressed down spring during [her]426-mme married misery , had returned to [her]426-mme as years went on , and as passion cooled and poetry diminished . Now marriage would probably involve a great risk of a diminution of income , since [the Pope]650-the pope and [the Court of [France]35-france]2925-the court of france might easily refuse to support [[Charles Edward]204-charles edward 's widow]2926-charles edward 's widow once [she]2926-charles edward 's widow had ceased to be [a Stuart]943-a stuart ; and it must inevitably mean an end to a quasi - regal mode of life to which [the widow of [the Pretender]605-the pretender]2928-the widow of the pretender could lay claim , but [the wife of [a Piedmontese noble]2931-a piedmontese noble]2930-the wife of a piedmontese noble could not . It is one of the various meannesses , committed quite unconsciously by [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany , and apparently not censured by [the people of the eighteenth century]2932-the people of the eighteenth century , that , so far from being anxious to shake off all vestiges of [her]426-mme hateful married life , [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany , on the contrary , seemed determined to enjoy , so to speak , [her]426-mme money 's worth ; to get whatever advantages had been bought at the price of [her]426-mme marriage with [Charles Edward]204-charles edward . [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany enjoyed being [the widow of [a kind of sovereign]2935-a kind of sovereign]2934-the widow of a kind of sovereign . Rather easy - going and familiar by nature , [she]426-mme nevertheless assumed towards [strangers]2936-strangers a certain queenly haughtiness which frequently gave offence ; and [Sir Nathaniel Wraxall]412-sir nathaniel wraxall , who was introduced at [[her]426-mme house]1717-her house in 1788 , found , to [his]412-sir nathaniel wraxall surprise , that all the plate belonging to [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany was engraved with the royal arms of [England]13-england ; that [guests]2938-guests were conducted through [an ante - room in which stood a royal throne also emblazoned with the arms of [England]13-england]2939-an ante - room in which stood a royal throne also emblazoned with the arms of england ; nay , that [the servants]2082-the servants had orders to address [the lady of [the house]769-the house]2350-the lady of the house by the title of [a queen]673-a queen : a state of things whose institution by [a woman who affected [nobility of sentiment]2945-nobility of sentiment and who made no secret of [her]426-mme hatred of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward , whose toleration by a man who scorned [the world]573-the world and abhorred royalty]2944-a woman who affected nobility of sentiment and who made no secret of her hatred of charles edward , whose toleration by a man who scorned the world and abhorred royalty , is one of those strange anomalies which teach [us]2947-us the enormous advance in self - respect and self - consistency due to social and democratic progress , an improvement which separates in feeling even [the most mediocre and worldly men]2948-the most mediocre and worldly men and [women of to - day]2949-women of to - day from [the most high - minded and eccentric men and women of a century ago]2950-the most high - minded and eccentric men and women of a century ago . To marry [Alfieri]345-alfieri would mean , for [the Countess of Albany]196-alfieri , to risk part of [her]345-alfieri fortune and to relinquish [her]345-alfieri royal state , as well as to sink into [a mere humdrum housewife]2951-a mere humdrum housewife . Hence , in both parties concerned , a variety of reasons , contemptible in [our]2947-us eyes , excellent in [their]2952-they own , against legitimating [their]2952-they connection . And , on the other hand , no corresponding inducement . Why should [they]2952-they get married ? [The Countess]1995-the countess , going in state every Sunday to [a convent]594-a convent where [she]1995-the countess was received with royal honours , [Alfieri]196-alfieri writing to [[his]196-alfieri mother]1610-his mother that although [he]196-alfieri was not regular at confession , [he]196-alfieri was yet provided with [a most austere and worthy spiritual director in case of need]2956-a most austere and worthy spiritual director in case of need , [neither of [them]2952-they]2957-neither of them had the smallest belief in Christianity nor in its sacraments . To please whom should [they]2952-they marry , pray ? To please religion ? Why , [they]2952-they had none . To please [society]996-society ? Why , society , in [this Paris]2959-this paris of the year 1788 , at least [such aristocratic society as [they]2952-they cared to see]2960-such aristocratic society as they cared to see , consisted entirely either of [devoted couples of high - minded lovers]2961-devoted couples of high - minded lovers each with [a husband]1863-a husband or [wife somewhere in the background]2963-wife somewhere in the background , or of even more interesting triangular arrangements of [high - minded and devoted wife]2964-high - minded and devoted wife , [husband]1004-husband , and [lover]2966-lover , all living together on charming terms , and provided , in case of disagreement , each with a lettre de cachet which should lock the other up in [the Bastille]150-the bastille . [A Queen of [England]13-england]2967-a queen of england by right divine , keeping [open house]2968-open house in company with [a ferociously republican Piedmontese poet]2969-a ferociously republican piedmontese poet , was indeed a new and perhaps a questionable case ; but [the pre - revolutionary society of [Paris]4-paris]2970-the pre - revolutionary society of paris was too philosophical to be surprised at anything ; and , after very little hesitation , resorted to [the charming Albany - Alfieri hotel in [the Rue de Bourgoyne]2972-the rue de bourgoyne]2971-the charming albany - alfieri hotel in the rue de bourgoyne . Now , if [the well - born and amusing people in [Paris]4-paris]2973-the well - born and amusing people in paris did not insist upon [Alfieri]196-alfieri and [the Countess]1995-the countess getting married , why should [they]2973-the well - born and amusing people in paris go out of [their]2973-the well - born and amusing people in paris way to do so ? [We good people of the nineteenth century]2975-we good people of the nineteenth century should have liked [them]2973-the well - born and amusing people in paris the better ; but then , [you]2976-you see , it was the peculiarity of [the men]687-the men and [women of the eighteenth century]2978-women of the eighteenth century to be quite unable to conceive that [the men and women of the nineteenth century]2979-the men and women of the nineteenth century would be in the least different from [themselves]2979-the men and women of the nineteenth century .

CHAPTER XIV

BEFORE THE STORM .

[The well - born and amusing people of the end of the eighteenth and beginning of the nineteenth century]2980-the well - born and amusing people of the end of the eighteenth and beginning of the nineteenth century did not stickle at the question of the marriage . [They]2980-the well - born and amusing people of the end of the eighteenth and beginning of the nineteenth century flocked to [the hotel of the [Rue de Bourgoyne]153-the rue de bourgoyne]2981-the hotel of the rue de bourgoyne , attracted by the peculiar cosmopolitan charm , the very undeniable talent for [society]996-society , the extraordinary intellectual superiority of [[Mme .]426-mme]2983-mme . d'Albany ; attracted , also , by a certain easy - going and half - motherly kindliness which seems , to [all those who wanted sympathy , to have been quite irresistible]2984-all those who wanted sympathy , to have been quite irresistible . It was the moment of the great fermentation , when even trifling things and [trifling people]2985-trifling people seemed to boil and seethe with importance ; when [cold - hearted people]2986-cold - hearted people were suddenly full of tenderness and chivalry , [selfish people]2987-selfish people full of generosity , [prosaic people full of poetry]2988-prosaic people full of poetry , and [mediocre people full of genius]2989-mediocre people full of genius : the brief carnival - week of [the old world]2990-the old world , when [men]711-men and [women]547-women masqueraded in all manner of outlandish and antiquated thoughts and feelings , and enjoyed the excitement of dressing - up so much that [they]2980-the well - born and amusing people of the end of the eighteenth and beginning of the nineteenth century actually believed [themselves]2980-the well - born and amusing people of the end of the eighteenth and beginning of the nineteenth century for the moment to be what [they]2980-the well - born and amusing people of the end of the eighteenth and beginning of the nineteenth century pretended : it was the brief moment , grotesque and pathetic , when [the doomed classes of society , who were fatally going to be exterminated]2993-the doomed classes of society , who were fatally going to be exterminated for [their]2993-the doomed classes of society , who were fatally going to be exterminated long selfishness and indifference , enthusiastically caught up pick - axe and shovel and tore down the bricks of the edifice which was destined to fall and to crush [them]2980-the well - born and amusing people of the end of the eighteenth and beginning of the nineteenth century all beneath its ruins .

[All [these men]2995-these men and [women]547-women]2994-all these men and women , [their]2994-all these men and women deep in - born corruption momentarily transfigured by this enthusiasm for liberty , for equality , for sentiment , for austerity , which mingled oddly with [their]2994-all these men and women childish pleasure in all new things , in mesmerism , in [America]152-america , in electricity , in Montgolfier balloons , with [their]2994-all these men and women habitual pleasure in all [their]2994-all these men and women big and small futile and wicked pleasures of worldliness ; - [all these men]2997-all these men and [women]547-women , [these morituri]2999-these morituri delighted at the preparations , the scaffoldings , red clothes , black crape , torches and drums and bugles , for [their]2994-all these men and women own execution , all assembled at [that hotel of [the Rue de Bourgoyne]153-the rue de bourgoyne]3000-that hotel of the rue de bourgoyne .

[A brilliant crowd of]3001-a brilliant crowd of [ministers]3002-ministers and [diplomatists]1397-diplomatists , and [artists]3004-artists and [pamphleteers]3005-pamphleteers , and [wits and beautiful women]3006-wits and beautiful women ; perishable and perished things , out of which [we]3007-we must select one or two , either as [types of that which has perished , or as types of the imperishable]3008-types of that which has perished , or as types of the imperishable ; and the perished , [the amiable and beautiful women]3009-the amiable and beautiful women , [the amusing and brilliantly - improvising orators and philosophers of the half - hour]3010-the amusing and brilliantly - improvising orators and philosophers of the half - hour , are often that which , could [we]3007-we have chosen , [we]3007-we should have preserved . Most notable among [the women]3011-the women , [the young daughter of [Necker]384-goldoni]3012-the young daughter of necker , [the wife of [the Swedish ambassador]3014-the swedish ambassador]3013-the wife of the swedish ambassador , [Mme]426-mme . [la Baronne de Staël Holstein]413-de staël : [a rather mannish superb sort of creature , with shoulders and arms compensating for thick swarthy features ; eyes like volcanoes]3015-a rather mannish superb sort of creature , with shoulders and arms compensating for thick swarthy features ; eyes like volcanoes ; the laugh of [the most kind - hearted of children]3016-the most kind - hearted of children ; the stride , the attitude , with [her]3017-her hands for ever behind the back , of [an unceremonious man]3018-an unceremonious man ; [a young woman]2404-a young woman already accounted [a genius , and felt to be a moral force]3020-a genius , and felt to be a moral force . Next to [her]3017-her [a snub , drab - coloured Livonian , with northern eyes telling of future mysticism]3021-a snub , drab - coloured livonian , with northern eyes telling of future mysticism , that [Mme]426-mme . [de Krüdener]414-de krüdener , as yet noted only for the droll contrast of [her]3017-her enthusiasm for [St. Pierre]384-goldoni and the simplicity of nature with [her]3017-her quarterly bills of twenty thousand francs from [Mdlle]415-mdlle . [Bertin]416-bertin , [[the Queen]3022-the queen 's milliner]3023-the queen 's milliner ; but later to be famous for [her]3017-her literary and religious vagaries , [her]3017-her influence on [Mme]426-mme . [de Staël]413-de staël , [her]3017-her strange influence on [[Alexander]405-duke alexander of [Russia]104-russia]3024-alexander of russia . Near [her]3017-her , doubtless , that fascinating [Suard]417-suard , in [the convent of [whose sister [Mme]426-mme . [de Krüdener]414-de krüdener]3026-whose sister mme . de krüdener]3025-the convent of whose sister mme . de krüdener was wo nt to spend a month in religious exercises , thanking [God]272-god , at the foot of the altar , for giving [her]3017-her [a sister like [Mdlle]415-mdlle]3027-a sister like mdlle . [Suard]417-suard , and [a lover like [Suard]417-suard [himself]417-suard]3028-a lover like suard himself . As yet but little noticed , except as [the pet friend]3029-the pet friend , [the " younger sister "[3029-the pet friend] of [Mme]426-mme]3030-the " younger sister " of mme . d'Albany , a Mme . [de Flahault]418-de flahault , later married to [the Portuguese Souza]419-the portuguese souza ; [a simple - natured little woman]3031-a simple - natured little woman , adoring [[her]3017-her children]1612-her children and the roses in [[her]3017-her garden]3033-her garden , and who , if [I]0-i may judge by the letters which , many , many years later , [she]3017-her addressed to [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany , would be [the woman of all those one would rather resuscitate for [a friend]3924-a friend]3034-the woman of all those one would rather resuscitate for a friend , leaving [Mmes]420-mmes . [de Staël]413-de staël and [de Krüdener]414-de krüdener quiet in [their]3036-their coffins . Further on , [the delicate and charming [Pauline de Beaumont]421-pauline de beaumont , who was to be [the Egeria of Joubert]422-the egeria of joubert and [the tenderly - beloved friend of [Châteaubriand]423-châteaubriand]3038-the tenderly - beloved friend of châteaubriand]3037-the delicate and charming pauline de beaumont , who was to be the egeria of joubert and the tenderly - beloved friend of châteaubriand ; and [a host of [women notable in those days for wit or heart or looks , wherewith to make a new Ballade of Dead Ladies]3040-women notable in those days for wit or heart or looks , wherewith to make a new ballade of dead ladies , much sadder than the one of [Villon]424-villon]3039-a host of women notable in those days for wit or heart or looks , wherewith to make a new ballade of dead ladies , much sadder than the one of villon : " But where are the snows of yester - year ? "[424-villon]

Round about [these ladies]2364-these ladies an even greater number of [men of what were , or passed for , eminent qualities]3042-men of what were , or passed for , eminent qualities ; [political for the most part , or busied with the new science of economy]3043-political for the most part , or busied with the new science of economy , like [the Trudaines]425-the trudaines ; and most notable among [them]2364-these ladies , as [the typical victim of genius of the Reign of Terror]3044-the typical victim of genius of the reign of terror , [poor André Chénier]426-mme , [his]3044-the typical victim of genius of the reign of terror exquisite imitations of [Theocritus]427-theocritus still waiting to be sorted and annotated in [prison]3045-prison ; and [the typical blood - maniac of genius]3046-the typical blood - maniac of genius , [the painter [David]428-david , who was to startle [Mme]426-mme . [d'Albany 's guests]3048-d'albany 's guests]3047-the painter david , who was to startle mme . d'albany 's guests , soon after the 10th August , by wishing that [the Fishwives]3049-the fishwives had stuck [Marie Antoinette]429-marie antoinette 's head without more ado upon a pike . Imagine all [these people]3050-these people assembled in order to hear [M. de Beaumarchais]430-m. de beaumarchais , in the full glory of [his]430-m. de beaumarchais millions and [[his]430-m. de beaumarchais wonderful garden]3051-his wonderful garden , give a first reading of [his]430-m. de beaumarchais Mère Coupable , after inviting [them]3050-these people to prepare [themselves]3050-these people to weep which was easy in those days of soft hearts " plein canal . "[431-m. de condorcet] Or else listening to the cold and solemn [M. de Condorcet]431-m. de condorcet , prophesying the time when science shall have abolished suffering and shall abolish death ; little dreaming of those days of wandering without food , of those nights in [the quarries of [Montrouge]154-montrouge]3052-the quarries of montrouge , of that little bottle of poison , the only thing that science could give to abolish [his]430-m. de beaumarchais suffering .

To [all these great and illustrious people [the Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany - [I]0-i had almost said [the Queen of [England]13-england]561-the queen of england]3053-all these great and illustrious people the countess of albany - i had almost said the queen of england - introduced [her]527-the countess of albany " incomparable friend "[527-the countess of albany] style then in vogue [Count Vittorio Alfieri]196-alfieri ; and all of [them]3050-these people doubtless took a great interest in [him]196-alfieri as [[her]527-the countess of albany lover]2050-her lover , and a little interest in [him]196-alfieri as [the great poet of [Italy]3-italy]3057-the great poet of italy ; not certainly without wondering - [amiable people]3058-amiable people as [they]3058-amiable people were , and persuaded that [France]35-france and [Paris]4-paris alone existed - that Mme . [d'Albany]3059-d'albany should find anything to love in [this particularly rude and disagreeable man]3060-this particularly rude and disagreeable man , and that [[a country]2007-a country like [Italy]3-italy]3062-a country like italy should have the impudence to set up [a poet of its own]3063-a poet of its own . [The Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany , made to be [a leader of intellectual society]3065-a leader of intellectual society , was happy ; but [Alfieri]196-alfieri was not . Ever since [his]196-alfieri childhood , when [a French dancing - master]3066-a french dancing - master had vainly tried to unstiffen [his]196-alfieri rigid person , [he]196-alfieri had mortally hated [the French nation]3067-the french nation ; ever since [his]196-alfieri first boyish travels [he]196-alfieri had loathed [Paris]4-paris as [the sewer]3068-the sewer , the cloaca maxima the expression is [his]196-alfieri own of [the world]573-the world ; [his]196-alfieri whole life had been a struggle with the French manners , the French language , which had permeated [Piedmont]100-piedmont ; one of the chief merits of the new drama [he]196-alfieri had conceived was in [his]196-alfieri own eyes to sweep [Corneille]376-corneille , [Racine]375-racine , and particularly [Voltaire]388-voltaire , [his]196-alfieri arch - aversion [Voltaire]388-voltaire , off the stage .

[Alfieri]196-alfieri , with [his]196-alfieri faults and [his]196-alfieri virtues , was specially constructed , if [I]0-i may use the expression , to ignore all the good points , and to feel with hysterical sensitiveness all the bad ones , of [the French nation]3067-the french nation ; and more especially of [the French nation of the pre - revolutionary and revolutionary era]3071-the french nation of the pre - revolutionary and revolutionary era . [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's reality and [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's ideal were austerity , inflexibility , pride and contemptuousness of character , coldness , roughness , decision of manner , curtness , reticence , and absolute truthfulness of speech ; above all , no consideration for [other folks]3072-other folks ' likings and dislikings , no mercy for [their]3072-other folks foibles . [His]196-alfieri ideal , even more so than the ideal of [other idealising minds]3073-other idealising minds , was the mere outcome of [himself]196-alfieri ; it contained [his]196-alfieri faults as well as [his]196-alfieri virtues . Now all that fell short of , or went beyond , [his]196-alfieri ideal - that is to say , [himself]196-alfieri - was abomination in [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's eyes . Consequently [France]35-france and [the French]432-the french , [all the nobility]3074-all the nobility , the wit , the sentiment , the warm - heartedness , the enthusiasm , the wide - mindedness , the childishness , the frivolity , the instability , the disrespectfulness , the sentimentality , the high falutinism , the superficiality , the looseness of principle , everything that made up the greatness and littleness of [the France]35-france of the end of last century , everything which will make up the greatness and littleness of [France]35-france , the glories and weaknesses which [the world]573-the world must love , to the end of time ; all these things were abhorrent to [Alfieri]196-alfieri ; and [Alfieri]196-alfieri , when once [he]196-alfieri disliked [a person]2443-a person or a thing , justly or unjustly , could only increase but never diminish [his]196-alfieri dislike . Let [us]3077-us look at this matter , which is instructive to [all persons whose nobility of character runs to injustice]3078-all persons whose nobility of character runs to injustice , a little closer ; it will help [us]3077-us to understand the Misogallo , the extraordinary apostasy which , quite unconsciously , [Alfieri]196-alfieri was later to commit towards the principle of freedom . [Alfieri]196-alfieri , intensely Italian , if mediæval and peasant [Italy]3-italy may give [us]3077-us the Italian type , in a certain silent or rather inarticulate violence of temper - violence which roars and yells and stabs and strangles , but which never talks , and much less argues - could not endure the particular sort of excitement which surrounded [him]196-alfieri in [France]35-france ; excitement mainly cerebral , heroism or villainy resulting , but only as the outcome of argument and definition of principle and of that mixture of logic and rhetoric called by [the French des mots]3079-the french des mots . [Alfieri]196-alfieri was not a reasoning mind , [he]196-alfieri was not [an eloquent man]3080-an eloquent man ; above all , [he]196-alfieri was not [a witty man]3081-a witty man ; [his]196-alfieri satirical efforts are so many blows upon [an opponent]3082-an opponent 's head ; they are almost physical brutalities ; there is nothing clever or funny about them . In such a society as [this Parisian society of the years ' 87]3083-this parisian society of the years ' 87 , ' 88 , ' 89 , ' 90 , [he]196-alfieri must have been at a continual disadvantage ; and at a disadvantage which [he]196-alfieri felt keenly , but which [he]196-alfieri felt , also , that any remarkable piece of Alfierism which would have moved [Italy]3-italy to admiration , such as glaring , or stalking off in silence , or punching [a man]1698-a man 's head , could only increase . To feel [himself]196-alfieri at a disadvantage on account of [his]196-alfieri very virtues , and with [people whom those virtues did not impress]3085-people whom those virtues did not impress , must have been most intolerable to [a man as vain and self - conscious]3086-a man as vain and self - conscious as [Alfieri]196-alfieri , and to this was added the sense that , from mere ignorance of the language the language whose nobility , as contrasted with [the " low , plebeian , nasal disgustingness "[196-alfieri] of French]3087-the " low , plebeian , nasal disgustingness " of french , [he]196-alfieri so often descanted on in which [he]196-alfieri wrote , it was quite impossible for [these people]3050-these people to be reduced to [their]3050-these people right place and right mind by the crushing superiority of [his]196-alfieri dramatic genius . [He]196-alfieri , who hungered and thirsted for glory , what glory could [he]196-alfieri hope for among [all these monkeys of Frenchmen , jabbering and gesticulating about [their]3050-these people States - General , [[their]3050-these people Montgolfier , [their]3050-these people St. Pierre , [their]3050-these people Condorcet , [their]3050-these people [Parny]384-goldoni , [their]3050-these people Necker , who had not even the decent feeling to know Italian , and who bowed and smiled and doubtless mixed [him]196-alfieri up with [Metastasio]384-goldoni and [Goldoni]384-goldoni when introduced by [the Countess]1995-the countess to so odd a piece of provincialism as [an Italian poet]3092-an italian poet]3090-their montgolfier , their st. pierre , their condorcet , their parny , their necker , who had not even the decent feeling to know italian , and who bowed and smiled and doubtless mixed him up with metastasio and goldoni when introduced by the countess to so odd a piece of provincialism as an italian poet]3089-all these monkeys of frenchmen , jabbering and gesticulating about their states - general , their montgolfier , their st. pierre , their condorcet , their parny , their necker , who had not even the decent feeling to know italian , and who bowed and smiled and doubtless mixed him up with metastasio and goldoni when introduced by the countess to so odd a piece of provincialism as an italian poet . " Does [Monsieur]4017-monsieur write comedies or tragedies ? "[3092-an italian poet] One fancies [one]1590-one can hear the politely indifferent question put with a charming smile by some powdered and embroidered French wit to [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany in [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's hearing ; nay , to [Alfieri]196-alfieri [himself]196-alfieri .

Mixed with such meaner , though unconscious motives for dissatisfaction , must have been the sense , intolerable to [a man like [Alfieri]196-alfieri]1951-a man like alfieri , of the horrid and grotesque jumble of good and bad , of real and false , not merely in the revolutionary movement itself , but in [all these men of [the ancien régime who initiated it]3096-the ancien régime who initiated it]3095-all these men of the ancien régime who initiated it . [Alfieri]196-alfieri conceived liberty from the purely antique , or , if [you]3097-you prefer , pseudo - antique , point of view ; it was to [him]196-alfieri the final cause of [the world]573-the world ; the aim of all struggles ; to be free was the one and only desideratum , to be master of one 's own thoughts , actions , and words , merely for the sake of such mastery . The practical advantages of liberty entirely escaped [him]196-alfieri , as did the practical disadvantages of tyranny ; nay , one can almost imagine that had liberty involved absolute misery for [all men]2101-all men , and tyranny absolute happiness , [Alfieri]196-alfieri would have chosen liberty . To [this pseudo - Roman and intensely patrician stoic]3100-this pseudo - roman and intensely patrician stoic , who had never known privation or injustice towards [himself]196-alfieri , and scarcely noticed it towards [others]1434-others , [the humanitarian , the philanthropic movement , characteristic of the eighteenth century]3102-the humanitarian , the philanthropic movement , characteristic of the eighteenth century , and which was the strong impulse of the revolution , was absolutely incomprehensible . [Alfieri]196-alfieri was , in the sense of [certain ancients]3103-certain ancients , [a hard - hearted man , indifferent , blind and deaf to suffering]3104-a hard - hearted man , indifferent , blind and deaf to suffering . That [a man of education and mind]3105-a man of education and mind , [a gentleman]3106-a gentleman , should have to sweep the ground with [his]3105-a man of education and mind hat on the passage of [another man]1854-another man , because that other happened to wear a ribbon and a star ; that [he]3105-a man of education and mind should be liable to exile , to imprisonment , for a truthful statement of [his]3105-a man of education and mind opinion : these were to [Alfieri]196-alfieri the insupportable things of tyranny . But that [a man in wooden shoes and a torn smock frock]3108-a man in wooden shoes and a torn smock frock , sleeping between the pigs and the cows on the damp clay floor , eating bread mainly composed of straw , should have all the profits of [his]3108-a man in wooden shoes and a torn smock frock hard labour taken from [him]3108-a man in wooden shoes and a torn smock frock in taxes , while [another man]1854-another man , [a splendid gentleman covered over with gold]3110-a splendid gentleman covered over with gold , riding over acres of [[his]3108-a man in wooden shoes and a torn smock frock land]3111-his land with [his]3108-a man in wooden shoes and a torn smock frock hounds , or [a fat priest dressed in silk , snoozing over [his]3112-a fat priest dressed in silk , snoozing over his lucullus dinner Lucullus dinner]3112-a fat priest dressed in silk , snoozing over his lucullus dinner , should be exempt from taxation and empowered to starve , rob , beat , or hang [the peasant]3113-the peasant : such a thing as this did not fall within the range of [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's feelings . To [his]196-alfieri mind , for ever wrapped in [an intellectual toga]3114-an intellectual toga , there was no tragedy in mere misery ; there was no injustice in mere cruelty , or rather misery , cruelty , nay , all their allied evils , ignorance , brutality , sickness , superstition , vice , were unknown to [him]196-alfieri . Hence , as [I]0-i have said , all the philanthropic side of [the revolutionary movement]3115-the revolutionary movement was lost to [him]196-alfieri ; just as the defence of [Labarre]433-labarre , the vindication of [Calas]434-calas , never disturbed the current of [his]196-alfieri contempt for [Voltaire]388-voltaire . So also the abolition of privileges , the secularisation of church property , the equalisation of legal punishment , the abrogation of barbarous laws , the liberation of [slaves]3116-slaves ; all these things , which stirred [even the most corrupt and apathetic minds of the late eighteenth century]3117-even the most corrupt and apathetic minds of the late eighteenth century , seemed merely so much declamation to [Alfieri]196-alfieri . To [him]196-alfieri , who could conceive no virtues beyond independent truthfulness , such things were mere sentimental trash , mere hypocritical nonsense beneath which [base men]3118-base men hid [their]3118-base men baseness . And the baseness , unhappily , was there : baseness of absolute corruption , or of scandalous levity , even in the noblest . To [Alfieri]196-alfieri , [a man like [Beaumarchais]430-m. de beaumarchais]3119-a man like beaumarchais , for all [his]3119-a man like beaumarchais quick philanthropy , [his]3119-a man like beaumarchais audacious outspokenness , must have seemed base , with [his]3119-a man like beaumarchais background of money - jobbing , of dirty diplomatic work , of legal squabbles . How much more such a man as [Mirabeau]435-mirabeau , with [his]435-mirabeau heroic resolution , [his]435-mirabeau heroic kindliness , [his]435-mirabeau whole Titan nature , carous , eaten into by a hundred mean vices . That [Mirabeau]435-mirabeau should have gained [his]435-mirabeau bread writing libels and obscene novels , meant to [Alfieri]196-alfieri not that [a man born in corruption and tainted thereby]3120-a man born in corruption and tainted thereby had , by the force of [his]196-alfieri genius , by the force of the great humanitarian movement , raised [himself]196-alfieri as morally high as [he]196-alfieri had hitherto grovelled morally low ; it merely meant that the immaculate name of [hero]3121-hero was degraded by [a foul writer]3122-a foul writer .

From [such figures as these Alfieri]3123-such figures as these alfieri turned away in indignant disgust . [The great movement of the eighteenth century]3124-the great movement of the eighteenth century seemed to [him]196-alfieri a mere stirring and splashing in [a noisome pool]3125-a noisome pool , in that cloaca maxima , as [he]196-alfieri had called it .

Already before settling in [Paris]4-paris in 1787 , [he]196-alfieri had written to [[his]196-alfieri Sienese friends]2864-his sienese friends that , were it not for the necessity of attending to the printing of [his]196-alfieri works to print which permission would not be obtainable in [Italy]3-italy , [he]196-alfieri would rather have established [himself]196-alfieri at [Prats]156-prats , at [Colle]157-colle , at [Buonconvento]158-buonconvento , at [any little town of two thousand inhabitants near [Florence]9-florence or [Siena]6-siena]3127-any little town of two thousand inhabitants near florence or siena . Surrounded by , in daily contact with , some of [the noblest minds of the century , nay , of any century]3128-the noblest minds of the century , nay , of any century , by people like [Mme . de Staël , André Chénier , Condorcet]426-mme , [Mirabeau]435-mirabeau , [Alfieri]196-alfieri could write , with a sort of bitter pleasure at [his]196-alfieri own narrow - mindedness : " Now [I]196-alfieri am among [a million of [men]711-men]4018-a million of men , and not one of [them]4018-a million of men that is worth [Gori]404-gori 's little finger . "[196-alfieri]

[I]0-i am almost prepared to say that [Alfieri]196-alfieri really felt as if living in [Paris]4-paris , among [such people]3129-such people and at such a moment , was a sort of saintly sacrifice , the crowning heroism of [his]196-alfieri life , which [he]196-alfieri made in order to print [his]196-alfieri books ; that [he]196-alfieri endured the contact of [this plague - stricken city]3130-this plague - stricken city , merely because [he]196-alfieri knew that unless [he]196-alfieri corrected a certain number of manuscript pages , and revised a certain number of proof - sheets , [the world]573-the world would be defrauded of the great and sovereign antidote to all such baseness as this in the shape of [his]196-alfieri own complete works .

Writing to [[his]196-alfieri mother]1610-his mother towards the end of the year 1788 , [he]196-alfieri mentions contemptuously the excitement and enthusiasm created by the approaching election of [the States - General]3133-the states - general , and adds calmly : " But all these sort of things interest [me]196-alfieri very little ; and [I]196-alfieri give [my]196-alfieri attention only to the correction of [my]196-alfieri proofs , a piece of work with which [I]196-alfieri am pretty well half through . "[196-alfieri]

CHAPTER XV .

[ENGLAND]13-england .

The contradictions in complex and self - contradictory characters like those of [the Frenchmen of the early revolution]3134-the frenchmen of the early revolution can be easily explained , and , say what [we]3135-we will , must be easily pardoned : rich natures , creatures of impulse , intensely sensitive to external influences , [we]3135-we feel that it is to the very richness of nature , the warmth of impulse , the susceptibility to influence , that [we]3135-we owe not merely [these men]2995-these men 's virtues but [their]2995-these men vices . But the contradictions of [the self - righteous]3137-the self - righteous are an afflicting spectacle , over which [we]3135-we would fain draw the veil : there is no room in a narrow nature for any flagrant violation of its own ideals to be stuffed away unnoticed in a corner . And now [we]3135-we come to one of the strangest self - contradictions in the history of [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany , that is to say , of [[her]426-mme lord]3138-her lord and master [Alfieri]196-alfieri .

The revision and printing of [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's works had been brought to an end ; but neither [he]196-alfieri nor [the Countess]1995-the countess seems to have contemplated a return to [Italy]3-italy . The fact was that [they]3140-they were both of [them]3140-they retained by money matters . A proportion of [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany 's income consisted in the pension which [she]426-mme received from [the French Court]923-the french court ; and the greater part of [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's income consisted in certain moneys made over to [him]196-alfieri by [[his]196-alfieri sister]1968-his sister as the capital of [his]196-alfieri life pension , and which [he]196-alfieri had invested in French funds .

By the year 1791 , the French Court and the French funds had got to be very shaky ; and those who depended upon [them]3143-them did not dare go to any distance , lest on [their]3143-them return [they]3143-them should find nothing to claim , or [no one to claim from]3144-no one to claim from . Hence the necessity for [Alfieri]196-alfieri and [the Countess]1995-the countess to remain in [France]35-france , or , at least , hover about near [it]35-france .

Now , whether the unsettled state of French affairs suggested to [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany , and through [her]426-mme to [Alfieri]196-alfieri , that it would be wise to see what sort of [home]1063-home , nay , perhaps , what sort of pecuniary assistance , might be found elsewhere , [I]0-i can not tell ; but this much is certain , that on the 19th May , 1791 , [Horace Walpole]257-walpole wrote as follows to [Miss Barry]436-miss barry : -

" [The Countess of Albany]527-the countess of albany is not only in [England]13-england , in [London]44-london , but at this very moment , [I]436-miss barry believe , in [the palace of St. James]4021-the palace of st. james ; not restored by as rapid a revolution as [the French]432-the french , but , as was observed at supper at [Lady Mount Edgecumbe 's]159-lady mount edgecumbe 's , by that topsy - turvihood that characterises the present age . Within these two days [the Pope]650-the pope has been burnt at [Paris]4-paris ; Mme . [du Barry]436-miss barry , [mistress of [Louis Quinze]437-louis quinze]4023-mistress of louis quinze , has dined with [the Lord Mayor of]4024-the lord mayor of [London]44-london ; and [[the Pretender]605-the pretender 's widow]4026-the pretender 's widow is presented to [the Queen of [Great Britain]40-great britain]4027-the queen of great britain . "[436-miss barry]

That [we]3147-we should have to learn so striking an episode of the journey to [England]13-england from the letters of [a total stranger , who noticed it as a mere piece of gossip]3148-a total stranger , who noticed it as a mere piece of gossip , while the memoirs of [Alfieri]196-alfieri , who accompanied [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany to [England]13-england , are perfectly silent on the subject , is , to say the least of it , a suspicious circumstance .

As [he]196-alfieri grew old , [Alfieri]196-alfieri seems to have lost that power , nay that irresistible desire , of speaking the truth and the whole truth which made [him]196-alfieri record with burning shame the caress of [Pius VI]382-pius vi . Perhaps , on the other hand , [Alfieri]196-alfieri , who , after all , was but a sorry mixture of [an ancient Roman]3149-an ancient roman and [a man of the eighteenth century]3150-a man of the eighteenth century , thought that a certain amount of baseness and dirt - eating , quite degrading in [a man]1698-a man , might be permitted to [a woman]689-a woman , even to [the lady of [his]196-alfieri thoughts]3153-the lady of his thoughts . And still [I]0-i can not help thinking that [Alfieri]196-alfieri , who could certainly , with [his]196-alfieri strong will , have prevented [the Countess]1995-the countess from demeaning [herself]1995-the countess , and in so far demeaning also [his]196-alfieri love for [her]1995-the countess , quietly abetted this step , and then as quietly consigned it to oblivion .

But oblivion did not depend upon registration , or non - registration , in [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's memoirs . The letters of [Walpole]257-walpole , the memoirs of [Hannah More]438-hannah more , the political correspondence collected by [Lord Stanhope]439-lord stanhope , furnish abundant detail of this affair . [The Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany was introduced by [[her]527-the countess of albany relation]3156-her relation , or connexion , [the young Countess of [Aylesbury]160-aylesbury]3157-the young countess of aylesbury , and announced by [her]527-the countess of albany maiden name of [Princess of [Stolberg]15-stolberg]596-princess of stolberg . [[Horace Walpole]257-walpole 's informant]3159-horace walpole 's informant , who stood close by , told [him]196-alfieri that [she]527-the countess of albany was " well - dressed , and not at all embarrassed . "[257-walpole] [George III]301-george iii . and [[his]196-alfieri sons]3160-his sons talked a good deal to [her]527-the countess of albany , about [her]527-the countess of albany passage , [her]527-the countess of albany stay in [England]13-england , and similar matters ; but [the princesses]3161-the princesses none of [them]3161-the princesses said a word ; and [we]3162-we hear that [Queen Charlotte]440-queen charlotte " looked at [her]527-the countess of albany earnestly . "[3163-the strait - laced wife of george iii] [The strait - laced wife of [George III]301-george iii]3163-the strait - laced wife of george iii . had probably consented to receive [[the Pretender]605-the pretender 's widow]4026-the pretender 's widow , only because this ceremony was a sort of second burial of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward , a burial of all the claims , the pride of [the Stuarts]241-the stuarts ; but [she]527-the countess of albany felt presumably no great cordiality towards [a woman who had run away from [[her]527-the countess of albany husband]790-her husband , who was travelling in [England]13-england with [[her]527-the countess of albany lover]2050-her lover ; and who , while affecting royal state in [[her]527-the countess of albany own house]3169-her own house , could crave the honour of being received by [the family of [the usurper]3171-the usurper]3170-the family of the usurper]3166-a woman who had run away from her husband , who was travelling in england with her lover ; and who , while affecting royal state in her own house , could crave the honour of being received by the family of the usurper .

[Mme . d'Albany]426-mme was not abashed : [she]426-mme seems to have made up [her]426-mme mind to get all [she]426-mme could out of royal friendliness . [She]426-mme accepted a seat in [the King]1321-the king 's box at [the opera]3173-the opera ; nay , [she]426-mme accepted a seat at the foot of the throne " the throne [she]426-mme might once have expected to mount , "[438-hannah more] remarks [Hannah More]438-hannah more , on the occasion of [the King]1321-the king 's speech in [the House of Lords]3175-the house of lords . It was the 10th of June , the birthday of [Prince Charlie]204-charles edward ; and [the woman who sat there so unconcernedly , kept a throne with the British arms in [[her]426-mme ante - room]3177-her ante - room]3176-the woman who sat there so unconcernedly , kept a throne with the british arms in her ante - room , and made [[her]426-mme servants]3178-her servants address [her]426-mme as [a Queen]673-a queen !

What were [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's feelings when [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany came [home]1063-home in [[her]426-mme Court toilette]3181-her court toilette , and told [him]196-alfieri of all these fine doings ? The more [we]3182-we try to conceive certain things , the more inconceivable they become : it is like straining to see what may be hidden at the bottom of a very deep well . In the case of [Alfieri]196-alfieri , [I]0-i think [we]3182-we may add that the well was empty . Since [his]196-alfieri illness at [Colmar]146-colmar , [he]196-alfieri had aged in the most extraordinary way : the process of dessication and ossification of [his]196-alfieri moral nerves and muscles , which , as [I]0-i have said , was the form that premature decrepitude took in [this abnormal man]3183-this abnormal man , had begun . The creative power was extinct in [him]196-alfieri , both as regards [his]196-alfieri works and [himself]196-alfieri : there was no possibility of anything new , of any response of this wooden nature to new circumstances . [He]196-alfieri had attained to the age of forty - two without any particular feelings such as could fit into this present case , and the result was that [he]196-alfieri probably had no feelings . [The Countess of [Albany]196-alfieri]527-the countess of albany was [the ideal woman [he]196-alfieri had enshrined [her]527-the countess of albany as such ages ago]3185-the ideal woman he had enshrined her as such ages ago , and [an ideal woman]3186-an ideal woman could not change , could not commit an impropriety , least of all in [his]196-alfieri eyes . If [she]527-the countess of albany had condescended to ridiculous meanness in order to secure for [herself]527-the countess of albany an opening in English society , a subsidy from [the English Government]913-the english government apparently already suggested at that time , but granted only many years later in case of a general break - up of [French]432-the french things ; if [she]527-the countess of albany had done this , it was no concern of [Alfieri]196-alfieri : Mme . d'Albany had been patented as [the ideal woman]3188-the ideal woman . As to [him]196-alfieri , why should [he]196-alfieri condescend to think about state receptions , galas , pensions , [kings]675-kings and [queens]676-queens , and similar low things ? [He]196-alfieri had put such vanities behind [him]196-alfieri long ago .

[Alfieri]196-alfieri and [the Countess]1995-the countess made a tour through [England]13-england , and projected a tour through [Scotland]37-scotland . Whether the climate , the manners , the aspect of [England]13-england and [[its]13-england inhabitants]3192-its inhabitants really disappointed the perhaps ideal notions [she]527-the countess of albany had formed ; or whether , perhaps , [she]527-the countess of albany was a little bit put out of sorts by no pension being granted , and by a possible coldness of [British matrons]3193-british matrons towards [a widow travelling about with [an Italian poet]3092-an italian poet]3194-a widow travelling about with an italian poet , it is not for [me]0-i to decide . But [her]527-the countess of albany impressions of [England]13-england , as recorded in a note - book now at [the Musée Fabre at [Montpellier]5-montpellier]3196-the musée fabre at montpellier , are certainly not those of [a person who has received a good welcome]3197-a person who has received a good welcome :

" Although [I]527-the countess of albany knew , "[527-the countess of albany] [she]527-the countess of albany says , repeating the stale platitudes or perhaps the true impressions ? of [all foreigners]3198-all foreigners , " that [the English]337-lamartine were melancholy , [I]527-the countess of albany had not imagined that life in [[their]3198-all foreigners capital]4028-their capital would be so to the point which [I]527-the countess of albany experienced it . No sort of society , and a quantity of [crowds]4029-crowds ... As [they]3198-all foreigners spend nine months in [the country]1454-the country - [the family]4031-the family alone , or with [only a very few friends]4032-only a very few friends - [they]3198-all foreigners like , when [they]3198-all foreigners come to [town]4033-town , to throw [themselves]3198-all foreigners into the vortex . [Women]547-women are never at [home]1063-home . The whole early part of the day , which begins at two for , going to bed at four in the morning , [they]3198-all foreigners rise only at mid - day , is spent in visits and exercise , for the English require , and [their]3198-all foreigners climate absolutely necessitates , a great deal of exercise . The coal smoke , the constant absence of sunshine , the heavy food and drink , make movement a necessity to [them]3198-all foreigners .... If [England]13-england had an oppressive Government , [this country]4036-this country and [[its]4036-this country inhabitants]3192-its inhabitants would be the lowest in [the universe]4038-the universe : a bad climate , bad soil , hence no sort of taste ; it is only the excellence of the political constitution which renders it inhabitable . [The nation]4039-the nation is melancholy , without any imagination , even without wit ; the dominant characteristic is a desire for money . "[527-the countess of albany]

The same note as that even of [such a man as [Taine]441-taine]3199-such a man as taine . The almost morbid love of beauty which [a civilisation , whose outward expression are the lines and lines of black boxes]3200-a civilisation , whose outward expression are the lines and lines of black boxes , with slits for doors and windows of [Bloomsbury]162-bloomsbury , produced in [men]711-men like [Coleridge]442-coleridge , [Blake]443-blake , and [Turner]444-turner , naturally escaped [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany ; but the second great rebellion of imagination and love of beauty , the rebellion led by [Madox Brown]445-madox brown and [Morris]446-morris , and [Rossetti]447-rossetti and [Burne Jones]448-burne jones , escaped [Taine]441-taine . But of all the things which most offended [this quasi - Queen of [England]13-england]3202-this quasi - queen of england in [our]3203-our civilisation , the social arrangements did so most of all . With the instinct of [a woman who has lived a by no means regular life in the midst of a society far worse than [herself]3204-a woman who has lived a by no means regular life in the midst of a society far worse than herself]3204-a woman who has lived a by no means regular life in the midst of a society far worse than herself , with the instinct of one of [those strange pseudo - French Continental mongrels with whom age always brings cynicism]3205-those strange pseudo - french continental mongrels with whom age always brings cynicism , [she]3204-a woman who has lived a by no means regular life in the midst of a society far worse than herself tries to account for the virtue of [Englishwomen]3206-englishwomen by accidental , and often rather nasty , necessities . [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany writes with the freedom and precision of [a Continental woman of [the world]573-the world of eighty years ago]3207-a continental woman of the world of eighty years ago ; and [her]426-mme remarks lose too much or gain too much by translation into [our]3203-our chaster language . " The charm of intimate society , "[426-mme] [she]426-mme winds up , conscious of the charms of [her]426-mme [own little salon full of [clever men]3210-clever men and [pretty women all well - acquainted with [each other]2262-each other]3211-pretty women all well - acquainted with each other]3209-own little salon full of clever men and pretty women all well - acquainted with each other - " the charm of intimate society is unknown in [England]13-england . "[3211-pretty women all well - acquainted with each other]

In short , the sooner [England]13-england be quitted , the better . Political , or rather financial circumstances - that is to say , the frightful worthlessness of French money and [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's and [her]426-mme money came mainly from [France]35-france , made a return to [Paris]4-paris urgent .

An incident , as curious perhaps as that of [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany 's presentation at [Court]3213-court , but which , unlike that , [Alfieri]196-alfieri has not thought fit to suppress , marked [their]3214-their departure from [England]13-england . As [Alfieri]196-alfieri , who had preceded [the Countess]1995-the countess by a few minutes to see whether the luggage had been properly stored on [the ship]3216-the ship at [Dover]163-dover , turned to go and meet [her]1995-the countess , [his]196-alfieri eyes suddenly fell with a start of recognition upon [a woman standing on the landing - place]3217-a woman standing on the landing - place . [She]3217-a woman standing on the landing - place was not young , but still very handsome , as some of [us]3218-us may know [her]3217-a woman standing on the landing - place from [Gainsborough]449-gainsborough 's portrait ; and [she]3217-a woman standing on the landing - place was no other than [Penelope Lady Ligonier]323-lady ligonier , for whom [Alfieri]196-alfieri had been so mad twenty years before , for whom [he]196-alfieri had fought [his]196-alfieri famous duel in [St. James ' Park]164-st. james ' park , and got [himself]196-alfieri disgracefully mixed up in a peculiarly disgraceful divorce suit . [He]196-alfieri had several times inquired after [her]3217-a woman standing on the landing - place , and always in vain ; and now [he]196-alfieri would scarcely have believed [his]196-alfieri eyes had [[his]196-alfieri former mistress]3219-his former mistress not given [him]196-alfieri a smile of recognition . [Alfieri]196-alfieri was terribly upset . The sight of this ghost from out of a disgraceful past , coming to haunt what [he]196-alfieri considered a dignified present , seems fairly to have terrified [him]196-alfieri ; [he]196-alfieri ran back into [the ship]3216-the ship and dared not go to meet [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany , lest in so doing [he]196-alfieri should meet [Lady Ligonier]323-lady ligonier . Presently , [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany came on board . With the indifference of [a woman of [the world]573-the world]3221-a woman of the world , of that easy - goingness which was rapidly effacing in [her]426-mme [the romantic victim of [Charles Edward]204-charles edward]3223-the romantic victim of charles edward , [she]426-mme told [Alfieri]196-alfieri that [the friends who had escorted [her]426-mme to [the ship]3216-the ship and who appear to have perfectly understood the temper of [the Countess]1995-the countess]3224-the friends who had escorted her to the ship and who appear to have perfectly understood the temper of the countess had pointed out [[his]196-alfieri former flame]3227-his former flame and entertained [her]426-mme with a brief biography of [[her]426-mme predecessor]3228-her predecessor in [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's heart . [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany took it all as a matter of course : [she]426-mme was probably no longer at all in love with [Alfieri]196-alfieri , but [she]426-mme admired [his]196-alfieri genius and character as much and more than ever ; and was probably beginning to develop a certain good - natured , half - motherly acquiescence in [his]196-alfieri eccentricities , such as [women who have suffered much , and grown stout and strong]3229-women who have suffered much , and grown stout and strong , and cynically optimistic now that suffering is over , are apt to develop towards [people accustomed to resort to [them]3230-people accustomed to resort to them , like sick children , in all their ups and downs of temper , like [sick children]3231-sick children , in all [their]3231-sick children ups and downs of temper]3230-people accustomed to resort to them , like sick children , in all their ups and downs of temper .

" Between [us]4040-us , "[196-alfieri] says [Alfieri]196-alfieri , " there was never any falsehood , or reticence , or coolness , or quarrel "[196-alfieri] ; - and , indeed , when [a woman]689-a woman , such as [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany must have been at the age of forty , has once determined to adore and humour [a particular individual]3233-a particular individual in every single possible thing , all such painful results of more sensitive passion naturally become unnecessary . If [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany merely smiled over bygone follies , [Alfieri]196-alfieri had been put into great agitation by the sight of [Lady Ligonier]323-lady ligonier . From [Calais]450-calais [he]196-alfieri sent [her]323-lady ligonier a letter , of which no copy has been preserved , but which , according to [his]196-alfieri account , " was full , not indeed of love , but of a deep and sincere emotion at seeing [her]323-lady ligonier still leading a wandering life very unsuited to [her]323-lady ligonier birth and position ; and of pain in thinking that [I]196-alfieri , although innocently that "[196-alfieri] although innocently " , on the part of [a man who had been the cause of [her]323-lady ligonier scandalous downfall]4041-a man who had been the cause of her scandalous downfall , is perfectly charming in its simple revelation of Continental morals , might have been the cause or the pretext thereof . "[196-alfieri]

[Lady Ligonier]323-lady ligonier 's answer came to hand in [Brussels]165-brussels . Written in bad French , it answered [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's tragic grandiloquence with a cold civility , which shows how deeply [his]196-alfieri magnanimous compassion had wounded [a woman who felt [herself]3234-a woman who felt herself to be no more really corrupt than he to be no more really corrupt than [he]196-alfieri]3234-a woman who felt herself to be no more really corrupt than he .

" [Monsieur]4042-monsieur , "[323-lady ligonier] so runs the letter , " [you]4042-monsieur could not doubt that the expression of [your]4042-monsieur remembrance of [me]323-lady ligonier , and of the interest which [you]4042-monsieur kindly take in [my]323-lady ligonier lot , would be duly appreciated and received gratefully by [me]323-lady ligonier ; the more especially as [I]323-lady ligonier can not consider [you]4042-monsieur as the cause of [my]323-lady ligonier unhappiness , since [I]323-lady ligonier am not unhappy , although the uprightness of [your]4042-monsieur soul makes [you]4042-monsieur fear that [I]323-lady ligonier am . [You]4042-monsieur were , on the contrary , the agent of [my]323-lady ligonier liberation from [a world for which [I]323-lady ligonier was in no way suited]4043-a world for which i was in no way suited , and which [I]323-lady ligonier have not for a moment regretted .... [I]323-lady ligonier am in the enjoyment of perfect health , increased by liberty and peace of mind . [I]323-lady ligonier seek the society only of [simple and virtuous persons without pretensions either to particular genius or to particular learning]4044-simple and virtuous persons without pretensions either to particular genius or to particular learning ; and besides such society [I]323-lady ligonier entertain [myself]323-lady ligonier with books , drawing , music , c. But what constitutes the basis of real happiness and satisfaction is the friendship and unalterable love of [a brother whom [I]323-lady ligonier have always loved more than [the whole world]2126-the whole world , and who possesses the best of hearts]4045-a brother whom i have always loved more than the whole world , and who possesses the best of hearts . "[323-lady ligonier] " [I]323-lady ligonier hear , "[323-lady ligonier] goes on [Lady Ligonier]323-lady ligonier , after a few compliments on [Alfieri]196-alfieri 's literary fame , " that [you]4042-monsieur are attached to [the Princess with whom [you]4042-monsieur are travelling]4047-the princess with whom you are travelling , whose amiable and clever physiognomy seems indeed formed for the happiness of a soul as sensitive and delicate as [yours]4042-monsieur . [I]323-lady ligonier am also told that [she]4047-the princess with whom you are travelling is afraid of [you]4042-monsieur : [I]323-lady ligonier recognise [you]4042-monsieur there . Without wishing , or perhaps even knowing it , [you]4042-monsieur have an irresistible ascendancy over all who are attached to [you]4042-monsieur . "[323-lady ligonier]

Was it this disrespectful hint concerning what [he]196-alfieri wished [the world]573-the world to consider as [his]196-alfieri ideal love for [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany , or was it [Lady Ligonier]323-lady ligonier 's determination to let [him]196-alfieri know that desertion by [him]196-alfieri had made [her]323-lady ligonier neither more disreputable nor more unhappy than before , [I]0-i can not tell ; but certain it is that something in this letter appears to have put [Alfieri]196-alfieri , who had not objected to [Mme]426-mme . d'Albany 's mean behaviour towards [George III]301-george iii . , into a condition of ruffled virtue and dignity .

" [I]196-alfieri copy this letter , "[196-alfieri] [he]196-alfieri writes in [his]196-alfieri memoirs , " in order to give an idea of [this woman]1716-this woman 's eccentric and obstinately evilly - inclined character . "[196-alfieri]

Did it never occur to [Alfieri]196-alfieri that [his]196-alfieri own character , whose faults during youth [he]196-alfieri so keenly appreciated , was not improving with years ?

CHAPTER XVI .

THE MISOGALLO .

[Alfieri]196-alfieri and [Madame d'Albany]534-madame d'albany were scarcely back in [Paris]4-paris , and settled in [a new house]3237-a new house , when the disorders in [Paris]4-paris and the movements of [the Imperial troops on [the frontier]894-the frontier]3238-the imperial troops on the frontier began to make the situation of [foreigners]3240-foreigners difficult and dangerous . The storming of [the Tuileries]451-the tuileries , the great slaughter of the 10th August 1792 , admonished [them]3241-their to sacrifice everything to [their]3241-their safety .
